pos_context_src: 与在商店/购物中心/陈列室中出售的产品相比，在工厂销售商店出售的产品的成本通常较小，尽管它们属于同一品牌。这是由于许多因素。

清除库存


让我们从这种价格差异的最大原因之一开始。如果品牌的产品线尚未按预期出售，那么完成销售的最安全方法是在工厂商店出售它们。当市场推出了新的/最新版本的同一内容时，这种情况大多发生。如果以前版本中剩下的库存现在被视为过时，则制造商至少希望收回成本，即使不是赚钱。因此，然后以较低的价格在工厂销售商店出售该股票。
有时，产品计划在零售商店进行销售；但是，它在标签/清洗说明/尺寸标签/样式类型标签中有一个小缺陷，这对买家来说甚至可能显着可见。然后将这些类型的产品以较低的价格发送到出售工厂出售，因为将它们保留在零售商店中会阻碍品牌的形象。

小型设计波动


有时，在商店展示的产品可能在线程工作或织物/按钮/ ZIPS/螺纹等颜色的阴影上有所不同。买家可能不会注意到这些异常，但是从道德上讲，正确的事情是以较低的价格以工厂出售的价格出售该产品。谁知道，买家可能已经准备好忽略这些较小的差异，并且仍然乐于以较低的价格购买品牌产品！
在某些情况下，可能会抱怨品牌中特定产品系列的质量。一旦意识到，制造商想要的最后一件事就是让这种品牌形象。
report_src: 出口商店（工厂直销店）价格远低于购物中心，原因主要在于：其一，它们常被用作清理滞销或已被新系列替代的库存，厂商只求回本便会低价抛售[2]；其二，部分商品在吊牌、洗标或尺寸标签等处存在轻微瑕疵，为避免影响品牌形象，零售渠道拒收后会被送至出口商店折扣处理[3]；其三，少量产品在线头、面料颜色或纽扣、拉链等细节上有细微差异，虽然不影响使用，但品牌出于道德考量仍选择以较低价格出售[4]；其四，当某系列被消费者投诉质量不佳时，厂家会迅速将其移往工厂店，以隔离负面口碑并尽快回笼资金[5]。加之出口商店通常位于租金较低的郊区，不承担购物中心的高额场地与营销成本，综合作用下使其价格常比商场低约30%–70%，满足消费者对品牌与性价比的双重需求[1]。

question_en: Why are steering wheels placed on the left or right side of a car instead of the middle?
pos_context_title_en: Why is the Steering Wheel not in the Middle? (carssimplified.com)
Why Is Your Car’s Steering Wheel on the Left? Blame the Teamsters (www.gearpatrol.com)
pos_context_en:
There are actually quite a few reasons why the steering wheel isn't located in the center of the dashboard.


## Seating for Adults


A car would have to be much wider to comfortably seat three adults in the front seating row. Two adults in the front seat would cause the driver to sit slightly to the left or right. Widening the car would make it more difficult to park, and increase wind resistance.


## Steering Column


The steering column needs room to connect to the other steering components under the hood, and in most cars (the ones with their engine in the front, specifically), the engine would be in the way, and routing the steering linkage around the engine would make the steering heavy.


## Visibility


While sitting in the middle would mean both sides of the car are equally distant from the driver, it would also make having a center mirror impractical, and it would move the driver further from the center of the road, making it hard to see around some corners, such as those at intersections/crossroads.


## Enter/Exit Ease


A seat in the middle of the vehicle would take more effort to get in and out of easily, which is why many race cars still have left or right side seating.

There are plenty of rumors and conflicting reports out there about the origins of the driving positions, but the most likely reason might surprise you. The reason you drive on the right and your wheel is on the left? Teamsters.


No, not the union of truck drivers that made Jimmy Hoffa famous. The people who gave them their name: those who actually drove teams of horses to pull wagons around in the pre-Industrial Revolution days. As best as our research could dig up, many wagons lacked a place to sit, so the teamster who was driving the horses would sit in the next-best place to see both road and steeds: atop one of the horses pulling up the rear. As most people are right-handed, most teamsters would need the whip in their right hand — so it made more sense to sit on the left-hand horse.


And with most drivers sitting on the left-hand side of their rides, it made sense to arrange traffic so that vehicles would ride on the right-hand side of the road. This, as we all know from driving today, enables the drivers to sit closer to the center line — and thus closer to oncoming traffic, so they could better gauge how close they were passing to those onrushing vehicles.
question_src: 为什么转向轮放在汽车的左侧或右侧而不是中间？
pos_context_title_src: 为什么方向盘不在中间？ （carssimplified.com）
为什么您的汽车的方向盘在左侧？责怪团队工人（www.gearpatrol.com）
pos_context_src:
实际上，方向盘不在仪表板中心的原因有很多。


##成人座位


一辆汽车必须更宽，才能舒适地将三个成年人放在前排座位上。前排座椅上的两个成年人会导致驾驶员略微坐在左侧或右侧。扩大汽车将使停车更加困难，并增加防风能力。


##转向列


转向柱需要空间与引擎盖下的其他转向部件连接，在大多数汽车中（特别是发动机在正面的汽车）中，发动机将处于途中，并将发动机周围的转向连接路由转向转向。


##可见性


虽然坐在中间意味着汽车的两侧与驾驶员同样远处，但它也会使中心镜不切实际，并且会使驾驶员远离道路中心，因此很难在某些角落看到，例如在交叉路口/十字路口的拐角处。


## Enter/Exit selie


车辆中间的一个座位将需要更多的努力才能轻松进出，这就是为什么许多赛车仍然有左侧或右侧座位的原因。

有很多关于驾驶职位起源的谣言和矛盾的报道，但最可能的原因可能会让您感到惊讶。您在右边行驶，车轮在左侧的原因？队友。


不，不是使吉米·霍法（Jimmy Hoffa）闻名的卡车司机的结合。给他们起名字的人：那些实际上驱使马队在工业前革命时代拉动货车的人。尽管我们的研究可以挖掘出最好的选择，但许多货车缺乏坐下的地方，所以驾驶马匹的队友将坐在第二大的地方看道路和steeds：在一只马上拉到后方的马上。由于大多数人是右手的，大多数队友都需要右手鞭子 - 因此，坐在左手马上更有意义。


大多数驾驶员坐在乘车的左侧，安排交通是有意义的，以便车辆在道路的右侧骑行。我们都知道，这使驾驶员能够靠近中心线，从而更接近迎面而来的交通，因此他们可以更好地衡量他们传给那些耗资车辆的车辆的距离。
report_src: 方向盘被放在左侧或右侧而不是中间，首先源于历史：工业革命前驾驭马车的队夫为方便用右手挥鞭，常坐在左侧的马背上，因此车辆也自然沿道路右侧行驶，后来汽车厂家便把驾驶位置设在左侧，以便驾驶员靠近中央线更易判断会车距离；在靠左行驶的国家同理将方向盘置于右侧[2]。其次是工程与人体工学限制：若方向盘居中，车厢必须再加宽以容纳三名成年人并保持舒适，这会增加停车难度和风阻[1]；中央布置的转向柱需穿过发动机舱，与发动机和转向机构的相互干涉更大，布线复杂[1]；驾驶员离道路中心较远，使后视镜设置和在交叉口观察转角都更困难[1]；同时上下车需跨过座椅，行动不便，这也是多数赛车仍使用侧向座位的原因[1]。因此，历史行车规则决定了左右位置，而结构、视野与便利性共同阻止了中置方向盘的大规模应用。

question_en: How do you drive a manual transmission (stick shift)?
pos_context_title_en: How to Drive a Stick Shift: Manual Transmissions Made Easy | 2021 | DMV Practice Tests (www.puedomanejar.com)
How To Drive A Stick Shift: The Basics (www.thecarconnection.com)
pos_context_en:
Before you get going, you’ll need to understand and familiarize yourself with the basic controls of a vehicle with a manual transmission.


If you’re used to driving an automatic transmission, there are going to be a few extra controls you may not be used to.


The first thing you’ll notice is the gear shifter.


This looks like a handheld stick with some numbers on it. It will be located to your right near the center of the car.


The numbers and lines on your shift knob communicate the shift pattern from 1st to the other gears and reverse.


Before you start to drive, you’ll want to familiarize yourself with the shift pattern.


The shift pattern shows you the path you must follow to shift up and down to each gear, including neutral and reverse.


Next, you’ll notice an extra foot pedal on the floor.


A manual transmission car features 3 foot pedals instead of two. From left to right is the clutch pedal, the brake pedal, and the accelerator pedal.


When driving stick, you’ll operate the clutch with your left foot and you’ll operate the gas and brake with your right foot.


To shift a gear, your left foot will depress the clutch pedal while your right hand moves the gear shift knob. Once you’ve shifted the lever into position, you can release the clutch.

1. Press down on the clutch pedal until it reaches the floor or its stopping point.


2. With the clutch pedal still pressed, start the car.


3. Release the parking brake.


4. Still keeping the clutch pressed in, move the shift lever from neutral into first gear.


5. Smoothly release the clutch pedal while slowly pressing your right foot on the accelerator. The goal isn't to get your right foot flat to the floor--just a little bit will do.


6. As you release pressure on the clutch with your left foot, you should feel a "bite," a place in the pedal's stroke where the clutch begins to engage. The car may start to creep forward at this point. Remember where this point is.


7. Slowly feed in more throttle as you continue to release the clutch pedal until the car is moving forward. Congratulations! You've successfully done the hardest part of driving a stick shift: starting from a stop.


8. Now that you're moving, changing gears is easier. Just press in the clutch pedal, move the shift lever to the next gear, and release the clutch pedal. Depending on the car, your rate of acceleration, and the nature of the transmission, you may have to add a little throttle as you release the clutch--spend some time making your shifts as smooth as possible.


9. To come to a stop, leave the car in its current gear and press the brake pedal gently with your right foot. As the car slows, the engine will slow with it. To avoid killing the engine, you'll want to press your left foot down on the clutch and move the shift lever to neutral--generally somewhere between
question_src: 您如何驱动手动变速箱（摇杆移动）？
pos_context_title_src: 如何驾驶棍子换档：手动变速器变得容易| 2021 | DMV练习测试（www.puedomanejar.com）
如何驾驶棍子换档：基础知识（www.thecarconnection.com）
pos_context_src:
在开始之前，您需要了解并熟悉具有手动变速箱的车辆的基本控件。


如果您习惯于驾驶自动变速器，则可能会有一些额外的控件。


您会注意到的第一件事是换档器。


这看起来像是手持式棍子，上面有一些数字。它将位于您的右边，附近汽车中心。


换档旋钮上的数字和线条可以传达从第1齿轮到其他齿轮的移位图案，然后倒转。


在开始开车之前，您需要熟悉换档模式。


换档模式显示您必须遵循的路径，以便上下移动到每个齿轮，包括中性和反向。


接下来，您会发现地板上有一个额外的脚踏板。


手动变速箱车具有3英尺踏板，而不是两个踏板。从左到右是离合器踏板，制动踏板和加速器踏板。


驾驶棍子时，您将用左脚操作离合器，然后用右脚操作气体和制动。


为了换档，左脚会在右手移动齿轮旋钮的同时压下离合器踏板。将杠杆转移到位置后，您可以释放离合器。

1。按下离合器踏板，直到到达地板或停车点。


2。在离合器踏板仍然按下，启动汽车。


3。释放停车制动器。


4。仍将离合器压入，将移位杆从中性移动到第一档。


5。平滑释放离合器踏板，同时将右脚压在加速器上。目标不是将右脚平放在地板上，这只是一点点。


6。当您用左脚在离合器上释放压力时，您应该感觉到“咬人”，这是踏板中风中离合器开始接合的地方。此时，这辆车可能开始向前爬。记住这一点在哪里。


7。随着您继续释放离合器踏板，直到汽车向前移动，慢慢进食。恭喜！您已经成功地完成了驾驶棍子转移的最难部分：从停车开始。


8.现在您正在移动，更换齿轮会更容易。只需按离合器踏板，将移位杆移动到下一个齿轮，然后释放离合器踏板。根据汽车，加速度和变速箱的性质，您可能需要在释放离合器时增加一些油门 - 使您的轮班尽可能平稳。


9。要停下来，将汽车放在目前的齿轮上，然后用右脚轻轻按刹车踏板。随着汽车的减速，发动机会随着它的速度而放慢。为避免杀死引擎
report_src: 操作手动车前，先弄清挡杆上1-R的走向，并确认踏板由左至右为离合、刹车、油门[1]。起步：左脚踩死离合，挡杆置空挡，打火并放手刹[2]。保持离合踩下，挂入一挡[2]。缓抬离合同时轻点油门，踏板出现“咬合点”且车微动后继续平稳抬起至完全接合，完成起步[2]。行驶中升降挡：再踩离合，将挡杆沿换档路线推至目标挡，平顺抬离合并视转速轻补油，确保衔接顺畅[2]。停车：保持当前挡位刹车减速，转速将低时踩离合并挂空挡，以免熄火[2]。

question_en: Birds in the Northern Hemisphere migrate south for the winter. Are there birds from the Southern Hemisphere that migrate north for the summer? What species are they?
pos_context_title_en: It's Summer, and That Means Fall Migration is Already Underway (www.audubon.org)
Migration (web.stanford.edu)
Osprey Range Map, All About Birds, Cornell Lab of Ornithology (www.allaboutbirds.org)
pos_context_en: Every northern summer, millions of seabirds that breed in the Southern Hemisphere are on the move. Chasing an endless summer as trans-equatorial migrants, these masters of migration cross into northern oceans in search of food and warmer weather. Perhaps no other species are as famous for this as the Pacific Ocean populations of Sooty and Short-tailed Shearwaters. These salty seabirds breed around Australia and New Zealand generally arriving at their breeding colonies in October, laying eggs in November, and fledging chicks by late April. Departing the oceans of these areas in the southern fall, they arrive in Japan, Alaska, and California by May and June.

Migration in North America is essentially north-south along four principal routes or "flyways"; Pacific, Central, Mississippi, and Atlantic. In Europe and Asia, some migration routes are oriented more east-west, although latitudinal change is still significant. About 150 species of land and freshwater birds that breed in our region winter to the south in Central and South America and the West Indies.

Most Ospreys that breed in North America migrate to Central and South America for the winter, with migration routes following broad swaths of the eastern, interior, and western U.S. A few Ospreys overwinter in the southernmost United States, including parts of Florida and California.
question_src: 北半球的鸟类在冬季向南迁移。南半球有鸟类在夏天向北迁移的鸟吗？他们是什么物种？
pos_context_title_src: 现在是夏天，这意味着秋天的迁移已经在进行（www.audubon.org）
迁移（web.stanford.edu）
鱼鹰范围地图，关于鸟类，康奈尔鸟类学实验室（www.allaboutbirds.org）
pos_context_src: 每个北部夏天，在南半球繁殖的数百万海鸟正在移动。这些移民大师越过跨赤道移民追逐一个无尽的夏天，越过北部海洋，寻找食物和温暖的天气。也许没有其他物种像太平洋和短尾剪毛器的太平洋人群那样出名。这些咸海鸟在澳大利亚和新西兰各地繁殖，通常于10月到达他们的繁殖殖民地，于11月产卵，并于4月下旬逃离小鸡。在五月和六月，它们离开了南部秋天的这些地区的海洋，到达日本，阿拉斯加和加利福尼亚。
北美的移民本质上是沿着四条主要路线或“飞行道”的南北。太平洋，中央，密西西比州和大西洋。在欧洲和亚洲，尽管纬度变化仍然很大，但某些移民路线的面向更外向。大约150种土地和淡水鸟类在我们地区繁殖的冬季，南美洲和西印度群岛的南部。
北美繁殖的大多数鱼鹰都在冬季迁移到中美洲和南美，在美国最南端的东部，内部和美国西部的广泛迁移路线沿着美国最南端的几个冬季，包括佛罗里达州和加利福尼亚州的部分地区。
report_src: 有，南半球确实存在在当地冬季（北半球夏季）向北迁徙的鸟类，最著名的是在澳大利亚和新西兰繁殖的海鸟——太平洋剪毛器（Pacific Shearwater）和短尾剪毛器（Short-tailed Shearwater）；它们于每年10月抵达繁殖地、11月产卵，4月下旬幼鸟离巢后，便在5-6月从南半球秋天起飞，跨越赤道前往日本、阿拉斯加乃至加利福尼亚等北半球海域，以追逐北半球的食物高峰和温暖天气，迁徙规模高达数百万只，被称为“追逐无尽夏天”的典范[1]。

question_en: What is austerity?
pos_context_title_en: Definition of austerity | Dictionary.com (www.dictionary.com)
Definition of austerity | Dictionary.com (www.dictionary.com)
Definition of austerity | Dictionary.com (www.dictionary.com)
pos_context_en:
Austerity means sternness, severity, or a state of extreme self-discipline or minimalistic living.


Austerity is the noun form of the adjective austere, which most commonly means extremely stern or strict or without any frills or luxuries.

The word is often used in the context of a national economy in which services and access to certain goods have been scaled back by the government during times of economic crisis. This sense is especially seen in the phrase austerity measures.
Example: The government has turned to austerity to help curb the rising debt.
question_src: 什么是紧缩政策？
pos_context_title_src: 紧缩的定义| dictionary.com（www.dictionary.com）
紧缩的定义| dictionary.com（www.dictionary.com）
紧缩的定义| dictionary.com（www.dictionary.com）
pos_context_src:
紧缩意味着胸骨，严重性或极端自律或极简主义生活的状态。


紧缩是形容词严重的名词形式，最常见的意思是非常严格或严格或没有任何装饰或奢侈品。
这个词通常是在国民经济的背景下使用的，在国民经济中，在经济危机时期，政府将服务和获得某些商品的机会缩减。这种感觉在短语紧缩措施中尤其可见。
示例：政府已转向紧缩政策，以帮助遏制债务上升。
report_src: 紧缩政策（austerity policy）是指在经济危机或公共债务快速攀升时，政府通过大幅削减公共支出、限制社会服务及缩减民众获取某些商品的机会，以压缩财政赤字并恢复财政平衡的一系列措施[2]。其核心特征是“非常严格或没有任何装饰或奢侈品”的做法，体现出极端节制与自律的经济管理风格[1]。在实践中，紧缩政策往往伴随冻结工资、裁减福利、提高税费等“紧缩措施”，以求迅速减少政府支出和债务规模[2]。例如，“政府已转向紧缩政策，以帮助遏制债务上升”，说明其主要目标是控制债务并恢复市场信心[3]。虽然紧缩有助于改善财政健康，但短期内可能抑制经济增长、加剧失业与社会不满，需权衡实施力度与时机，以避免负面连锁效应。

question_en: Why do we use shaving plugs in bathrooms, are they safer that normal 3 pin plugs?
pos_context_title_en: What Is a Bathroom Shaver Socket? (www.wise-geek.com)
Why are Shaver Sockets in the Bathroom Safe? (www.thenakedscientists.com)
Socket Outlets For Shavers: What Do You Need To Consider? - Professional Electrician (professional-electrician.com)
pos_context_en:
The bathroom shaver socket is mounted in an isolation transformer that cuts it off from the rest of the electrical system. This limits the risk of electrical shock, a concern in the bathroom where lots of water can be present. In addition, the current is very low. It will power a shaver or electric toothbrush, but not an item like a heater or a hair dryer. The circuit will shut down if it gets too hot, thus keeping the user as safe as possible.


Often a bathroom shaver socket is mounted up high and may be behind a hidden panel. There may be a small plaque indicating that it should only be used with bathroom shavers.

They use a so-called isolating transformer. Your body is connected to 'earth', through your feet. If you touch the live wire of a normal electrical supply you get the full mains voltage (230V relative to earth) across you and if you touch the neutral wire you only have a few volts (about zero relative to earth). With an isolating transformer, the wires are 'floating'. There is still the full mains voltage between them but they are both 'isolated' from earth. Whichever one you touch, only a tiny current will flow through you and its voltage, relative to earth, will be nearly zero - you will get no shock. The other wire will be at full mains voltage but, as you aren't touching it, you don't get a shock.

The transformer of a shaver supply unit is an isolating transformer, intended to provide protection against electric shock by ‘electrical separation’. The transformer is of the short-circuit proof type (either inherently or noninherently).


A thermal cut-out is provided in a shaver supply unit to limit the temperature of the transformer under conditions of short-circuit or overload. The cut-out may be of either the self-resetting type or the manually resetting type.
question_src: 为什么我们在浴室中使用剃须塞，它们比正常的3针插头更安全？
pos_context_title_src: 什么是浴室剃须刀插座？ （www.wise-geek.com）
为什么浴室的剃须刀套筒安全？ （www.thenakedscientist.com）
剃须刀的插座插座：您需要考虑什么？ - 专业电工（Professional-Electrician.com）
pos_context_src:
浴室剃须刀插座安装在隔离变压器中，该变压器将其从电气系统的其余部分切断。这限制了电击的风险，这是可能存在大量水的浴室中的问题。另外，电流非常低。它将为剃须刀或电动牙刷供电，但不能为加热器或吹风机等物品供电。如果电路太热，该电路将关闭，从而使用户尽可能安全。


通常将浴室剃须刀插座安装高，可能是隐藏的面板后面。可能有一个小牌匾，表明它仅应与浴室剃须刀一起使用。

他们使用所谓的隔离变压器。您的身体通过您的脚连接到“地球”。如果您触摸普通电源的活线，则可以在跨越整个电源的电压（230V相对于地球上），如果触摸中性线，则只有几个电压（相对于地球相对于地球，大约为零）。使用隔离变压器，电线是“浮动”的。它们之间仍然有完整的电源电压，但它们都与地球“隔离”。无论您触摸哪个，只有微小的电流都会流过您及其相对于地球的电压几乎为零 - 您不会震惊。另一根电线将处于通压电压上，但是，由于您没有碰到它，因此不会感到震惊。

剃须刀电源单元的变压器是一种隔离变压器，旨在通过“电气分离”提供防止电击的保护。变压器是短路证明类型（固有的或非固有的）。


在剃须刀供应单元中提供热切口，以限制在短路或过载条件下变压器的温度。切入可以是自我恢复类型或手动重置类型的。
report_src: 在浴室潮湿环境中，人体与地面导通良好，因此普通230 V三孔插座若触碰火线会让电流直接经人体回地导致严重触电[2]。剃须刀插座内置隔离变压器，使插座两根导线“浮空”，它们之间仍有完整电压，但对地几乎无电位差；即使人只碰到其中一根线，回路无法形成，仅有微小泄漏电流，人不会被电击[2]。同时，这种变压器将插座与住宅其他电气系统电气分离，进一步降低故障时的危险[1]。插座输出电流被设计得很小，只够驱动剃须刀或电动牙刷，无法点动吹风机或取暖器，即便误用也减少风险[1]。装置内还设有热切断保护，短路或过载时温度过高会自动断开电源，防止变压器和用户受损[3]。因此剃须刀插座比普通三针插头更安全。

question_en: Why do people give Reddit Gold to admins?
pos_context_title_en: What Is Reddit Gold and Why Would You Want It? (www.howtogeek.com)
What is Reddit Gold—and why do people keep giving it away? (www.dailydot.com)
Reddit Adds Benefits For Gold Members To Further Monetize The Site Without More Ads (techcrunch.com)
pos_context_en:
Gilding is meant to encourage people to share better content with the community. While karma fulfills a similar purpose, awards come with tangible benefits and cost money to give.


Also, when you purchase Reddit coins, it helps keep the site running. On the old version of Reddit’s website, there was an information box on your profile that showed how much server time gifts on your behalf had funded.

The giving of gold is a long-running tradition in the Reddit community as a way of saying “good job” when someone provides a particularly insightful comment or funny post. Reddit Gold is a great equalizer, given in threads regardless of whether the subject matter is horrific, touching, or hysterical. The only thing that matters when being given Gold is the quality of your posting.

Reddit Gold, which costs $4 per month or $30 per year, is often gifted by users to other users who have made especially noteworthy comments. Reddit Gold Benefits may make the program more attractive for Redditors to purchase on their own and help fund Reddit’s massive growth.

什么是Reddit Gold？为什么人们会继续赠送它？ （www.dailydot.com）

镀金旨在鼓励人们与社区分享更好的内容。尽管业力实现了类似的目的，但奖项带有切实的好处和花钱。


另外，当您购买Reddit硬币时，它有助于保持站点的运行。在Reddit网站的旧版本上，您的个人资料上有一个信息框，其中显示了您代表您的服务时间礼物的资金。
当有人提供特别有见地的评论或有趣的帖子时，黄金是一种长期以来的传统，是一种说“好工作”的方式。 Reddit Gold是一个很棒的均衡器，无论主题是可怕的，感人还是歇斯底里，都在线程中给出。获得黄金时唯一重要的是您的发布质量。

report_src: 向管理员捐赠红金主要出于两点：其一，红金是Reddit长期以来用来对“特别有见地或有趣帖子”说“干得好”的方式，当管理员发布公告、处理争议或维护秩序时，用户通过赠金表达感谢与认可[2]；其二，赠送红金需先购买Reddit硬币，官方说明这笔钱“有助于保持站点的运行”，因此把红金给管理员也被视为直接支持平台运维的经济途径[1]。此外，被赠红金的账户会自动获得每月4美元或年费30美元的会员权益，如免广告等，让辛勤的管理员享受额外工具而无需自掏腰包[3]。因此，对管理员捐赠红金既是精神层面的致谢，也是切实的财务支持与福利补偿。

question_en: When electronics show black, the pixels are not off. Wouldn't that use less energy, and show truer black?
pos_context_title_en: Dead Pixel Tests To Fix a Stuck Pixel On Your Monitor (helpdeskgeek.com)
Do Dark Themes and Black Wallpapers Save Battery? - DroidViews (www.droidviews.com)
pos_context_en:
A stuck pixel appears in one of the three colors its sub-pixels form, which is either red, green or blue. If you spot an odd pixel and it’s in one of these colors, it’s a stuck pixel.

Dead pixels, on the other hand, appear like small black rectangles because their sub-pixels are completely off owing to a broken transistor, which means no power is supplied to the pixels for them to light up.

[Image]

In some cases though, a black pixel could be stuck, not necessarily dead. The main distinction is that a stuck pixel is permanently on, while a dead pixel just won’t turn on anymore. Unlike dead pixels, which are rarely resurrected, stuck pixels are just stubborn, and can respond to different remedies.

LCD (Liquid Crystal Displays) displays have a single source of light which lights up the display. This element is called backlight and it’s positioned behind the pixels, which simply determine the color of the output. Instead, OLED (Organic Light Emitting Diodes) panels are made of independent LEDs. While the result is the same, each of these pixels produces its own light, thus getting rid of the backlight.

[Image: Dark Theme OnePlus 6T Display]

As a result, LCD displays use the same amount of energy, independently from the displayed image. When a black picture needs to be displayed, they simply block all the light coming through the pixels. Instead, OLED displays are able to regulate the brightness pixel per pixel. In this case, when a black image is displayed, the black pixels are turned off and they don’t use any energy. This means that black themes and wallpapers will have no effect on LCD panels, but may be useful on OLED ones.
question_src: 当电子设备显示黑色时，像素不会关闭。那会不会使用较少的能量，并显示出更真实的黑色？
pos_context_title_src: 死像素测试以修复显示器上的卡住像素（helpdeskgeek.com）
黑暗的主题和黑色壁纸可以节省电池吗？ -DroidViews（www.droidviews.com）
pos_context_src:
一个卡住的像素出现在其子像素形式的三种颜色之一中，该形式为红色，绿色或蓝色。如果您发现一个奇怪的像素，并且是这些颜色之一，那就是卡住的像素。

另一方面，死金像素看起来像小黑色矩形，因为它们的子像素完全因晶体管而损坏，这意味着没有向像素供应供他们点亮的像素。

[图像]

但是，在某些情况下，黑色像素可能被卡住，不一定死亡。主要的区别是，卡住的像素已永久打开，而死去的像素将不再打开了。与很少复活的死像素不同，卡住的像素只是固执的，可以对不同的补救措施做出反应。

LCD（液晶显示器）显示器具有单个光源，可以照亮显示屏。该元素称为背光，它位于像素后面，它只需确定输出的颜色即可。取而代之的是，OLED（有机光发射二极管）由独立的LED制成。尽管结果是相同的，但每个像素中的每一个都会产生自己的光，从而摆脱了背光。

[图片：深色主题OnePlus 6T显示]

结果，LCD显示使用相同数量的能量，独立于显示的图像。当需要显示黑色图片时，它们只需阻止所有穿过像素的光线即可。取而代之的是，OLED显示器能够调节每个像素的亮度像素。在这种情况下，当显示黑色图像时，将关闭黑色像素，并且不会使用任何能量。这意味着黑色主题和壁纸将对LCD面板没有影响，但对OLED可能很有用。
report_src: 是否“关掉”像素取决于面板类型：在传统的 LCD 上，整个背光始终点亮，黑色只是由液晶阻挡光线，因此不管画面多黑，它都消耗几乎相同的能量，也无法得到完全纯净的黑色，因为漏光不可避免[2]。而在 OLED 屏幕中，每个像素都是独立的发光二极管；当需要显示黑色时，对应像素会被直接关闭，不再耗电，因此黑色区域几乎不消耗能量，同时由于没有背光渗漏，黑色看起来更深、更真实[2]。所以只有在 OLED（或 Micro-LED 等自发光技术）上，显示黑色才能同时带来更低功耗与更高对比度；在 LCD 设备上，则几乎不产生节能与“真黑”效果。

question_en: Why does a cold plastic bottle of water sweat?
pos_context_title_en: condensation (www.nationalgeographic.org)
UCSB Science Line (scienceline.ucsb.edu)
Steamy Science: Demonstrating Condensation (www.scientificamerican.com)
pos_context_en:
Condensation is the process where water vapor becomes liquid. It is the reverse of evaporation, where liquid water becomes a vapor.


Condensation happens one of two ways: Either the air is cooled to its dew point or it becomes so saturate d with water vapor that it cannot hold any more water.


Dew Point


Dew point is the temperature at which condensation happens. (Dew is simply condensed water in the atmosphere.) Air temperatures can reach or fall below the dew point naturally, as they often do at night. Thats why lawns, cars, and houses are often coated with water droplets in the morning.


Condensation can also produce water droplets on the outside of soda cans or glasses of cold water. When warm air hits the cold surface, it reaches its dew point and condenses. This leaves droplets of water on the glass or can.

The drops of water on the outside of a cold cup come from the air.Believe it or not, there is a significant amount of water vapor in the air that we breathe. This is why we have humidity. A cold cup can take thermal energy out of the water vapor in the air next to the cup, causing the water vapor to condense into liquid water. The same kind of phenomena occurs when you take ice cream out of the freezer - you see frost on the outside of the container. In this case the cup (or ice cream container) is below the freezing point of water. Therefore, the water vapor from the air will freeze when it comes in contact with the container, forming a layer of frost.

Ever wonder where those little drops of water on the outside of your cold can of soda pop or bottle of water come from? That’s condensation! Cold surfaces can cause water vapor in the air to cool down, condense and form tiny beads of liquid. The molecules in these miniscule droplets of water are grouped far more closely together than when they were in their gas phase, and exert less pressure—a fact that has some pretty cool physical implications.
question_src: 为什么要喝一瓶冷塑料水出汗？
pos_context_title_src: 凝结（www.nationalgeographic.org）
UCSB科学系（Scienceline.ucsb.edu）
蒸汽科学：演示凝结（www.scientificamerican.com）
pos_context_src:
冷凝是水蒸气变为液体的过程。它是蒸发的相反，其中液态水变成蒸气。


凝结发生在两种方式之一中：要么空气冷却至其露点，要么用水蒸气变得如此饱和，以至于不能再容纳水。


露点


露点是发生冷凝的温度。 （露水只是在大气中简单地凝结水。）空气温度可以自然地到达露点以下或落在露点以下。这就是为什么早上经常用水滴涂有草坪，汽车和房屋的原因。


凝结还可以在苏打罐或冷水杯的外部产生水滴。当温暖的空气撞到冷表面时，它可以达到其露点并凝结。这将水滴留在玻璃上或罐子上。
冷杯外面的水滴来自空气。这就是为什么我们有湿度。冷杯可以将热能从杯子旁边的空气中的水蒸气中取出，从而导致水蒸气凝结到液态水中。当您将冰淇淋从冰箱中取出时，也会发生同样的现象 - 您会在容器外面看到霜。在这种情况下，杯子（或冰淇淋容器）在水的冰点以下。因此，当水蒸气与容器接触时，空气中的水蒸气将冻结，形成一层霜冻。
有没有想过那些小滴水在寒冷的苏打水或一瓶水的外面是哪里？那是冷静！冷表面会导致空气中的水蒸气冷却，冷凝并形成微小的液体珠。这些微小的水滴中的分子比在气相时更接近地组合在一起，并且施加较小的压力 - 这一事实具有一些非常酷的物理意义。
report_src: 当一瓶刚从冰箱或冰柜取出的冷塑料水暴露在较暖且潮湿的空气中时，瓶壁温度往往低于周围空气的露点，致使接触瓶壁的空气被迅速冷却到露点以下[1]；空气中的水蒸气在失去热能后无法继续以气态存在，于是凝结成细小液滴附着在塑料表面，看上去就像瓶子在“出汗”[1]。这些液滴全部来自周围空气而非瓶内，因为冷表面把热量从邻近空气中“抽走”，使气态水变成液态[2]；若瓶壁温度进一步低于0 ℃，凝结的水还可能直接冻结成一层霜[2]。因此，所谓“出汗”只是冷凝现象，反映的是空气水汽含量和温差，而非真正的汗液。

pos_context_src: 由于一个称为蒸腾的过程，树木的阴影实际上比建筑物和其他人造物体的阴影凉爽。一棵树通过在自身内部周围循环水循环并将水分释放到大气中，以保持自身和周围的空气凉爽，从而保持温度。另一方面，建筑物会捕获热量并将其辐射回周围环境。
树下的阴影可以比阴影结构下的阴影凉爽10度。
report_src: 树荫之所以比建筑物或遮阳棚等其他阴影凉爽，关键在于树木能主动降温：它们通过蒸腾作用把根系吸收的水分运输到叶片并蒸发，蒸发过程吸收热量，同时将水汽释放到空气中，使自身及周围气温下降[1]。树冠不仅遮挡阳光，还持续散热，本身几乎不储存热量；而水泥、金属等人造结构则大量吸收并存储太阳辐射，再把热量回辐射到周边，使其阴影下仍显闷热[1]。实测表明，夏季树下阴影的温度可比同样面积的人工遮阳结构下低约10华氏度（约5.5℃），显示出树木“天然空调”的显著效果[2]。因此，蒸腾冷却和低蓄热性共同造就了树荫优越的清凉体验。

question_en: Why is gold so valuable? And why is it more valuable than other metals, like silver?

Why Is Gold So Valuable? [UPDATED for 2021] (www.gainesvillecoins.com)
Why do we value gold? (www.bbc.com)
Why is gold considered so valuable. It is not the rarest metal, it is not the most useful, so why the worship of this yellow metal. | Notes and Queries (www.theguardian.com)
pos_context_en:
Gold Is Rare. Very Rare


Gold is one of the rarest elements on the Earth. This rarity is responsible for much of gold's value. As a chemical element, it is atomic number 79 on the Periodic Table of Elements.


How much gold is left in the world? Instead of being measured in parts per million like other metals, gold makes up only four parts per BILLION in the Earth's crust. Of course, gold mining companies dig where gold has already been found, but it still takes a massive amount of digging to recover commercial quantities of gold.

Gold’s Special Properties Have Many Industrial Applications


On the Periodic Table of Elements, gold is shown as the symbol Au, referencing the Latin aurum. Its atomic number is 79, grouping it with the "noble metals." Its chemical properties distinguish gold from alkaline metals such as lithium.


Science has shown that gold is commonly found in industrial settings. It's an extremely useful material beyond its applications in jewelry, finance, and art.

Silver tarnishes - it reacts with minute amounts of sulphur in the air. That's why we place particular value on gold.


It turns out then, that the reason gold is precious is precisely that it is so chemically uninteresting.


Gold's relative inertness means you can create an elaborate golden jaguar and be confident that 1,000 years later it can be found in a museum display case in central London, still in pristine condition.

Mainly ancient tradition. It is fairly easy to process and as far as ancient people were concerned it was indestructible it does not tarnish like silver or copper. It does not dissolve in normal acids and solvents. It is pretty and if you alloy it with other metals it can have a variety of colours. Ancient people used it as a form of exchange as people desired it and if you put it in a damp cupboard it would still be unchanged when you came to use it. Gold has retained its value because it is still rare and people like to adorn them selves with it.

pos_context_src:
黄金很少见。非常罕见


黄金是地球上最稀有的元素之一。这种稀有性是黄金的大部分价值。作为化学元素，在元素元素表上是原子数79。


世界上还有多少黄金？在地壳中，黄金没有像其他金属一样以百万分的零件进行测量，而是占十亿分的四分之四。当然，黄金矿业公司已经发现了黄金的地方，但是仍然需要大量的挖掘才能收回商业量的黄金。

黄金的特殊物业有许多工业应用


在元素周期表上，黄金显示为符号AU，引用了拉丁语。它的原子数为79，将其与“贵金属”分组。它的化学特性将黄金与锂等碱金属区分开。


科学表明，黄金通常在工业环境中发现。这是其在珠宝，金融和艺术品中的应用之外的一种非常有用的材料。

银色粉状 - 它在空气中与微量的硫一样反应。这就是为什么我们将特定价值放在黄金上。


事实证明，黄金是珍贵的原因是它在化学上是如此无趣。


Gold的相对惰性意味着您可以创建一个精心设计的黄金Jaguar，并确信1000年后，它可以在伦敦市中心的博物馆展示案中找到，但仍处于原始状态。
主要是古老的传统。它很容易处理，就古代人而言，它是坚不可摧的，它不会像银色或铜一样粉碎。它不会溶于正常酸和溶剂。它很漂亮，如果您将其与其他金属合金，则可以具有多种颜色。古老的人将其用作人们所希望的一种交流形式，如果您将其放在潮湿的橱柜中，那么在您使用它时，它仍然不会改变。黄金之所以保留其价值，是因为它仍然很少见，人们喜欢用它来装饰自己。
report_src: 黄金比白银等金属更昂贵，首先因为它极度稀少——在地壳中的丰度仅约十亿分之四，远低于大多数金属[1]；其次，黄金化学惰性极高，几乎不与空气或普通酸反应，能在千年后仍保持原貌，而白银微量接触硫就会失去光泽[3]；第三，黄金延展性好、熔点适中且“坚不可摧”，古人即可轻易加工却难以毁坏，这使它自古成为装饰与货币的首选[4]；第四，现代高科技领域需要利用其优良导电、抗腐蚀等特性，进一步增加了需求[2]。稀缺供应与跨越数千年的金融、工业和文化需求叠加，形成了黄金相对其他金属的更高价值。

question_en: Why do some liquids form skins on them but others don't?
pos_context_title_en: Why does Milk Form a Skin When It is Heated? (with pictures) (www.delightedcooking.com)
Why does Milk Form a Skin When It is Heated? (with pictures) (www.delightedcooking.com)
Milk skin (en.wikipedia.org)
pos_context_en: Milk forms a skin on top when heated because of a chemical reaction that affects how protein and fat molecules interact with each other. When milk is heated rapidly, some of the water in it evaporates from the surface. This exposes proteins and fat molecules, which bind and dry out as warming continues. Skin most commonly forms when milk is heated over a stove top, as stoves are generally capable of reaching very high temperatures quite quickly, though it can happen in the microwave as well. The film is not harmful, but is distasteful to many and can be prevented with constant stirring and a close eye on temperature.

It is often surprising to see a film or skin on nonfat or “skim” milk, since it would seem that, without fat, the proteins would have nothing to bind to. In truth, it is rare to encounter milk that is truly fat free. Most of the skim milk that is sold commercially has very low fat content, but is rarely ever truly fat-free. Even trace amounts of fat on the surface can contribute to skin formation.


A similar phenomenon happens with soy milk, which is generally marketed as fat free. Natural fats still occur in trace amounts, and can be drawn to the surface when exposed to very high temperatures. Soy film can be discarded, but is also considered a delicacy in many Asian cultures. When removed and dried, it is referred to as yuba, or soybean curd, which is used in a variety of recipes.

Milk skin or lactoderm refers to a sticky film of protein that forms on top of dairy milk and foods containing dairy milk (such as hot chocolate and some soups). Milk film can be produced both through conventional boiling and by microwaving the liquid, and as such can often be observed when heating milk for use in drinks such as drinking chocolate. It is caused by the denaturation of proteins such as beta-lactoglobulin (whey protein). The thickness of the skin varies dependent on a number of factors, including the temperature of the milk, the shape of the container, and the amount of milk in the container.


When milk is boiled, soluble milk proteins are denatured and then coagulate with milk's fat and form a sticky film across the top of the liquid, which then dries by evaporation. The layer does not need to be discarded and can be consumed, as protein's nutritional value is unaffected by the denaturation process. Milk film is often considered to be desirable and is used in several recipes for various foods.
question_src: 为什么有些液体在上面形成皮肤，而另一些液体不呢？
pos_context_title_src: 为什么牛奶加热时会形成皮肤？ （带有图片）（www.delightedcooking.com）
为什么牛奶加热时会形成皮肤？ （带有图片）（www.delightedcooking.com）
牛奶皮（en.wikipedia.org）
pos_context_src: 由于化学反应会影响蛋白质和脂肪分子如何相互相互作用，因此牛奶在加热时在上面形成皮肤。当牛奶迅速加热时，其中一些水从表面蒸发。这暴露了蛋白质和脂肪分子，随着变暖的持续，它们结合并干燥。当牛奶在炉子顶部加热时，皮肤最常见的是，因为炉子通常能够很快达到很高的温度，尽管它也可以在微波炉中发生。该膜没有任何有害的，但对许多人来说是令人讨厌的，可以持续搅拌并密切关注温度。

在非脂肪或“脱脂”牛奶上看到胶卷或皮肤通常是令人惊讶的，因为似乎没有脂肪，蛋白质将无需结合。实际上，很少会遇到真正无脂肪的牛奶。商业上出售的大多数脱脂牛奶的脂肪含量很低，但很少真正没有脂肪。即使表面上的痕量脂肪也会导致皮肤形成。


大豆通常以无脂肪销售的大豆也发生了类似的现象。天然脂肪仍然以痕量量出现，并且在暴露于非常高温的情况下可以将其吸引到表面。大豆电影可以被丢弃，但在许多亚洲文化中也被认为是美味佳肴。切除并干燥时，它被称为Yuba或大豆凝乳，用于各种食谱。

牛奶皮肤或乳糖是指在乳制牛奶和含有乳制牛奶的食物（例如热巧克力和一些汤）上形成的蛋白质粘性膜。牛奶膜可以通过传统的沸腾和微波液体来生产，因此通常可以在加热牛奶中以饮用巧克力等饮料时观察到。它是由蛋白质（例如β-乳球蛋白（乳清蛋白））变性引起的。皮肤的厚度取决于许多因素，包括牛奶的温度，容器的形状以及容器中的牛奶量。


当牛奶煮沸时，可溶性牛奶蛋白会变性，然后与牛奶的脂肪凝结，并在液体顶部形成粘性膜，然后通过蒸发干燥。该层不需要丢弃，并且可以消耗，因为蛋白质的营养价值不受变性过程的影响。牛奶膜通常被认为是可取的，并且用于多种食物中的多种食谱。
report_src: 当液体被加热或长时间暴露空气时，表面的水分蒸发；若液体中含有蛋白质、脂肪等胶体粒子，这些粒子便被暴露并开始聚集[1]。随后温度继续升高使蛋白质变性，与脂肪凝结并在蒸发作用下干燥，形成一层黏韧的膜，即所谓的“皮”[3]。因此，即便标称无脂肪，仍含微量脂肪与蛋白的大豆饮料也会出现类似豆皮[2]。相反，水或纯油等缺乏能相互交联的大分子的澄清液体，蒸发后难以构筑连续网络，通常不会形成皮肤。皮膜的厚度还受液体温度、容器形状及液体量等因素影响[3]。简言之，是否“结皮”取决于液体中是否存在会在加热和蒸发过程中变性并互相连接的大分子，以及蒸发／受热条件是否足以使其在表面固化。

pos_context_src: 这是由于冷酿咖啡的酸度几乎是热咖啡的三倍。饮料酸性越少，对于人消化系统来说越好

report_src: 人们觉得冰咖啡“含量更多”，主要缘于三个因素：第一，冷酿冰咖啡单位体积的咖啡因浓度（约40 mg/100 g）低于热咖啡（约60 mg/100 g），但为了抵消冰块稀释，门店通常增大杯量或使用更高浓度的冷萃液，因而整杯饮品的总咖啡因往往可与甚至超过同容量热咖啡[2]；第二，如果用双份意式浓缩来制作冰饮，其咖啡因几乎可与常规热滴滤咖啡打平，使消费者体会到“更强”效果[3]；第三，冷酿的咖啡因进入血液的速度较慢，作用持续时间更长，容易被误认为摄入量更高[4]。此外，冷酿酸度只有热咖啡的约三分之一，刺激性更小，导致人们更容易一次喝下更大分量，这也加深了“含量更多”的观感[1]。换言之，冰咖啡被视为“更浓”的主因并非单位浓度，而是杯量、配方及咖啡因释放方式共同造成的体感差异。

question_en: How are people able to sleepwalk safely? Why do people make the decisions they make when they sleepwalk?
pos_context_title_en: Sleepwalking - Causes, Symptoms, & Treatments - Sleep Foundation (www.sleepfoundation.org)
Why Do People Sleepwalk? Causes, Symptoms, Dangers, More (www.healthline.com)
5 Steps for Stopping a Sleepwalker (www.webmd.com)
pos_context_en: Sleepwalking, formally known as somnambulism, is a behavior disorder that originates during deep sleep and results in walking or performing other complex behaviors while still mostly asleep. It is more common in children than adults and is more likely to occur if a person has a family history of the condition, is sleep deprived, or is prone to repeated nighttime awakenings.

Sleepwalking is a sleeping disturbance that occurs in the deepest part of your nonrapid eye movement (NREM) sleep. It most often occurs within 1 to 2 hours of falling asleep.


During an episode of sleepwalking, you may sit up, walk around, and even perform ordinary activities — all while sleeping. Your eyes are open, but you’re actually still in a deep state of sleep.

Waking someone who is sleepwalking can be dangerous, but allowing a sleepwalker to roam about a room filled with sharp objects or to jump into the driver's seat of a vehicle is what's really hazardous.


The lesson: Stop sleepwalkers and get them back to bed. How? Gently turn them around and make sure they return to the bedroom safely. If they resist, stay with them and help them avoid perilous objects and situations. If you must awaken them, do so with loud noises rather than by shaking or touching them roughly.

人们为什么梦游？原因，症状，危险，更多（www.healthline.com）
停止梦游者的5个步骤（www.webmd.com）
pos_context_src: 梦游，正式称为somnambulism，是一种行为障碍，起源于深度睡眠，导致行走或执行其他复杂行为，同时仍大部分仍在睡觉。它在儿童中比成人更普遍，如果一个人有病情的家族史，被剥夺睡眠或容易重复夜间觉醒，则更有可能发生。

梦游是一种睡眠障碍，发生在非剥夺眼睛运动（NREM）睡眠的最深处。它通常发生在入睡后的1到2个小时内。


在梦游活动的一集中，您可能坐起来，四处走走，甚至在睡觉时进行普通活动。您的眼睛睁开，但实际上您仍处于深处的睡眠状态。

唤醒梦游的人可能很危险，但是让梦游者在一个装满锋利物体的房间里漫游或跳入车辆驾驶员座位是真正的危险。


课程：停止梦游者，让他们回到床上。如何？轻轻地转过身，确保他们安全返回卧室。如果他们抵抗，请与他们在一起，并帮助他们避免危险的物体和情况。如果您必须唤醒它们，请大声噪音，而不是大致摇动或触摸它们。
report_src: 梦游发生在最深的非快速动眼睡眠阶段，睡眠者的运动控制区被激活而意识仍沉睡，因此他们虽能睁眼起身、走动并执行日常动作，却并未进行真正有意识的决策；看似“决定”实际上是大脑在半醒状态下的自动程序[2]。要让梦游过程尽量安全，关键是防止受伤：首先保持环境无锋利或危险物，并阻止其接触车辆等高风险场所，因为让梦游者在危险区域徘徊比唤醒本身更具威胁[3]；其次轻声讲话或轻轻转身引导，将他们安全送回卧室，如有抵抗则陪伴在侧以避险[3]；若确需唤醒，应通过制造较大的声响而非剧烈摇晃或用力触碰，以减少惊吓和攻击性反应[3]。此外，充足睡眠、避免睡眠剥夺及夜间频繁醒来，可降低梦游发生的概率[1]。

report_src: 图帕克1996年遇害后，他留下的海量未发表录音被母亲阿芬尼·沙库尔创立的 Amaru Entertainment 与原东家 Death Row Records 共同控制，因此得以持续发行作品；截至目前，双方已将遗存素材整理成六张死后录音室专辑并售出数百万张[2]。版权结构的核心是：Amaru 代表沙库尔遗产掌握词曲与大部分母带，Death Row（后来多次易主）保有部分发行权，再按专辑项目分别授权给不同厂牌或制作人。为保持商业热度，专辑常由当时炙手可热的制作人“拼盘”完成：例如第五张专辑有 17 首歌，其中 13 首的配乐由阿姆与长期搭档 Luis Resto 重新制作[1]；《Pac Music》双 CD 又邀请 Johnny “J”、QDIII、L.T. Hutton 等老伙伴补完音轨[3]。正因为遗产公司采用开放授权、每张专辑都重新“编配”，才会出现看似“和上百万艺术家合作”的局面；实质上，词曲主体仍出自 2Pac 生前录音，而制作层面的多方参与只是为了让老素材符合当时市场声音，同时最大化版权收益。

question_en: Why does lying down reduce my urge to puke when I feel like puking?
pos_context_title_en: Nausea at Night: Causes, Treatment, Prevention (www.healthline.com)
What Could Be Causing Your Chronic Nausea? (www.verywellhealth.com)
pos_context_en: Prop your head up so you’re not lying flat in bed. If it’s comfortable for you, try to sleep with your head about 12 inches above your feet. This can help keep acid or food from moving up into your esophagus.

Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is a common condition that occurs when stomach contents come back up into the esophagus. This can cause symptoms of heartburn, regurgitation, and nausea.


Symptoms might be worse after eating or at night after lying down. The nausea may linger, especially if stomach acid backs up into the throat.
question_src: 为什么躺下会减少我喜欢呕吐的冲动？
pos_context_title_src: 晚上恶心：原因，治疗，预防（www.healthline.com）
是什么会导致您的慢性恶心？ （www.verywellhealth.com）
pos_context_src: 支撑您的头，这样您就不会平躺在床上。如果对您来说很舒服，请尝试用脚上约12英寸的头睡觉。这可以帮助防止酸或食物进入食道。

胃食管反流疾病（GERD）是一种常见的疾病，当胃含量恢复到食道时，会发生。这会导致胃灼热，反流和恶心的症状。


进食后或晚上躺下后的症状可能会更糟。恶心可能会流连忘返，尤其是当胃酸回到喉咙中时。
report_src: 恶心常由胃内容物或酸液返流刺激食道所致；将上半身垫高睡眠（如把床头抬高约12英寸）时，胃位置低于食道，重力可阻止食物和酸上冲，减少食道刺激，自然缓解呕吐冲动[1]。相反，吃完即完全平躺会削弱这种重力屏障，使胃酸更易逆流，慢性胃食管反流病患者因此在夜间常出现反复恶心[2]。因此，“躺下”若指保持半坐卧而非水平平躺，就能通过减轻反流来减少想吐的感觉。

question_en: Why do some people dream deeply and vividly while others rarely remember theirs?
pos_context_title_en: Why Some People Always Remember Their Dreams and Others Forget (www.healthline.com)
Why Some People Always Remember Their Dreams and Others Forget (www.healthline.com)
Do Frequent Dreams and the Ability to Recall Them Indicate Depression? - Guardian Liberty Voice (guardianlv.com)
pos_context_en:
Basically, this theory suggests that dreams occur when our brain is processing information, eliminating the unnecessary stuff and moving important short-term memories into our long-term memory. So people who recall dreams may have a difference in their ability to memorize things in general.


Beyond that, a person’s brain may actually block out a dream so we don’t remember it the following day. “The dream activity can be so real and intense that our brains actually hide, or mask away the dream, so [it doesn’t] get lost between our waking experience, and our dream lives. Thus it is normal to forget dreams, most of the time.” Dimitriu says.

A study published in the journal Neuropsychopharmacology and reported by International Business Times suggested that those people who reported high dream recall had more activity in the temporoparietal junction than those who didn’t recall their dreams often.


Lambert tells Healthline that if someone consistently doesn’t get enough sleep, the amount of REM sleep they experience will drop, making it harder for them to remember their dreams the following day.


Even personality traits can be an indicator of whether someone will be able to remember their dreams.


Lambert continues: “Researchers also looked at the most common personality traits that are presented in people who can recall their dreams. Overall, such people are prone to daydreaming, creative thinking, and introspection. At the same time, those who are more practical and focused on what is outside themselves tend to have difficulty remembering their dreams.”


This may mean that some people are naturally more likely to recall their dreams than others, despite their quality of sleep.


Other factors, like stress or experiencing a trauma, can also cause people to have vivid dreams or nightmares that they’re more likely to recall the next day. For example, a person who’s coping with grief after losing a loved one may dream about the death in elaborate detail. Remembering the dream the next day may affect mood and cause even more stress or anxiety.

People who have the ability to recall their dreams five mornings per week, on average, have more spontaneous activity occurring in certain parts of their brains than others. The parts of the brain that host these increased levels of activity are called the temporo-parietal junction, which is an information-processing hub, and the prefrontal cortex, which is responsible for the expression of personality as well as the planning of complex cognitive behaviors. And, interestingly, this escalation in liveliness is higher during both wakefulness and sleep, so says a study of 41 people recently published online February 19 in the journal Neuropsychopharmacology. The activity in the brains of the people in this study were measured by Positron Emission Tomography while they were awake and sleeping. What do these findings tell us?


In combination with previous research from one of the study’s authors, Perrine Ruby, the findings tell us why some people remember their dreams and some do not. Ruby co-authored related research that was published last year in the journal Cerebral Cortex, which showed that people who have the ability to regularly recall their dreams are also more reactive to sounds when they are both asleep and awake. Ruby made some comments in a recent statement that synthesized the findings for both of these studies. Ruby stated that the brain needs to awaken from sleep in order to memorize new information. This, said Ruby, may explain the reason that those who react more to environmental stimuli can remember their dreams better; they simply are awakened more often and can therefore better encode into memory their dreams than others who are less reactive to sounds. In addition, the researchers said that people who often recall their dreams may also have more dreams than “low-recall” dreamers.
question_src: 为什么有些人会深深而生动地梦想，而另一些人很少记住自己的梦想？
pos_context_title_src: 为什么有些人总是记住自己的梦想而其他人忘记了（www.healthline.com）
为什么有些人总是记住自己的梦想而其他人忘记了（www.healthline.com）
频繁的梦想和回忆能力表明抑郁症吗？ - 《卫报》自由声音（guardianlv.com）
pos_context_src:
基本上，该理论表明，当我们的大脑正在处理信息，消除不必要的东西并将重要的短期记忆转移到我们的长期记忆中时，就会发生梦想。因此，回想起梦的人可能在记住事物的能力上可能有所不同。


除此之外，一个人的大脑实际上可能会阻止梦想，因此我们不记得第二天。 “梦想活动可能是如此真实和强烈，以至于我们的大脑实际上掩盖了梦想，或者掩盖了梦想，因此[在我们醒来的经历和我们的梦想生活之间都不会迷失。因此，大多数时候忘记梦想是正常的。” Dimitriu说。

一项发表在《神经心理药理学》杂志上的研究并由国际商业时报报道说，与那些不经常召回梦想的人相比，那些报告高梦想召回的人在颞叶交界处的活动更多。


兰伯特（Lambert）告诉Healthline，如果某人一贯无​​法入睡，那么他们经历的REM睡眠量将会下降，这使他们很难记住第二天的梦想。


即使是个性特征，也可以表明某人是否能够记住自己的梦想。


兰伯特继续说：“研究人员还研究了可以回想起自己梦想的人们所呈现的最常见的人格特征。总的来说，这样的人容易发生白日梦，创造性的思维和自省。与此同时，那些更实用的人，更实用，专注于外界的事物倾向于难以记住自己的梦想。”


这可能意味着有些人自然而然地回想起自己的梦想，尽管睡眠质量。


其他因素，例如压力或经历创伤，也可能导致人们有​​生动的梦想或噩梦，使他们更有可能在第二天回想起。例如，一个失去亲人后应付悲伤的人可能会以精致的细节梦见死亡。记住第二天的梦想可能会影响情绪，并引起更多的压力或焦虑。

平均每周五个早晨回想起梦想的人比其他地区的某些部位发生的自发活动要比其他地区更多。主持这些增加的活性水平的大脑部分称为颞顶交界处，这是一个信息处理中心和前额叶皮层，这是负责人格表达以及复杂认知行为的计划。而且，有趣的是，在清醒和睡眠期间，这种活泼的升级都更高，因此对最近在网上在线发表的《神经心理药理学》杂志上在线发表的41人的研究说。这项研究中人们的大脑中的活动是通过正电子发射断层扫描在醒着和睡觉时测量的。这些发现告诉我们什么？


结合一位研究作者Perrine Ruby的先前研究，这些发现告诉我们为什么有些人会记住自己的梦想，而有些人则没有。 Ruby共同撰写了去年在《大脑皮层》杂志上发表的相关研究，该研究表明，有能力定期回想起梦想的人在睡着和清醒时对声音也更加充满活力。 Ruby在最近的一份声明中发表了一些评论，该声明综合了这两项研究的发现。 Ruby表示，大脑需要从睡眠中唤醒才能记住新信息。 Ruby说，这可能解释了那些对环境刺激更能反应的人可以更好地记住自己的梦想。与其他对声音反应较低的人相比，他们更频繁地唤醒他们，因此可以更好地编码自己的梦想。此外，研究人员说，经常回想起自己梦想的人可能比“低回忆”的梦想家拥有更多的梦想。
report_src: 人们在梦境深浅与记忆上的差异主要来自大脑活动、睡眠结构、性格与心理状态的综合作用：研究显示，高梦境回忆者在颞顶交界处与前额叶皮层的自发活动显著增强，这两个区域负责信息整合与复杂认知，使他们在睡眠与清醒时都更易捕获并保存梦中内容 [3]；相反，大脑为避免将强烈的梦与现实混淆，常主动“屏蔽”或抑制这些记忆，导致许多人醒来后难以想起梦境 [1]。足够的快速动眼期（REM）是储存梦记忆的前提，长期失眠或睡眠被打断会减少REM，使回忆梦境更困难 [2]。人格也起作用——喜欢白日梦、具创造性与自省特质的人更常记住梦，而务实、外向者则相反 [2]。此外，对外界刺激更敏感者夜间易短暂觉醒，这类短醒可“标记”并巩固梦记忆，解释了他们平均每周能在五个清晨回忆梦境的现象 [3]；而压力或创伤则可能令梦更生动，从而增加次日的记忆概率 [2]。

question_en: Explain: The security implications Microsoft's "golden key" backdoor, present in all copies of Windows since Windows 8.
pos_context_title_en: 1.4 UEFI... The Microsoft Kill Switch (www.learnlinuxandlibreoffice.org)
Microsoft Leaks Secure Boot Key, Raises Security Concerns (www.informationweek.com)
pos_context_en:
As if the insanity of handing the keys to our computers over to Microsoft was not bad enough, in June 2016, two computer security researchers discovered that Microsoft was doing some rather reckless things with these Golden Keys. Microsoft developers wanted to make changes to certain devices without going through the hassle of getting authorized keys to Secure Boot. So they developed a secret “super policy” for bypassing Secure Boot completely. Had this Golden Key “super policy” been discovered by hackers it would have given them unlimited access to nearly every computer in the world. The only good news to this story is that this backdoor nuclear weapon was discovered by “Good Guy” researchers before it was discovered by Bad Guy hackers. https://www.infoworld.com/article/3106079/security/secure-boot-proves-insecurity-of-backdoors.html


After the researchers notified Microsoft of the issue, the company released a security patch MS16-094 in July 2016. This “golden key” super policy is now blocked from loading on computers with the July patch installed. However, the July patch is not a complete fix -- it's at most a small roadblock. The issue remains only partially addressed, and what's worse, it is believed that it is impossible for Microsoft to fully revoke the leaked Golden Key Super policy.


[Image: 1.4.09]


Because of the implications of this Golden Key Backdoor being released to the wild, the two researchers wrote a letter to the FBI explaining why the entire concept of having super keys to all computers was a bad idea:


“Microsoft implemented a 'secure golden key' system. And the golden keys got released by Microsoft's own stupidity. Now, what happens if you tell everyone to make a 'secure golden key' system? This is a perfect real-world example about why your idea of backdooring cryptosystems with a 'golden key' is very bad!”


The first lesson we should learn from the 2016 Golden Key incident is that keys and secrets will eventually get leaked or stolen. The second lesson is that a fix is not always possible.

Microsoft is causing major cyber-security concerns with the accidental leak of a "golden key" intended to protect devices equipped with Secure Boot.


The Secure Boot feature is intended to protect Windows devices by making sure they only use software trusted by the PC maker or user. It's part of Microsoft's Unified Extensible Firmware Interface (UEFI) and ensures each component loaded during the boot process is validated.


The all-access keys were discovered by MY123 and Slipstream in March 2016. A recent blog post (animated site with tinny, arcade-style music) by researchers at MY123 and Slipstream dives into the details of Microsoft's security problems and the errors it made in addressing them.


[Google: QuadRooter threat is blocked on most Android devices.]


Note that the golden key isn't an actual key, but a means of changing the tasks launched by UEFI during the boot process, as explained in a report by Ars Technica. The policy has been made available online. It will enable anyone to disable the Secure Boot feature.


Secure Boot can be disabled on several types of desktop PCs, but is hard-coded into most devices running Windows. It seems the golden key is intended to turn off OS checks so programmers can test new projects. However, it can also leave Windows devices vulnerable.


The keys leaked by Microsoft will allow users with admin rights to install any operating system -- like Linux or Android -- on their Windows PCs, smartphones, or tablets.
question_src: 解释：Microsoft的“ Golden Key”后门的安全性含义，自Windows 8以来，Windows的所有副本中都存在。

Microsoft泄漏安全的引导键，提出安全问题（www.informationweek.com）
pos_context_src: 好像将钥匙交给微软的精神错乱还不够糟糕，2016年6月，两名计算机安全研究人员发现，微软正在用这些金键做一些相当鲁ck的事情。 Microsoft Developers希望对某些设备进行更改，而不会经历授权密钥保护启动的麻烦。因此，他们开发了一个秘密的“超级政策”，以完全绕过安全启动。如果黑客发现了这个黄金钥匙的“超级政策”，它将无限制地访问世界上几乎所有计算机。这个故事的唯一好消息是，这种后门核武器是由“好人”研究人员发现的，然后被Bad Guy Hackers发现。 https://www.infoworld.com/article/3106079/security/secure-boot-boot-proves-insecurity-backdoors.html在研究人员向Microsoft通知Microsoft之后，该公司向2016年7月的MS16-094发布了一个安全补丁的“金额安装”。但是，七月的补丁并不是一个完整的修复 - 最多是一个小障碍。这个问题仍然只是在部分解决，更糟糕的是，据信微软不可能完全撤销泄漏的金键超级政策。 [图片：1.4.09]由于这款金色钥匙后门被释放给野外的含义，两位研究人员写了一封信给联邦调查局的信，解释了为什么对所有计算机拥有超级钥匙的整个概念是一个坏主意：“ Microsoft实现了一个'安全的金键'系统。示例说明为什么您使用“黄金钥匙”的后台隐式系统的想法非常糟糕！”我们应该从2016年黄金钥匙事件中学到的第一堂课是，钥匙和秘密最终将被泄漏或被盗。第二个 教训是，修复并非总是可能的。

微软正在引起主要的网络安全问题，因为旨在保护配备安全靴的设备的“金钥匙”的意外泄漏。


安全启动功能旨在通过确保仅使用PC Maker或用户信任的软件来保护Windows设备。它是Microsoft统一的可扩展固件接口（UEFI）的一部分，并确保验证了启动过程中加载的每个组件。


My123和Slipstream于2016年3月发现了全访问密钥。最近的博客文章（具有Tinny，Tinny，Arcade风格的音乐的动画网站）是由MY123的研究人员在MY123上发现的，并向SlipStream潜水介绍了Microsoft的安全问题的详细信息及其在解决问题时所犯的错误。


[Google：大多数Android设备上的Quadrooter威胁被阻塞。]


请注意，金钥匙不是实际的钥匙，而是改变启动过程中UEFI启动的任务的一种手段，如ARS Technica的报告中所述。该政策已在线提供。它将使任何人都可以禁用安全启动功能。


可以在几种类型的台式PC上禁用安全启动，但是将其硬编码为运行Windows的大多数设备。似乎金钥匙旨在关闭操作系统检查，以便程序员可以测试新项目。但是，它也可能使Windows设备易受伤害。


Microsoft泄漏的密钥将允许具有管理员权利的用户在其Windows PC，智能手机或平板电脑上安装任何操作系统（例如Linux或Android）。
report_src: 微软在 UEFI Secure Boot 中预留的所谓“Golden Key”是一组可向固件注入“超级策略”的签名数据，原供开发者跳过密钥管理测试，却在 2016 年意外泄漏[1]。取得该密钥后，任何拥有管理员权限的攻击者都能在启动链最早阶段关闭 Secure Boot 校验或加载未签名映像，从而绕过操作系统与防毒软件的全部防护，安装并启动任意系统（如 Linux、Android），对 PC、手机或平板实现完全控制[2]。研究人员指出，这相当于给予黑客“对世界上几乎所有计算机的不受限制的访问权”，因为自 Windows 8 起 Secure Boot 已随每台预装 Windows 的设备强制启用[1]。微软虽在 2016 年 7 月发布 MS16-094 补丁，但只能增加障碍，无法吊销已泄漏的签名，后门事实上无法彻底修复[1]。事件表明，一旦为系统植入“万能钥匙”，泄漏几乎必然发生，且带来长期、全球性、不可逆的安全风险。

question_en: What keeps the oceans from flooding the earth?
pos_context_title_en: All About the Ocean (www.nationalgeographic.org)
Oceans. Formation of the Oceans. Facts about the Oceans (encyclopedia.lubopitko-bg.com)
The Water Cycle (oceantoday.noaa.gov)
pos_context_en:
After the Earth began to form about 4.6 billion years ago, it gradually separated into layers of lighter and heavier rock. The lighter rock rose and formed the Earth’s crust. The heavier rock sank and formed the Earth’s core and mantle.


The ocean’s water came from rocks inside the newly forming Earth. As the molten rocks cooled, they released water vapor and other gases. Eventually, the water vapor condensed and covered the crust with a primitive ocean. Today, hot gases from the Earth’s interior continue to produce new water at the bottom of the ocean.

The largest features of the Earth's surface are the continents and ocean basins. The four major ocean basins (Arctic, Atlantic, Indian, and Pacific) are bound by landmasses and major oceanic ridges. Each continent is rimmed by a submerged, gently sloping continental margin. This includes the relatively flat continental shelf, generally found at depths of less than 600 feet (183 meters) with a width of a few miles to more than 200 miles (322 kilometers). At the shelf break portion of the margin, there is a rise in the continental shelf before the continental slope begins its plunge to the deep-sea bottom. Deep submarine canyons frequently cut into the continental margin.

Over 96% of total global water is in the ocean, so let’s start there. Energy from the sun causes water on the surface to evaporate into water vapor – a gas. This invisible vapor rises into the atmosphere, where the air is colder, and condenses into clouds. Air currents move these clouds all around the earth.


Water drops form in clouds, and the drops then return to the ocean or land as precipitation - let’s say this time, it’s snow. The snow will fall to the ground, and eventually melts back into a liquid and runs off into a lake or river, which flows back into the ocean, where it starts the process again.
question_src: 是什么防止海洋淹没地球？
pos_context_title_src: 关于海洋的一切
海洋。海洋的形成。关于海洋的事实（百科全书.lubopitko-bg.com）
水循环（eachtoday.noaa.gov）
pos_context_src:
大约46亿年前，地球开始形成后，它逐渐分为更轻，更重的岩石。较轻的岩石升起，形成了地壳。较重的岩石沉没，形成了地球的核心和地幔。


海洋的水来自新形成的地球内的岩石。随着熔融岩石的冷却，它们释放出水蒸气和其他气体。最终，水蒸气冷凝并用原始海洋覆盖了外壳。如今，地球内部的热气继续在海底产生新的水。
地球表面最大的特征是大陆和海盆。四个主要的海盆（北极，大西洋，印度和太平洋）受陆地和主要海洋山脊的约束。每个大陆都被一个淹没的，轻轻倾斜的大陆边缘束缚。其中包括相对平坦的大陆架，通常在小于600英尺（183米）的深度上发现，宽度为几英里至200英里（322公里）。在边缘的架子断裂部分，在大陆斜率开始陷入深海底部之前，大陆架上升了。深层峡谷经常切入大陆边缘。

全球水总水中有96％以上，所以让我们从那里开始。来自太阳的能量会导致表面的水蒸发到水蒸气中 - 一种气体。这种无形的蒸气升入了空气更冷的大气中，并凝结成云。气流在地球上移动这些云。


水滴在云层中形成，然后滴水以降水返回海洋或陆地 - 假设这次是雪。雪将落在地面上，最终融化回到液体中，然后流入湖泊或河流，后者流回海洋，在那里再次开始该过程。
report_src: 海洋之所以没有淹没地球，根本原因在于地壳“轻重不均”造成的两级地形：较轻、厚而富含硅铝的大陆地壳因浮力效应上浮，形成高于海平面的大陆；较重、薄而富含铁镁的岩石下沉，形成深达数千米的海盆，专门“容纳”海水[1]。因此全球表面呈现出大陆与四大海盆（北冰洋、大西洋、印度洋、太平洋）相间分布的格局[2]。当水分通过蒸发–凝结–降水循环在海陆间迁移时，降到陆地上的水因地势高差最终沿河流回流入海盆[3]；即使地幔持续少量释放新水，也会优先充填海盆而非漫过大陆高地[1]。这种由差异密度塑造的“天然水槽”加上水循环的自动回流机制，共同防止了海洋漫过陆地，保持了今日约三成陆地、七成海洋的星球外貌。

question_en: Why are items always priced ending in ".99" instead of ".00"?
pos_context_title_en: The Real Reason Most Prices End in .99 (www.rd.com)
Why Do Most Prices End in .99? (www.livescience.com)
pos_context_en:
Prices are more likely to end in .99 more than any other pair of numbers—and certainly more than the even .00. We probably don’t think twice about buying something for $5.99 or $16.99, but it is a little strange when you think about it. Why aren’t prices just even dollar amounts? Is it an elaborate marketing scheme to get you to spend more?

Well, essentially…yes. But there’s really nothing “elaborate” about it; it’s actually pretty simple. “It’s a type of psychological pricing,” says Julie Ramhold, consumer analyst with DealNews.com. “Because we read from left to right, we pay less attention to the end of the number versus the beginning.” This is especially effective if you’re just quickly perusing several prices in a row; the first number will definitely stand out to you more. Psychological pricing is powerful, but luckily, there are also plenty of psychology tricks to help you spend less while shopping.

Of course, we still know that $9.99 is basically ten dollars, not nine dollars. But the $.99 trick takes advantage of the way our brains process prices. When we see a price of $9.99, we associate it as part of the $9–$9.99 “range” rather than the $10–$10.99 “range.” “Consumers don’t want to transcend a certain category, so even a penny less may make a huge psychological difference,” explains Subimal Chatterjee, Distinguished Teaching Professor of Marketing at Binghamton University School of Management.

Ending a price in .99 is based on the theory that, because we read from left to right, the first digit of the price resonates with us the most, Hibbett explained. That's why shoppers are more likely to buy a product for $4.99 than an identical one for $5 the item that starts with a 4 just seems like a better deal than the one that starts with 5.

"We also tend to attempt to reduce the amount of effort expended on making product decisions, especially with lower-cost items," Hibbett told Life's Little Mysteries. "So we may not really process the numbers after the dollar amount."

Additionally, the .99 alone serves to make an item appear to be on sale, according to the article "Mind Your Pricing Cues," published in the September 2003 issue of the Harvard Business Review. Price-conscious consumers have become conditioned to believe that they are getting a good deal when they buy something with a price ending in .99 even if the markdown is minimal.
question_src: 为什么总是以“ .99”而不是“ .00”结尾的项目？
pos_context_title_src: 大多数价格以.99结束的真正原因（www.rd.com）
为什么大多数价格以.99结束？ （www.livescience.com）
pos_context_src:
价格比其他任何一对数字更可能以0.99结尾，而且肯定比.00的价格还要多。我们可能不会三思而后行，以5.99美元或16.99美元的价格购买商品，但是当您考虑一下时，这有点奇怪。为什么价格甚至不花钱？这是一种精心制作的营销计划，可以让您花费更多吗？

好吧，本质上……是的。但是，实际上没有什么“详尽的”。实际上很简单。 DealNews.com的消费者分析师Julie Ramhold说：“这是一种心理定价。” “因为我们从左到右阅读，我们对数字结束与开始的末尾的关注更少。”如果您只是连续仔细阅读几个价格，这尤其有效；第一个数字肯定会给您更多。心理定价很强大，但幸运的是，也有很多心理学技巧可以帮助您在购物时花费更少的钱。

当然，我们仍然知道9.99美元基本上是十美元，而不是9美元。但是，$ 0.99的技巧利用了我们的大脑过程价格的方式。当我们看到$ 9.99的价格时，我们将其作为9.99美元的“范围”而不是$ 10- $ 10.99的“范围”将其关联。宾厄姆顿大学管理学院杰出教学教授Subimal Chatterjee解释说：“消费者不想超越某个类别，因此即使是一分钱也可能会产生巨大的心理差异。”

Hibbett解释说，以.99的价格结束价格是基于这样的理论：因为我们从左到右阅读，价格的第一个数字最吸引了我们。这就是为什么购物者更有可能以4.99美元的价格购买产品，而不是相同的价格为5美元，从4美元开始的商品似乎比以5票开始的产品更好。

希贝特对生活中的小谜团说：“我们还倾向于尝试减少制定产品决策所花费的努力，尤其是使用较低成本的项目。” “因此，我们可能不会真正处理美元金额后的数字。”

此外，根据2003年9月的《哈佛商业评论》上发表的文章“ Mind您的定价提示”，仅此.99即可使物品似乎正在销售。注重价格的消费者已经有条件相信，即使降价很少，他们的价格以0.99结尾，他们将获得很多交易。
report_src: 商家把价格设为“.99”而非“.00”是一种心理定价策略，利用人们对数字的直觉反应来提升购买率[1]。由于我们自左向右阅读，最先看到的数字最能吸引注意，4.99 美元给人的第一印象仍是“四元多”，因此比5.00 美元看上去便宜，消费者更可能下单[2]。同时，大脑倾向于把9.99归入9–9.99这一较低“类别”，而不是10–10.99的区间，即使只差一分钱也产生显著的心理落差[1]。购物者在快速决策时往往懒得深究小数点后的数字，从而进一步放大了这一差距[2]。此外，多数人已被训练成看到“.99”就联想到特价或打折，这种“正在促销”的暗示感也推高了成交概率[2]。

question_en: My mom just told me most stocks don't pay dividends. Is this the case? If so why does the stock market even exist, did we all just agree to make a gambling arena where we bet on others betting on what we bet on? And if so why does how well the company does matter to stockholders?
pos_context_title_en: How and When Are Stock Dividends Paid Out? (www.investopedia.com)
Do All Stocks Have Dividends? (Why Don’t Some Stocks Pay Dividends?) (therobusttrader.com)
Is Investing in Stocks Just a Form of Gambling? (realmoney.thestreet.com)
Is Investing in Stocks Just a Form of Gambling? (realmoney.thestreet.com)
Going All-In: Investing vs. Gambling (www.investopedia.com)
pos_context_en: A dividend is the distribution of some of a company's earnings to a class of its shareholders. Dividends are usually paid in the form of a dividend check. However, they may also be paid in additional shares of stock. The standard practice for the payment of dividends is a check that is mailed to stockholders a few days after the ex-dividend date, which is the date on which the stock starts trading without the previously declared dividend.

All stocks do not pay a dividend. Profitable companies’ managers have the option of either compensating shareholders directly (through a dividend), or investing back into the company to fuel growth and increase the value of the company. Because of this, investors have the option to either go for dividend-paying stocks or stocks which emphasize growth over shareholder compensation.

Gambling, trading, speculation, and investment are perceived in very different ways but they have two core similarities. First, they all involve risking money in hopes of a positive return. Second, the results are dependent in part on luck.

A number of distinctions between the various endeavors are usually drawn. Gambling is typically viewed as a form of entertainment that carries a higher level of risk and has a less certain outcome. Speculation and investment are generally viewed as business enterprises in which risk is understood and steps are taking to mitigate and manage it.

True, investing and gambling both involve risk and choice—specifically, the risk of capital with hopes of future profit. But gambling is typically a short-lived activity, while equities investing can last a lifetime. Also, there is a negative expected return to gamblers, on average and over the long run. On the other hand, investing in the stock market typically carries with it a positive expected return on average over the long run.
question_src: 我妈妈刚刚告诉我，大多数股票都不付钱。是这样吗？如果是这样，为什么股票市场甚至存在，我们都同意做一个赌博领域，我们押注其他人押注我们的赌注？如果是这样，为什么公司对股东有多重要？
pos_context_title_src: 股票股利是如何以及何时支付的？ （www.investopedia.com）
所有股票都有股息吗？ （为什么有些股票不支付股息？）（therobusttrader.com）
投资股票只是一种赌博形式吗？ （realmoney.thestreet.com）
投资股票只是一种赌博形式吗？ （realmoney.thestreet.com）
全力以赴：投资与赌博（www.investopedia.com）
pos_context_src: 股息是将公司的某些收益分配给其股东的类别。股息通常以股息支票的形式支付。但是，它们也可以以额外的股票支付。支付股息的标准惯例是一张支票，该支票是在出行日期后几天邮寄给股东的，这是股票开始交易的日期，而没有先前宣布的股息。
所有股票都不支付股息。有利可图的公司的经理可以选择直接（通过股息）补偿股东，或者投资回到公司以促进增长并增加公司的价值。因此，投资者可以选择购买股息股票或强调股东薪酬增长的股票。
赌博，贸易，投机和投资的方式非常不同，但它们具有两个核心相似之处。首先，它们都涉及冒险，希望获得积极的回报。其次，结果部分取决于运气。
通常会绘制各种努力之间的许多区别。赌博通常被视为一种娱乐形式，它具有更高的风险水平，并且结果较少。人们通常将投机和投资视为了解风险的商业企业，并采取了缓解和管理它的步骤。
的确，投资和赌博都涉及风险和选择 - 特别是，资本风险带有未来利润的希望。但是赌博通常是一项短暂的活动，而股票投资可以持续一生。同样，从长远来看，赌徒的预期回报率有负。另一方面，从长远来看，投资股票市场的平均预期收益率很高。
report_src: 你妈妈的说法有一定事实依据：不少上市公司选择不发放股息，因为管理层认为把利润再投入业务、推动增长与公司价值提升，比立即分红更能回报股东[2]。即便没有股息，投资者仍可通过公司盈利扩张带来的股价上涨获利，因此股票市场并非纯粹“押注别人押注”——它让企业获得长期资本，投资人获得分享企业成果与资产增值的权利。赌博和投资都冒风险，但赌场游戏从长期看预期回报为负，而股票市场历史平均预期收益率则为正[5]；投资者还能通过研究、分散化等方式识别并管理风险[4]。公司之所以重视股东，是因为股东提供的资金支持研发、扩产及并购；作为所有者，股东可凭投票权影响董事会、在公司分红或清算时分配剩余资产，这套产权与治理机制正是现代经济持续扩张的基础。

question_en: How does Snap Chat work? I'm not getting the information I'm curious about in previous posts.
pos_context_title_en: Is Snapchat Privacy-Friendly? [Analysis] - Choose To Encrypt (choosetoencrypt.com)
Is Snapchat Privacy-Friendly? [Analysis] - Choose To Encrypt (choosetoencrypt.com)
Is Snapchat Privacy-Friendly? [Analysis] - Choose To Encrypt (choosetoencrypt.com)
How To Fix ‘Random People Adding Me On Snapchat’ Problem (nerdschalk.com)
pos_context_en: Snapchat uses end-to-end encryption on photos shared between its users. Text messages and other messages sent on Snapchat aren’t protected by the same encryption. Snapchat doesn’t disclose much information about the type of encryption that it uses, so it can be difficult to truly understand what happens to your messages once they get to Snap’s servers.

Don’t Let People Find You with Your Mobile Number: Snapchat settings allow you to toggle whether or not other users can find your Snapchat account using your mobile number. If you are concerned about privacy, you should turn this feature off. If you use your personal cell phone number for work purposes, or have your phone number published anywhere online, turning this off can protect you from an unwanted flood of unknown people adding you as a friend.

The truth is, however, that whenever a user opens the Snapchat app, their location is shared on the Snap Map. Verge reporter Dani Deahl explained that she was able to pinpoint one of her friend’s locations down to the exact street address. Since the address was in a residential area, she determined that was where her friend lived.


Snapchat users may assume that sharing their location is harmless, but it could allow for someone to find you or track your frequent locations. In Snapchat’s settings you can select which friends you share your location with, if any at all.

When you create an account on Snapchat, you give Snapchat the permission to display your profile to users that look you up. In this case, if a user knows your Snapchat ID, they can search for you and then add you from the search results.


If you have added your phone number on the app, you may show up on the accounts of people who have your number saved on their phones under ‘People you may know’. This is because Snapchat lets you sync your phone contacts to help you add your friends easily.


Users can also scan your Snapcode to be redirected to your Snapchat profile. If you posted your Snapcode in a public forum, anyone could scan it and add you using that code.


Related: What Happens When You Block Someone On TikTok?


## Who are the random people on my Snapchat?


Recently, a number of users have complained about getting an influx of ‘Adds’ on Snapchat. While this should not raise any red flags if it was organic growth, the users adding have no mutual friends. So the question arises, where did they get your profile info from?


Well, it seems a number of users have resorted to using bots to gain followers on the app. These bot accounts add you and wait for you to add them back. Once you do, they remove you as a friend. This allows users to reach a larger audience.


So if you are wondering why you have a bunch of strangers trying to add you on Snapchat, they could just be bot accounts.

好吧，似乎许多用户都求助于使用机器人在应用程序上获得关注者。这些机器人帐户添加了您，并等待您添加它们。一旦您这样做，他们就将您删除为朋友。这使用户可以吸引更多的受众。

question_en: the US presidential electoral system. I do not get it.
pos_context_title_en: Presidential Election Process | USAGov (www.usa.gov)
How the US Electoral College System Works (www.thoughtco.com)
How the US Electoral College System Works (www.thoughtco.com)
How the US Electoral College System Works (www.thoughtco.com)
pos_context_en:
After you cast your ballot for president, your vote goes to a statewide tally. In 48 states and Washington, D.C., the winner gets all the electoral votes for that state. Maine and Nebraska assign their electors using a proportional system.


A candidate needs the vote of at least 270 electors—more than half of all electors—to win the presidential election.


In most cases, a projected winner is announced on election night in November after you vote. But the actual Electoral College vote takes place in mid-December when the electors meet in their states. See the Electoral College timeline of events for the 2020 election.


While the Constitution doesn’t require electors to vote for the candidate chosen by their state's popular vote, some states do. The rare elector who votes for someone else may be fined, disqualified and replaced by a substitute elector, or potentially even prosecuted.
The Founding Fathers created the Electoral College system as a compromise between having the president elected by Congress and having the president elected by the popular vote of qualified citizens.

When you vote for a presidential candidate, you are in fact voting to instruct the electors from your state to cast their votes for the same candidate.


For example, if you vote for the Republican candidate in the November election, you are really just picking an elector who will be pledged to vote for the Republican candidate when the Electoral College votes in December. The candidate who wins the popular vote in a state wins all the pledged votes of the state's electors in the 48 winner-take-all states and District of Columbia.﻿﻿ Nebraska and Maine award electors proportionally.

Each state gets a number of electors equal to its number of members in the U.S. House of Representatives plus one for each of its two U.S. senators. The District of Columbia gets three electors.﻿﻿ State laws determine how electors are chosen, but they are generally selected by the political party committees within the states.


Each elector gets one vote. Thus, a state with eight electors would cast eight votes. As of the 1964 election, there are 538 electors, and the votes of a majority of them—270—are required to be elected.﻿﻿ Because Electoral College representation is based on congressional representation, states with larger populations get more Electoral College votes.

开国元勋们创建了选举学院制度，这是由国会选出的总统和由合格公民的普选选举的总统之间的妥协。

当您投票选出总统候选人时，实际上，您会投票通过您州的选民投票给同一候选人。

每个州的选民在美国众议院的成员人数等于其两位美国参议员的成员人数。哥伦比亚特区获得了三名选民。州法律决定了选举人的选择方式，但通常由各州的政党委员会选择。


每个选举人都有一票。因此，一个拥有八名选民的州将投票八票。截至1964年大选，有538名选举人，其中大多数人（270）的选票必须当选。由于选举学院的代表是基于国会代表，因此人口较大的州获得了更多的选举学院投票。

question_en: if and how a greater volume of almonds could have significantly less calories with cinnamon and sugar added (nutrition facts photo in text)
pos_context_title_en: New Study Reveals Fewer Calories in Almonds | Food Network Healthy Eats: Recipes, Ideas, and Food News | Food Network (www.foodnetwork.com)
New Study Reveals Fewer Calories in Almonds | Food Network Healthy Eats: Recipes, Ideas, and Food News | Food Network (www.foodnetwork.com)

pos_context_en:
A new study published in the American Journal of Clinical Nutrition found that almonds have 20% fewer calories than originally thought. The results found that a one-ounce serving of almonds (about 23 nuts) has 129 calories as opposed to 160 that’s currently listed on the Nutrition Facts Panel.


Interestingly, it has nothing to do with the composition of the almond—rather, the way we metabolize it.

several studies published over the past 10 years have suggested that when people eat almonds, not all of the fat is digested and absorbed. Some of the fat remains intact within the almonds’ rigid cell walls. Recognizing that this could affect the number of calories actually available from almonds, researchers at USDA's Agricultural Research Service decided to specifically determine the calories absorbed. We were not at all surprised to learn from Dr. Baer’s work that fewer calories from almonds are available for absorption. However, we were pleasantly surprised by the magnitude of the difference. In 2011, Dr. Baer conducted research using the same methodology to find out available calories from pistachios and found that the number was only 5% lower than previously thought, while the number for almonds was 20% lower.

Why the change in almonds and cashews? The difference in the calorie counts is because research found your body doesn’t actually break down and use all of the calories that are in nuts, explains Alissa Rumsey, RD, nutrition therapist and owner of Alissa Rumsey Nutrition and Wellness. “This concept is called bioavailability,” she says. “Basically, just because nutrients are present in a food, that doesn’t automatically mean that the body will readily use them. Therefore fewer calories may actually be absorbed.”

The resulting data from this new study showed that, with the exception of almond butter, all of the almond forms analyzed provide fewer calories than is listed on packages:


[Image: almond nutrients]


Wondering why the discrepancy in calories? Mechanical processes, such as roasting, chopping and grinding play a role because they disrupt the cell wall of almonds and affect particle size. Particle size is also affected when almonds are chewed and digested in the body. The larger the particle size, the less the almond is broken down by digestive enzymes and the more of the almond is excreted, so fewer calories are absorbed. The reverse is also true: the smaller the particle size, the more calories are absorbed. Further research is needed to better understand the results of this study and how this method of measuring calories could potentially affect the calorie count of other foods.

pos_context_src:
发表在《美国临床营养杂志》上的一项新研究发现，杏仁的卡路里比最初想象的要少20％。结果发现，一盎司的杏仁（约23个坚果）具有129卡路里的热量，而目前在营养事实面板上列出了160卡路里。


有趣的是，这与杏仁的构成无关，这是我们代谢它的方式。

在过去的十年中，发表的几项研究表明，当人们吃杏仁时，并非所有脂肪都被消化和吸收。一些脂肪在杏仁的刚性细胞壁内保持完整。美国农业部农业研究服务公司的研究人员认识到这可能会影响杏仁实际可获得的卡路里数量，因此决定专门确定吸收的卡路里。从贝尔博士的工作中得知，从杏仁中吸收的卡路里更少，我们一点也不感到惊讶。但是，我们对差异的幅度感到惊喜。 2011年，Baer博士使用相同的方法进行了研究，以从开心果中找出可用的卡路里，发现该数字仅比以前想象的低5％，而杏仁的数量低20％。
为什么要改变杏仁和腰果？卡路里计数的差异是因为研究发现您的身体实际上并没有崩溃，并使用了坚果中的所有卡路里。她说：“这个概念称为生物利用度。” “基本上，仅仅因为食物中存在营养，这并不意味着身体很容易使用它们。因此，实际上可能会吸收较少的卡路里。”

这项新研究的结果数据表明，除了杏仁黄油外，所有分析的杏仁形式的卡路里比包装上列出的卡路里更少：


[图像：杏仁营养素]


想知道为什么卡路里差异？机械过程（例如烘烤，切碎和研磨）起着作用，因为它们破坏了杏仁的细胞壁并影响粒径。当杏仁被咀嚼并在体内消化时，粒径也会受到影响。粒径越大，杏仁被消化酶分解的越少，并且杏仁的排泄量越多，因此吸收的卡路里越少。相反的情况也是如此：粒径越小，吸收的卡路里就越多。需要进一步的研究以更好地了解这项研究的结果，以及这种测量卡路里的方法如何可能影响其他食物的卡路里人数。
report_src: 现有研究表明，杏仁实际可被人体吸收的热量约比营养标签低20%，原因是部分脂肪被锁在坚硬的细胞壁内而随排泄物排出[1]；若将杏仁烘烤、切碎或研磨，会破坏细胞壁、减小粒径，使可吸收热量反而增加[4]。添加肉桂只会带来极少量近乎可忽略的热量，本身并不影响杏仁细胞壁的完整性，也不限制脂肪吸收；而糖每克约提供4千卡，任何撒糖或用加糖肉桂粉调味都会额外增加碳水化合物热量，无法“抵消”或“减少”杏仁自身的热量。现有文献并未发现“肉桂＋糖”能进一步降低杏仁可吸收热量的证据，若要保持较低热量，应避免细碎加工并控制或省去含糖调味，而非依赖肉桂或糖本身。

question_en: As a person with astigmatism, why is it when I squint my eyes a little I can see a little clearer?
pos_context_title_en: Why Can I See Better When I Squint My Eyes? - Grosinger, Spigelman & Grey (www.eyemichigan.com)
Why Do I See Better When I Squint? (www.invision2020.com)
Vision Hack: How to See Clearly Without Your Glasses or Contacts (vision-and-hearing.wonderhowto.com)
Cornell Center for Materials Research (www.ccmr.cornell.edu)
pos_context_en:
What Does Squinting Do to Your Eye?


Even though it doesn’t feel much different, squinting does three things to our eyes that lead to slightly clearer vision.


* Our Eye Lens Changes Shape – The lens of the eye is flexible and changes shape when we squint.
* The Eye Lens Adjusts – Small adjustments in the lens allow us to focus better, much like a camera.
* Less Light Enters the Eye – Less light enters, reducing the impact on the retina and allowing the object we view to look sharper.

A small amount of the increased clarity of vision is due to changing the shape of the eye as you squint. However, the main optical principle at work, and one that is quite fascinating, is called the “pinhole effect”. Clear vision is a result of light rays that properly focused on the retina located in the back of the eye. Typically, this is done with glasses or contact lenses; both of which bend light into focus and therefore correct vision.


When we squint it creates the same effect as looking through a pinhole. Basically only a small amount of focused central light rays are allowed into the eye. This prevents the unfocused light rays in the periphery from reaching the retina. The result is better vision. Photographers understand this as “depth of field”.

The reason that squinting helps you see is because it changes the shape of your eye, making the pupil smaller, thus letting less light in and making an image clear. This is similar to the way a larger aperture works; a smaller hole in your camera lets less light in, with better focus.

By limiting the rays of light that come in through the bottom and top of the pupil, squinting allows rays to pass closer to the center of the lens, thereby creating a more focused image. So, that means that squinting works by two mechanisms – by both changing the shape of the eye and by letting in light that can be focused more precisely by the lens.

康奈尔材料研究中心（www.ccmr.cornell.edu）
pos_context_src:
斜视对您的眼睛有什么作用？


即使感觉并没有太大的不同，斜视对我们的眼睛做了三件事，这会导致视力稍微清晰。


*我们的眼镜会改变形状 - 眼睛的镜头是柔韧性的，当我们斜视时会改变形状。
*眼镜调整 - 镜头的小调整使我们能够更好地聚焦，就像相机一样。
*较少的光线进入眼睛 - 较少的光线进入，减少对视网膜的影响，并允许我们看到的物体看起来更清晰。

少量的视力清晰度增加是由于斜视时会改变眼睛的形状。但是，工作中的主要光学原理和非常有趣的光学原理称为“针孔效应”。清晰的视力是光线射线的结果，该光线适当地集中在眼睛背面的视网膜上。通常，这是用眼镜或隐形眼镜完成的；两者都将光线弯曲为焦点，因此正确视力。


当我们斜视时，它会产生与透过针孔相同的效果。基本上，只允许少量聚焦的中央光线进入眼睛。这样可以防止外围未关注的光线到达视网膜。结果是更好的视野。摄影师将其理解为“景深”。
斜视帮助您看到的原因是因为它改变了眼睛的形状，使瞳孔变小，从而减少了光线并使图像清晰。这类似于较大的光圈的工作方式。相机中的一个较小的孔可以减少点亮，以更好的焦点。
通过限制穿过学生底部和顶部的光线，斜视使射线可以靠近镜头的中心，从而创造出更加集中的图像。因此，这意味着斜视通过两种机制起作用 - 既通过改变眼睛的形状，也可以通过镜头更精确地将其聚焦在光线下。
report_src: 散光时角膜弯曲不均，光线无法在视网膜形成单一点成像而出现重影和模糊。眯眼会收窄眼裂、缩小瞳孔，只让靠近光轴的少量中央光线进入，相当于在眼前加了“针孔”，屏蔽了原本偏离焦点的周边光线，于是视野变得锐利，这就是针孔效应[2]。同时，眼睑压力与眼肌紧张使晶状体曲率略增，相当于微调镜头焦距，使光线更好地汇聚于视网膜[1]。两种机制叠加，可让散光者暂时看得更清晰，但并不能替代专业验光与矫正。

pos_context_en:
> The Swiss heroin prescription program was targeted at hard-core drug users with very well established heroin habits. These people were heavily engaged in both drug dealing and other forms of crime.


> They also served as a link between importers, few of whom were Swiss, and the — primarily Swiss — users. As these hard-core users found a steady, legal means for addressing their addiction, they reduced their illicit drug use. This reduced their need to deal in heroin and engage in other criminal activities. Thus, the program had three effects on the drug market:


>   * It substantially reduced the consumption among the heaviest users, and this reduction in demand affected the viability of the market.
>   * By removing local addicts and dealers, Swiss casual users found it difficult to make contact with sellers.

Advocates of drug legalization believe that making high-quality drugs cheaply and widely available will eliminate the illegal drug market, regulate quality and price, and decrease law enforcement costs including arrest and incarceration. They predict that governments will spend less money on law enforcement, benefit from a new source of tax revenue and that drug-related crime will fall if drugs from marijuana to heroin become routinely accessible, more or less as are alcohol and tobacco.

question_en: Do meteors (or other space debris) damage or cause risk to the atmospheric layers and such? If so, how dangerous is it to us? If not, why doesn't it?

In Earth's Atmosphere, Meteors May Explode from the Inside Out (www.space.com)
In Earth's Atmosphere, Meteors May Explode from the Inside Out (www.space.com)
pos_context_en: It may seem like meteors crashing to Earth are rare, but more than 48 tons of debris falls into Earth's atmosphere every single day. Most of this comes in the form of dust and micrometeorites that burn up instantly, but on rare occasions, larger rocks may fall into the planet's gravity well. Depending on the size of the object, an impact can cause a number of different effects, and a large enough asteroid could drastically change life on Earth.

A massive asteroid impact would create long-term changes in the atmosphere and climate of the planet. Upon impact, vaporized dirt and rock would fill the atmosphere, blocking sunlight and creating a state of near-permanent darkness and winter-like conditions. After the particles in the atmosphere settle, an increase in greenhouse gases from impact fires and released stores in the crater area could actually increase temperatures substantially due to an increased greenhouse effect. The severity and length of each of these phases would depend on the size of the impact, with a one or two kilometer-wide asteroid causing enough damage to trigger worldwide disturbances for years.

Another dangerous effect of an asteroid strike would be damage to the ozone layer. The energy imparted to the atmosphere by the incoming object would be enough to disrupt the protective layer of ozone high in the stratosphere, drastically increasing the amount of ultraviolet light that made it to the surface. This would increase global cancer rates, affect the growth of plants and animals and possibly lead to genetic mutations over the period of increased exposure. Depending on the size of the asteroid, this could last for as much as two years.

Earth's atmosphere may infiltrate the interior of porous meteors as they hurtle toward the planet, creating pockets of high-pressure air inside the rocky space debris. These pockets can then cause the space rocks to explode, breaking into smaller pieces.

When meteors enter the planet's atmosphere, they heat up, and ultimately disintegrate. (This is either because of something -called ram pressure or friction.). However, the new research highlights a new way in which the atmosphere may break up meteors and protect Earth, the researchers said.

pos_context_src: 坠落到地球的流星似乎很少见，但是每天有48吨以上的碎屑落入地球大气中。其中大多数以灰尘和微型通灵物的形式立即燃烧，但是在极少数情况下，较大的岩石可能会很好地落入地球的重力中。根据物体的大小，影响会导致许多不同的影响，而足够大的小行星可以大大改变地球上的生命。
巨大的小行星影响会在地球的大气和气候上长期变化。在撞击后，蒸发的污垢和岩石将充满大气，遮挡阳光，形成近乎永久的黑暗和类似冬季的状态。在大气中的颗粒沉降之后，由于温室效应的增加，撞击火灾和释放的商店的温室气体增加实际上可能会大大增加温度。这些阶段中每个阶段的严重程度和长度将取决于冲击的大小，一到两公里范围内的小行星造成足够的损害，以触发多年来的全球干扰。
小行星罢工的另一个危险效果是对臭氧层的损害。传入物体赋予大气的能量足以破坏平流层中高臭氧的保护层，从而大大增加了使其表面的紫外线的量。这将提高全球癌症率，影响动植物的生长，并可能导致暴露期间的基因突变。根据小行星的大小，这可以持续两年。
当地球的大气层朝着地球往时，它们可能会渗透到多孔流星的内部，从而在岩石空间碎片内形成大量的高压空气。然后，这些口袋会导致空间岩石爆炸，分成较小的碎片。
当流星进入地球的气氛时，它们会加热并最终瓦解。 （这要么是因为被称为某些内容的RAM压力或摩擦。）。但是，这项新的研究突出了一种新的方式，使大气可以破坏流星并保护地球。
report_src: 每天约有48吨太空碎屑坠入大气，其中绝大多数在高空就以尘埃或微小流星体的形式烧毁，对大气和地表几乎无害[1]。当较小流星进入大气时，高温和动压常使其瓦解，甚至因空气渗入多孔内部而“从内而外”爆炸成碎片，进一步降低落地危害[4]。然而若撞击体直径达到约1–2公里，就足以抛射大量蒸发尘土遮蔽阳光，在全球范围内引发多年“撞击冬天”并扰乱气候[2]。待尘埃沉降，大量温室气体与撞击火灾产生的气溶胶又会导致显著增温，形成长期气候变暖[2]。此外，撞击输入的巨大能量能破坏平流层臭氧层，使地表紫外线强度大增，持续约两年，危及人类健康与生态[3]。因此，日常流星对大气几乎无风险，但极少数大型小行星若撞击则可能带来灾难性全球环境变化。

question_en: if someone on my WiFi is using a VPN, does this mean I am also using a VPN?
pos_context_title_en: How to install a VPN on your router (nordvpn.com)
Do I need a VPN at home? (us.norton.com)
pos_context_en:
A VPN creates an encrypted and secure connection between the device it’s installed on and the internet. It gathers all of that device’s requests to access the internet and directs them through its encrypted tunnel and VPN server so they can’t be read or redirected.


That’s easy to understand when you’re on a device with a user interface. Want to visit a website? You go through the tunnel. Want to video call your BFF? Through the tunnel. But what happens on a device with no user interface, like a router?


Once you’ve set up a router VPN, every single device connected to your router will have its traffic sent through the encrypted tunnel.

If you’re using a VPN, your computer or mobile device will first connect to this outside VPN server before it connects to the web. A VPN also encrypts the data you send and receive while searching online.


This combination — your connection to the outside VPN server and the encryption of your data — helps keep your browsing private. The only people who will know what sites you visit or links you click are you, your VPN provider, and the people or companies running the sites you visit.

我在家需要VPN吗？ （us.norton.com）
pos_context_src:
VPN在安装在Internet上的设备和Internet之间建立了加密而安全的连接。它收集了所有该设备访问Internet的请求，并通过其加密隧道和VPN服务器引导它们，因此无法读取或重定向。


当您使用用户界面的设备上时，这很容易理解。想访问网站吗？你穿过隧道。想视频打电话给您的BFF吗？穿过隧道。但是，在没有用户界面（例如路由器）的设备上会发生什么？


设置了路由器VPN后，连接到路由器的每个设备都将通过加密的隧道发送其流量。

如果您使用的是VPN，则您的计算机或移动设备将首先连接到此外部VPN服务器，然后再连接到Web。 VPN还可以在线搜索时对您发送和接收的数据进行加密。


这种组合 - 您与外部VPN服务器的连接以及数据的加密 - 有助于保持您的浏览。唯一会知道您访问的网站或您点击的链接的人是您，您的VPN提供商以及运行您访问的网站的人员或公司。
report_src: 当同一 Wi-Fi中的某个人仅在自己的电脑或手机上安装并开启VPN时，隧道只存在于“该设备↔外部VPN服务器”之间，其流量被加密重定向，而您的设备仍按原路径直接访问互联网，因此您并未使用VPN [2]；只有当VPN被配置在路由器层级时，路由器会把所有连入的设备（包括您的）产生的流量一并导入加密隧道，这时整张局域网才共同处于VPN之下 [1]。

真主（; [1] [2]阿拉伯语：اللا，罗马化：allāh，ipa：[[ʔaɫ.ɫaːh]（[图像：关于此声音]听）是对上帝的普遍阿拉伯语。
