制图师是如何在现代之前将海岸绘制的？ （utdoors.stackexchange.com）
制图师是如何在现代之前将海岸绘制的？ （utdoors.stackexchange.com）
非常准确的中世纪地图的奥秘（www.discovermagazine.com）
pos_context_src:
“驾驶”。通过驾驶，您将使用准确地图上参考点的轴承确定位置。在这里，我们使用轴承对物体来确定沿海岸线的点位置。尽管如此，它的工作方式几乎相同。


地图 - 尤其是海岸线 - 几乎可以肯定是由从船上拍摄的观察结果制成的。海军导航比在土地上的导航（尤其是没有好的地图！）要准确得多。

在1700年代中期之前，导航的主要手段是死亡的（DR）。这要求您使用方向和距离从最后一个已知的位置迭代地将您在地图上的位置提高。当然，随着时间的流逝，错误会增加准确性的降低。您必须有一种方法来衡量旅行方向和速度（某些）准确的价值。


在1700年代的晚些时候，可以使用天体导航更准确地导航。这使熟练的导航器可以在全球任何时候都相当准确地确定其位置（通常在几英里之内）。该位置通常每天每天一次找到一次，并根据需要使用DR提前。

导航和制图的主题是同一枚硬币的两个方面，每本书都写了整本书。研究制图的历史很有趣，因为它非常图形地显示了随着时间的推移导航的相应改进。


为了制作准确的地图，您需要首先知道从哪里进行观察。从先前已知的位置进行观察将导致更高的准确性。该立场可能是由较早的调查（例如，从现有地图上的已知点工作）建立的，或者能够在地球范围内良好地确定自己的位置。

问题是波托兰地图制造商缺乏将球形地球减少到平坦地图的系统方式。对于短途旅行而言，这并没有什么后果，但是在航行更长的距离时，它的影响力更多。 1569年，比利时的地理学家和制图师Gerardus Mercator创建了他的方法，是在平坦地图上展示球形世界的方法，这是当今我们所熟悉的。这种地图制作技术虽然拉伸和压缩的地标及其之间的距离，但具有很大的优势，即直线指南针的路线由地图上的一条直线表示。


Mercator的预测开始在1800年代初开始航行开放海洋，到那时波尔托兰的排行榜几乎消失了。但是它们的重要性是不可否认的。赫斯勒说：“这些地图的发展彻底改变了人们对空间的看法，就像Google Earth在我们一生中所做的那样。” “了解如何开发技术使我们深入了解我们如何到达这里，也许可以进入要去的地方。”
report_src: 在没有卫星的时代，制图师首先必须知道自己的位置，因为“导航和制图是同一枚硬币的两个方面”[3]；中世纪航海者沿海进行运行测量：在船上不断对岸上显著地物测定罗盘方位，将相交方位线绘于纸上以描绘海岸线，这种方法被称为“driving”[1]。1700 年代中期以前船位主要靠推算定位，通过记录航向与估算航速逐段累加距离，但误差会随时间放大[2]；18 世纪晚期天文导航普及，熟练的航海者每天一两次利用太阳或恒星即可把船位确定到数英里之内，再以推算法插补[2]。依托这种较精确的海上定位，波托兰海图描绘出细致的欧洲及地中海海岸，尽管缺乏统一投影[4]；1569 年麦卡托投影将罗盘直航表现为地图直线，19 世纪初成为远洋测绘与导航标准[4]。借助测方位、量距离、天文定位与改进投影，制图师在卫星出现前已能相当准确地绘制出大陆、国家及其海岸线。

question_en: Why is wearing a swastika considered taboo but every biker I see wears an iron cross on his shirt, jacket, skin or motorcycle?
pos_context_title_en: Swastika (en.wikipedia.org)
History of the Swastika (encyclopedia.ushmm.org)
Iron Cross (www.adl.org)
Iron Cross (www.adl.org)
pos_context_en: In the Western world, it was a symbol of auspiciousness and good luck until the 1930s[4] when the right-facing tilted form became a feature of Nazi symbolism as an emblem of the Aryan race. As a result of World War II and the Holocaust, many people in the West still strongly associate it with Nazism and antisemitism.

The Nazi Party was not the only party to use the swastika in Germany. After World War I, a number of far-right nationalist movements adopted the swastika. As a symbol, it became associated with the idea of a racially “pure” state. By the time the Nazis gained control of Germany, the connotations of the swastika had forever changed.

The Iron Cross is a famous German military medal dating back to the 19th century. During the 1930s, the Nazi regime in Germany superimposed a swastika on the traditional medal, turning it into a Nazi symbol. After World War II, the medal was discontinued but neo-Nazis and other white supremacists subsequently adopted it as a hate symbol and it has been a commonly-used hate symbol ever since.

In the United States, however, the Iron Cross also became one of several Nazi-era symbols adopted by outlaw bikers, more to signify rebellion or to shock than for any white supremacist ideology. By the early 2000s, this other use of the Iron Cross had spread from bikers to skateboarders and many extreme sports enthusiasts and became part of the logo of several different companies producing equipment and clothing for this audience. Consequently, the use of the Iron Cross in a non-racist context has greatly proliferated in the United States, to the point that an Iron Cross in isolation (i.e., without a superimposed swastika or without other accompanying hate symbols) cannot be determined to be a hate symbol.

铁十字（www.adl.org）
pos_context_src: 在西方世界中，这是吉祥和好运的象征，直到1930年代[4]，当时朝向的倾斜形式成为纳粹象征主义作为雅利安人种族的象征的特征。由于第二次世界大战和大屠杀，西方许多人仍然将其与纳粹主义和反犹太主义联系起来。
纳粹党不是唯一在德国使用swastika的政党。第一次世界大战后，许多极右翼的民族主义运动采用了瓦斯蒂卡（Swastika）。作为一个象征，它与种族“纯”状态的观念相关联。到纳粹对德国的控制权时，瓦斯蒂卡的含义已经永远改变。
铁十字架是一枚著名的德国军事奖牌，其历史可以追溯到19世纪。在1930年代，德国的纳粹政权在传统奖牌上叠加了一条swastika，将其变成了纳粹符号。第二次世界大战后，奖牌被停产，但新纳粹分子和其他白人至上主义者随后将其作为仇恨象征，从那以后一直是一种普遍使用的仇恨象征。

然而，在美国，铁十字也成为了非法骑自行车的人采用的几个纳粹时代的符号之一，比对于任何白人至上主义者意识形态而言，更多地表示叛乱或震惊。到2000年代初，铁十字架的另一种用途已经从骑自行车的人到滑板运动员和许多极端的运动爱好者，并成为了为观众生产设备和服装的几家不同公司的徽标的一部分。因此，在美国的非种族主义背景下使用铁十字架已经大大增殖，以至于不能确定孤立的铁十字（即没有叠加的swastika或没有其他伴随的仇恨符号）是仇恨符号。
report_src: swastika在西方原本象征吉祥，但1930年代被纳粹倾斜使用为雅利安标志，经历二战和大屠杀后，人们至今将其直接联想为纳粹与反犹主义，因此公开佩戴几乎等同宣扬仇恨，社会普遍禁忌[1]。纳粹上台前，极右团体已将swastika与“种族纯洁”概念捆绑，使其含义永久污名化[2]。铁十字则源自19世纪德国勋章，只是在纳粹时期被加上swastika才染上纳粹色彩[3]。战后美国骑士、滑板等亚文化把不带swastika的铁十字当成叛逆或酷炫符号，广泛用于服装和机车装备，以致单独出现的铁十字难以判定为仇恨标记[4]。因此，swastika几乎一律被视为极端主义象征，而骑手常用的铁十字多被看作流行图案，但仍需结合上下文判断潜在意图。

pos_context_en: CRISPR stands for “clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats.”
This CRISPR/Cas9 tool was first described in 2012 and 2013. Science labs around the world soon started using it to alter an organism’s genome — the entire set of its DNA instructions.

This tool can quickly and efficiently tweak almost any gene in any plant or animal. Researchers already have used it to fix genetic diseases in animals, to combat viruses and to sterilize mosquitoes. They have also used it to prepare pig organs for human transplants and to beef up the muscles in beagles.

Crispr might be new, but the key points of our conversation were hardly original. We focused on the scientists’ concerns—regulatory uncertainties, access to research funding, intellectual property ownership—and on the government officials’ concerns—national security and public backlash to engineered “designer babies.” The same conversation happened in 1991 when the first gene therapy trials started on humans, and again in 1996 with the birth of Dolly, a cloned sheep. A few years later, in 2003, the sequencing of the first human genome raised the same concerns. The questions were always narrow and reductive, in part because those asking the questions only imagined a future in which we cut, copied, and pasted existing genetic material. They failed to see a future in which anyone could create life from scratch.

It was. Zhang’s work demonstrated that CRISPR could be used to precisely and efficiently edit the DNA of human cells. And with that, the revolution was under way.


Today you can go online to any number of biological-supply companies and order your own CRISPR kit for as little as $130.

该工具可以快速有效地调整任何动植物或动物中的任何基因。研究人员已经用它来修复动物中的遗传疾病，对抗病毒和对蚊子进行消毒。他们还用它来为人类移植的猪器官准备，并用贝克斯的肌肉加强肌肉。

CRISPR可能是新的，但是我们对话的要点并不是原始的。我们专注于科学家的担忧 - 调节性的不确定性，研究资金，知识产权所有权 - 以及政府官员的关注 - 对设计的“设计师婴儿”的本地安全和公众反对。同样的对话发生在1991年，当时第一次基因疗法试验开始于人类，并在1996年再次随着克隆的绵羊多莉的诞生。几年后，即2003年，第一个人类基因组的测序引起了同样的关注。这些问题总是狭窄而还原，部分原因是那些提出问题的人只是想象着我们剪切，复制和粘贴现有遗传物质的未来。他们没有看到任何人可以从头开始创造生活的未来。

report_src: CRISPR是一种基因编辑技术，全名为“定期间隔短的短质体重复序列”[1]。科学家在2012年至2013年首次描述了CRISPR/Cas9工具，随后各国实验室迅速用它来改变有机体的整个基因组[2]。它把DNA视作可以“剪切、复制和粘贴”的代码，以此实现精准的遗传材料改写[4]；凭借这一机制，研究人员已能快速且有效地调整任何动植物或动物中的任何基因[3]。具体应用包括修复动物遗传病、对抗病毒、消毒蚊子，以及为人类移植准备猪器官等[3]。如今，人们甚至可以在网上以约130美元购买一套CRISPR试剂包自行实验，显示出该技术的低成本和实用性[5]。

question_en: Year counting in ancient Greece
pos_context_title_en: The Ancient Greek Calendar | Polysyllabic (www.polysyllabic.com)
The Ancient Greek Calendar | Polysyllabic (www.polysyllabic.com)
pos_context_en:
The Athenians seem to have taken a rather casual attitude towards their calendar. It appears they used neither a regular formula nor continuous direct observation to determine the length of the months. Most likely, they followed a general rule of alternating months (29 and 30 days long), subject to periodic correction by observation.

In addition to this calendar, which has been called the festival calendar, Athenians maintained a second calendar for the political year. This "conciliar" year divided the year into "prytanies," one for each of the "phylai," the subdivisions of Athenian citizens. The number of phylai, and hence the number of prytanies, varies over time. Until 307 BCE, there were 10 phylai.

After that the number varies between 11 and 13 (usually 12). Even more confusing, while the conciliar and festival years were basically the same length in the 4th century BCE, such was not regularly the case earlier or later. Thus documents dated by prytany are frequently very difficult to assign to a particular equivalent in the Julian calendar, although we are usually secure in assigning an approximate date

Ancient historians date by Olympiad by giving both the number of the Olympiad and the year within the cycle, 1-4 (the Olympiad itself was held on year 1). Additionally, lists of Olympic winners were maintained, and the 3rd c. BCE writer Timaios compiled a synchronic list comparing Olympic winners, Athenian archons, Spartan kings, and the priests of Hera from Argos.

Olympiad 1,1 correlates to 776 BCE. We do not actually need to believe an actual festival was held on this date, but when Greek historians are writing in later times, they date their own events using this as the epoch. We can establish a precise correlation to the common era from a variety of different sources, but the most definitive comes from a passage in Diodorus, where he dates the year of a total solar eclipse to the reign of the Athenian archon Hieromnemon, which he also gives as Ol. 117,3. The only astronomically possible date for this event is August 15, 310 BCE, which fixes our epoch
question_src: 一年在古希腊
pos_context_title_src: 古希腊日历| polyllabic（www.polysyllabic.com）
古希腊日历| polyllabic（www.polysyllabic.com）
pos_context_src:
雅典人似乎对他们的日历采取了相当休闲的态度。看来他们既不使用常规公式也不使用连续直接观察来确定月份的长度。他们最有可能遵循交替的月份（29天和30天）的一般规则，但要通过观察周期性进行校正。

除了被称为节日日历的日历外，雅典人还保留了政治年度的第二个日历。这个“使人的”一年将一年分为“ prytanies”，“ phylai”一个，即雅典公民的细分。人类的数量以及prytanies的数量随时间而变化。直到公元前307年，有10个Phylai。

之后，数字在11和13之间变化（通常为12）。更令人困惑的是，虽然在公元前4世纪的和解和节日的年份基本上是相同的长度，但这种情况并非早些时候或晚些时候。因此，Prytany的文件通常很难分配给朱利安日历中的特定等效物

古代历史学家通过奥林匹克运动会来追溯到奥林匹克运动会的数量和周期内的年度，即1-4（奥林匹克本身在1年级举行）。此外，维持奥林匹克冠军的名单和第3 c。 BCE作家Timaios汇编了一个同步名单，比较了奥林匹克冠军，雅典执政官，斯巴达国王和阿尔戈斯的赫拉神父。

奥林匹亚1,1与公元前776年相关。我们实际上不需要相信在这个日期举行了一个实际的节日，但是当希腊历史学家以后写作时，他们将自己的活动与时代约会。我们可以从各种不同的来源与共同时代建立精确的相关性，但是最明确的词来自狄奥多鲁斯的一段话，在那里他将日食全年与Athenian Archon Hieromnemon的统治时期约会，他也将其作为OL。 117,3。该活动的唯一天文学日期是公元前310年8月15日，它解决了我们的时代
report_src: 在古希腊，历法因城邦而异；以雅典为例，宗教“节日日历”采用阴阳合历，一年 normally 含 12 个月，月份按“大小月”交替设 29 天与 30 天，并按观测月相不定期校正[1]。除宗教年外，雅典还有政治年，它把一年划分为若干个 prytany，数量等于公民部族（phylai）的数目：公元前307 年以前为 10 个，此后在 11–13 个之间波动（多为 12 个），因此政治年的长度随时期而变，给现代学者的换算造成难题[1]。在全希腊范围，历史学家更常用四年一周期的“奥林匹克纪年”来标记年份，同一奥林匹克的第 1 年即举行赛事的那年；按传统，第一奥林匹克第 1 年对应公元前 776 年，从而建立了连续纪年体系[2]。例如狄奥多鲁斯把一次日食记为第 117 届第 3 年，经现代天文学推算为公元前 310 年 8 月 15 日，进一步确立了奥林匹克纪年与公历的对照[2]。

question_en: How does a song get transported across an aux cable from a phone and get played in the car?
pos_context_title_en: Plugging in: differences between optical and aux audio (www.orbitsound.com)
Aux Inputs vs. USB Connections (www.lifewire.com)
The Physics of How Your Earphone Jack Works (Just in Time to Say Goodbye) (www.wired.com)
pos_context_en: In the timeline of these two formats, aux came first, in the 1960s. It’s an analogue medium, meaning it can only transmit sound. In addition to this aux cables are made of copper, and the data transmitted through it do so via the continuous waveform of electrical information.

The main difference between a USB (Universal Serial Bus) connection and an auxiliary input is that USB cords send digital information while aux cables send analog signals. USB cords transfer data as you would to a computer, while aux cables transmit audio as you would to an amplifier or pair of headphones.

At the most basic level, an earphone is a loop of wire with current running through it. This electric current in the loop then interacts with a permanent magnet which in turn pushes the air---that's sound.
question_src: 一首歌如何从手机上运输并在汽车上播放？
pos_context_title_src: 插入：光学和AUX音频之间的差异（www.orbitsound.com）
AUX输入与USB连接（www.lifewire.com）
耳机插孔的工作原理（及时及时说再见）（www.wired.com）
pos_context_src: 在这两种格式的时间表中，AUX在1960年代首次出现。这是一种模拟媒介，这意味着它只能传输声音。除了该辅助电缆外，还由铜制成，并且通过其连续的电气信息传输的数据可以通过电缆传输。
USB（通用串行总线）连接与辅助输入之间的主要区别在于，USB电源线在Aux电缆发送模拟信号时发送数字信息。 USB绳索像您一样传输数据，而AUX电缆像放大器或一对耳机一样传输音频。
在最基本的层面上，耳机是电线的循环，电流贯穿其中。然后，循环中的电流与永久磁铁相互作用，而永久磁铁又将空气推动 - 这是声音。
report_src: 当你在手机上点播歌曲时，音轨以数字数据形式储存在手机内，手机可通过两条常见路径把音乐送往汽车：若使用AUX 3.5 mm线，手机先在内部数模转换，将数字音频变成连续的模拟电压信号，再经铜芯AUX线把这些电气变化送到车载功放输入[1]；若用USB线，手机把仍为数字的比特流通过通用串行总线传输，车机或线控盒中的数模转换器随后完成解码[2]。无论是哪条路径，功放把得到的模拟信号放大并推送到汽车扬声器线圈，线圈中的电流在永久磁铁作用下驱动振膜压缩空气，从而在车厢内再现声音[3]。因此，一首歌先以数字形态存储，再在手机或车机完成数模转换，经模拟电流驱动扬声器产生声波，整个过程通常只需毫秒级延迟即可同步播放。

question_en: Why don't general physicians cover teeth?
pos_context_title_en: The Reason Your Dental Work Isn't Covered by Medical Insurance (www.nbcnews.com)
Why Doesn’t Health Insurance Cover Dental and Vision, Too? (melmagazine.com)
Why Doesn’t Health Insurance Cover Dental and Vision, Too? (melmagazine.com)
pos_context_en:
We may have since greatly evolved in how we regard and understand dentistry, but we haven’t embraced it as a primarily medical issue; if we had, it would be covered under medical insurance, or at least, things like a root canal would be, because if you need a root canal and don’t get one, you could end up with all kinds of lethal problems that lead to hospitalization. It is rumored that Queen Elizabeth died from blood poisoning as a result of an untreated tooth infection. That was a long time ago, but hey, it happens.

Why isn’t a health problem so serious it can be deadly, not considered medical? To an extent, it’s because it’s not that common to end up in the hospital as a result of a tooth or gum problem — not if you’re keeping up with preventative dental care.

That aside, one of the main reasons why our eyes and teeth are ignored by most health-care plans has to do with history and stigma. For one, dentistry and medicine have long been considered to be distinctly different practices. Until the 1800s, barbers served as unsophisticated dentists, pulling teeth and piercing abscesses after giving you a nice, close shave. As time went on, dentistry (and ophthalmology, to some degree) was regarded as less advanced than medicine, which seeped into the minds of Congress while they formulated public health insurance policies in the 1960s. As just one example of the general sentiment during those times, in 1940, an appellate court in New York decided that dentists weren’t doctors, and thus not deserving of the same prestige.

This same stigma has also led to a perception that dental and vision problems are perhaps less serious than “medical” ones, and therefore should be kept separate. (Some people may also mistakenly feel like dental problems are a personal problem that has to do with your own lapses in dental hygiene, whereas medical problems can affect everyone.) But this is a questionable stance: More than 50,000 people will be diagnosed with oral cancer this year. Research has demonstrated links between periodontal infections and chronic conditions, like diabetes and cardiovascular disease. Surely, tons of people end up in the ER because of accidents caused by them not being able to see well enough. And what about all the people who lose out on opportunities because they have a missing tooth?
question_src: 一般医生为什么不遮住牙齿？
pos_context_title_src: 医疗保险未涵盖牙科工作的原因（www.nbcnews.com）
健康保险为什么也不涵盖牙科和视力？ （melmagazine.com）
健康保险为什么也不涵盖牙科和视力？ （melmagazine.com）
pos_context_src:
从那以后，我们可能会在如何看待和理解牙科方面进行大量发展，但我们并没有将其视为主要是医学问题。如果有的话，它将被医疗保险所覆盖，或者至少是根管之类的东西，因为如果您需要根管而没有一条根管，您可能会遇到各种致命的问题，导致住院。有传言说，伊丽莎白女王因未经治疗的牙齿感染而死于血液中毒。那是很久以前的，但是嘿，它发生了。

为什么健康问题不是如此严重，它可能是致命的，而不是医疗的？在某种程度上，这是因为由于牙齿或牙龈问题而导致医院最终并不常见 - 如果您要跟上预防性牙科护理，则不是很常见。

除此之外，大多数卫生保健计划忽略了我们的眼睛和牙齿的主要原因之一与历史和污名有关。首先，牙科和医学长期以来被认为是截然不同的实践。直到1800年代，理发师在给您一个漂亮，靠近的剃须后，一直担任牙医，拔牙和刺穿脓肿。随着时间的流逝，牙科（和眼科在某种程度上）被认为比医学不那么先进，在1960年代制定公共卫生保险政策时，牙科渗入了国会的脑海。作为那段时间的普遍情绪的一个例子，在1940年，纽约的上诉法院认为牙医不是医生，因此不值得同样的声望。

同样的污名也使人们认为牙齿和视力问题可能不如“医学”严重，因此应保持分开。 （有些人可能还会错误地觉得牙齿问题是一个个人问题，与您自己在牙科卫生中的失误有关，而医疗问题可能会影响所有人。）但这是一个可疑的立场：今年将被诊断出50,000多人患有口腔癌。研究表明，牙周感染与慢性疾病（如糖尿病和心血管疾病）之间的联系。当然，由于他们无法看到足够好的事故，大量人最终陷入了急诊室。那些因为缺少牙齿而失去机会的人呢？
report_src: 19世纪牙科常由理发师兼做，被视为次于医学的手艺，故1960年代拟订公共医保时被排除在外[2]。这种分离让大众觉得牙病不算严重，多因个人卫生不佳[3]。重症牙病最终需住院者少见，立法者更难接受医保覆盖[1]。于是普通医生及常规医保迄今仍不“管”牙齿。

question_en: How can someone put me in to jail if i am not guilty?
pos_context_title_en: Why the innocent end up in prison (www.chicagotribune.com)
Why the innocent end up in prison (www.chicagotribune.com)
Why the innocent end up in prison (www.chicagotribune.com)
Why the innocent end up in prison (www.chicagotribune.com)
pos_context_en: The rate of wrongful convictions in the United States is estimated to be somewhere between 2 percent and 10 percent. That may sound low, but when applied to an estimated prison population of 2.3 million, the numbers become staggering. Can there really be 46,000 to 230,000 innocent people locked away? Those of us who are involved in exoneration work firmly believe so.

Bad police work. Most cops are honest, hard-working professionals. But some have been known to hide, alter or fabricate evidence; lie on the stand; cut deals in return for bogus testimony; intimidate and threaten witnesses; coerce confessions; or manipulate eyewitness identifications.

Prosecutorial misconduct. Most prosecutors are also honest, hard-working professionals. But some have been known to hide exculpatory evidence; encourage witnesses to commit perjury; lie to jurors, judges and defense lawyers; use the testimony of bogus experts; or ignore relevant evidence beneficial to the accused.

False confessions. Most jurors find it impossible to believe that a suspect would confess to a serious crime he didn't commit. Yet the average citizen, if taken to a basement room and subjected to 10 consecutive hours of abusive interrogation tactics by experienced cops, might be surprised at what they would say. Of the 330 people who were exonerated by DNA evidence between 1989 to 2015, about 25 percent gave bogus confessions after lengthy interrogations
question_src: 如果我没有罪，有人怎么能把我送进监狱？
pos_context_title_src: 为什么无辜者最终入狱（www.chicagotribune.com）
为什么无辜者最终入狱（www.chicagotribune.com）
为什么无辜者最终入狱（www.chicagotribune.com）
为什么无辜者最终入狱（www.chicagotribune.com）
pos_context_src: 估计在美国的不法定罪率在2％至10％之间。这听起来可能很低，但是当估计的监狱人口230万时，这些人数变得惊人。真的可以锁定46,000至230,000人无辜的人吗？我们当中那些参与免责工作的人坚信如此。
不良警察工作。大多数警察都是诚实，勤奋的专业人士。但是有些人众所周知会隐藏，改变或捏造证据。躺在看台上；削减交易以换取虚假证词；威胁和威胁证人；坦白供认；或操纵目击者的身份。
检察官不当行为。大多数检察官也是诚实，勤奋的专业人士。但是众所周知，有些人可以掩盖挖掘的证据。鼓励证人伪证；对陪审员，法官和辩护律师说谎；使用虚假专家的证词；或忽略对被告有益的相关证据。
错误的供词。大多数陪审员发现不可能相信犯罪嫌疑人会承认他没有犯下的严重罪行。然而，普通公民，如果带到地下室，并经历了经验丰富的警察的连续10个小时的虐待策略，他们可能会对他们说的话感到惊讶。在1989年至2015年之间被DNA证据免除的330人中，大约25％的人在长时间的审讯之后给了虚假供词
report_src: 在美国，研究估计2%至10%的定罪是错误的，这意味着约230万名在押人员中可能有4.6万至23万人实际无辜[1]。无辜者仍会被判刑，首先因为部分警员会隐藏、篡改或捏造证据，甚至以威胁和交易诱导假证言、操纵目击者指认，致使案件事实被严重扭曲[2]。其次，个别检察官会掩盖对被告有利的证据、鼓励伪证或使用虚假专家意见，对陪审员与法官撒谎，使辩护方无法揭示真相[3]。再次，长时间高压审讯可逼使嫌疑人在极度疲惫与恐惧中作出虚假供述；1989—2015年被DNA洗清的330人中约25%是在这种情况下认罪[4]。当警方捏造、检方违规与错误供词交织在一起，陪审团往往基于表面“铁证”裁定有罪，无辜者遂被送进监狱[2]。

question_en: Scientifically speaking , how likely is it that our existence is extremely small?
pos_context_title_en: Rare Earth hypothesis (en.wikipedia.org)
pos_context_en: The Rare Earth hypothesis argues that the evolution of biological complexity anywhere in the universe requires the coincidence of a large number of fortuitous circumstances, including, among others, a galactic habitable zone; a central star and planetary system having the requisite character (i.e. a circumstellar habitable zone); a terrestrial planet of the right mass; the advantage of one or more gas giant guardians like Jupiter and possibly a large natural satellite to shield the planet from frequent impact events; conditions needed to ensure the planet has a magnetosphere and plate tectonics; a chemistry similar to that present in the Earth's lithosphere, atmosphere, and oceans; the influence of periodic "evolutionary pumps" such as massive glaciations and bolide impacts; and whatever factors may have led to the emergence of eukaryotic cells, sexual reproduction, and the Cambrian explosion of animal, plant, and fungi phyla. The evolution of human beings and of human intelligence may have required yet further specific events and circumstances, all of which are extremely unlikely to have happened
question_src: 从科学上讲，我们的存在极小的可能性很小？
pos_context_title_src: 稀土假设（en.wikipedia.org）
pos_context_src: 稀土假设认为，宇宙中任何地方的生物复杂性的演变都需要大量偶然的环境的巧合，包括银河居住区。具有必要特征的中央恒星和行星系统（即一个居住区）；右质量的陆地行星；像木星这样的一个或多个气体巨型监护人的优势，也可能是一颗大型的自然卫星，以保护地球免受频繁的冲击事件的影响；确保行星具有磁层和板块构造所需的条件；与地球岩石圈，大气和海洋中存在的化学反应相似。周期性“进化泵”的影响，例如巨大的冰川和炸药的影响；任何因素可能导致真核细胞的出现，有性繁殖以及动物，植物和真菌门的寒武纪爆炸。人类和人类情报的演变可能需要进一步的特定事件和情况，所有这些都极不可能发生
report_src: “稀土假设”指出，若要从原始行星环境走到像人类这样的智能物种，需要同时满足一系列低概率条件：处于适宜辐射环境的银河居住区、拥有质量合适的岩石行星、旁边有木星般的气体巨型行星和大质量卫星以减少灾难性撞击、具备维持磁层与板块构造的内部热机制、岩石圈—海洋—大气化学反应相当于地球、周期性的“进化泵”如全球冰期和大型撞击，并依次触发真核细胞、有性繁殖、寒武纪爆发直到人类出现等多个偶然事件，这些因素中缺一即可中断复杂生命的演化[1]。因此，在纯概率意义上，把所有这些巧合叠加后，宇宙中产生地球级复杂生命乃至人类的机会被认为极低。然而该假设仍具争议，天文学界也在积极寻找其他生命形态以验证或反驳这一观点。

question_en: How do birds know which way is South when migrating for winter?
pos_context_title_en: How Do Birds Know Which Way is South? (www.wonderopolis.org)
How Do Birds Navigate? (www.nationalgeographic.org)
How do migratory birds find their way ? - News - EducaPoles (www.educapoles.org)
pos_context_en:
One thing birds definitely rely upon is the Sun. The Sun rises in the east and sets in the west. Birds flying south for the winter can stay on track by using the Sun's position in the sky throughout the day as a guide.


Of course, once the Sun sets, it isn't much help as a guide. Luckily, many birds can also navigate by the position of the stars in the sky once night rolls around. Constellations guided many sailors at night before modern technology came along. Birds can use the stars as navigational aids in the same way.


Birds also have the benefit of a bird's eye view. Human hikers lost in the woods sometimes must climb to the top of the nearest mountain to be able to see natural or man-made landscape features, like roads or coastlines, to find their way home. Birds just take to the sky where they get an awesome view of everything below them. Sometimes traveling south is as simple as following the path of a river that travels south to warmer temperatures.


Finally, some scientists believe some birds may also get some of their guidance from Earth's magnetic field. Some species of birds have a highly-magnetic mineral called magnetite in their brains. Experts believe this mineral may help birds detect Earth's magnetic field and use it to guide them south.

The flight paths used by birds in their annual migrations are called flyway s.


Scientists are not entirely sure how birds navigate their flyways. They seem to have an internal global positioning system (GPS) that allows them to follow the same pattern every year. A young bird imprint s on the sun and stars to help orient it. Some researchers think a bird may also recognize landmark s.


Individual organ s also contribute to a bird’s remarkable navigational ability. A bird’s eyes interact with its brain in a region called “cluster N”, which probably helps the bird determine which way is north. Tiny amounts of iron in the neurons of a bird’s inner ear also help in this determination.

nother tool is the earth's magnetic field (earth's north and south magnetic poles). Some birds, like pigeons, have a small zone in their brain made of magnetite (magnetic mineral), just like a small compass. But other scientists think it's rather in their eyes that some birds have a system which indicates them where the magnetic north is...


Of course, birds also use their knowledge of the landscape: they follow rivers, valleys or roads, or locate themselves with particular mountain peaks.


Other tracks are still to be explored. For example it seems that some birds could find their way by following their sense of smell...
question_src: 鸟类在冬季迁移时如何知道南方是哪种方式？
pos_context_title_src: 鸟类怎么知道南方的方式？ （www.wonderopolis.org）
鸟如何导航？ （www.nationalgeographic.org）
候鸟如何找到自己的方式？ - 新闻 - 教育生物（www.educapoles.org）
pos_context_src:
鸟类绝对依赖的一件事是太阳。太阳在东方升起，并在西部落下。冬天飞向南方的鸟类可以通过全天在天空中的阳光作为指导来保持正轨。


当然，一旦太阳落山，作为指导的帮助并不多。幸运的是，一旦夜晚，许多鸟类也可以通过天空中的恒星位置导航。在现代技术出现之前的晚上，许多水手指导了许多水手。鸟类可以以相同的方式将恒星用作导航辅助工具。


鸟类也有鸟类视野的好处。在树林中迷失的人类徒步旅行者有时必须爬到最近山的顶部，以便能够看到自然或人造的景观特征，例如道路或海岸线，以找到回家的路。鸟儿只是沿着天空欣赏到下面的一切。有时向南行驶就像遵循向南行驶至温度更高的河流的路径一样简单。


最后，一些科学家认为，有些鸟类也可能从地球磁场获得了一些指导。一些鸟类的大脑中有一种高磁性矿物质，称为磁铁矿。专家认为，这种矿物可能会帮助鸟类发现地球的磁场并用它来引导它们向南。

鸟类在年度迁移中使用的飞行路径称为飞行道。


科学家并不完全确定鸟类如何在飞行中航行。他们似乎具有内部全球定位系统（GPS），使他们每年都能遵循相同的模式。一只幼鸟烙印在阳光下，星星有助于将其定向。一些研究人员认为，一只鸟也可以识别地标。


单个器官也有助于鸟类的出色航行能力。鸟的眼睛在称为“簇N”的区域与大脑相互作用，这可能有助于鸟确定北方的方式。鸟内耳神经元中的少量铁也有助于这一决定。

Nother工具是地球的磁场（地球的北极和南磁极）。一些鸟类，例如鸽子，在大脑中的磁铁矿（磁性矿物）的小区域，就像一个小指南针一样。但是其他科学家认为，在他们眼中，有些鸟有一个系统，可以指示它们在磁性北的位置...


当然，鸟类还利用他们对景观的了解：它们跟随河流，山谷或道路，或者在特定的山峰上找到自己。


其他曲目仍有待探索。例如，似乎有些鸟可以通过遵循嗅觉来找到自己的路...
report_src: 在冬季迁徙时，鸟类会综合利用多套“导航仪”来判断南方：白天它们通过观察太阳东升西落的路径，并根据阳光在天空中的方位持续修正飞行方向[1]；夜晚则改用恒星的位置，如同早期水手按星图航行一般指引自己[1]；大脑中的高磁性矿物质磁铁矿能感知地球磁场，像内置指南针帮助分辨南北[1]；鸟类眼睛与大脑“簇N”区域的协作也被认为能进一步确定北向，从而推断南方[2]；此外，它们还会沿河流、山谷或海岸等显著地标飞行，以强化定位准确性[1]。多重导航机制相互印证，使候鸟每年都能精确找到温暖的南方过冬。

question_en: How are rare, valuable, irreplaceable museum artifacts transported?
pos_context_title_en: Valuable artefacts from Egypt transported to Prague’s National Museum (english.radio.cz)
Artifact Loan Procedures and Requirements (airandspace.si.edu)
Artifact Loan Procedures and Requirements (airandspace.si.edu)
How Do Museums Move Artifacts? - Square Cow Moovers (squarecowmovers.com)
How Do Museums Move Artifacts? - Square Cow Moovers (squarecowmovers.com)
pos_context_en: Dozens of artefacts discovered by Czech archaeologists in Egypt’s Abusir have been transported under strict security measures to the National Museum in Prague.

All transportation (carrier, customs brokerage, freight forwarding, additional security, storage, travel between venues, etc.) associated with transit from and to NASM, and between venues, must be approved by NASM, with all costs borne by the Borrower. The use of an approved customs brokerage firm is required to coordinate the shipping of all international loans and may be required for certain domestic loans.

If a courier is required, the Borrower will be responsible for all courier costs and any and all unforeseen expenditures required to assure the safe transport and installation of the lent artifacts as well as the transport of the courier. NASM retains the right to require that a loan be accompanied by a NASM staff courier (or outside contracted individual) and that unpacking, mounting, installation, de-installation, and repacking be supervised by the courier at the Borrower’s expense. Types of lent artifacts that generally require the aid of a courier include, but are not limited, to those possessing unique conservation concerns (such as spacesuits), highly fragile artifacts, artifacts that require specialized knowledge for installation or handling, and artifacts with high monetary or scholarly values. In addition to a courier, certain high value artifacts may require the use of specialized security escorts during transit.

The short answer to the question in the title is – very, very carefully. Since exhibitions frequently change, museums have to transport a lot of precious, culturally important items. In addition to being priceless artifacts, many museum pieces are extremely delicate and don’t fit in a standard packing box. Moving any type of artifact is a massive undertaking that requires multiple moving experts.

Moisture is the biggest cause of weather damage to artifacts. The slightest bit of humidity can damage items made of plant and animal materials. If the relative humidity is off it can also increase the chance of mildew and microbial growth.


Temperature is also a concern. Extreme cold and hot temperatures could compromise some items. Moving in the spring or fall is a preferred time in some areas since the weather is usually more temperate. The ideal temperature for many artifacts is 65 degrees Fahrenheit.


Climate has to be controlled at every stage, including short-term storage. If the truck containing the piece isn’t insulated during transport, consider how it can be packaged to provide extra insulation. Moving blankets are an excellent way to provide extra padding and insulation.


### Give Items Plenty of Space


Packing strategically is important anytime you move, but for museum quality pieces ample space is often needed. Instead of cramming everything in together like sardines to save space, heirlooms, artifacts and artwork may actually benefit from extra space.


If there’s any chance that friction or contact could damage a museum piece it’s placed in a crate or special packaging. Museums have even had to construct mounts, trays and supports to stabilize artifacts before they’re moved. When that’s not possible, the item is adequately secured in place and given plenty of room in the moving truck.


### Special Packaging for Documents


Even the documentation that authenticates a historical artifact or art piece is a vital item that has to be handled and packed with care. When you’re moving files moisture is again a top concern, but physical damage can also easily occur if documents aren’t packaged appropriately.


File boxes are designed to securely hold thousands of letter or legal size documents. File folders can also be used in the boxes to keep documents in order without causing any damage.


### Limit Light and UV Exposure
question_src: 如何运输稀有，有价值的，不可替代的博物馆文物？

工件贷款程序和要求（airandspace.si.edu）

博物馆如何移动文物？ - 方牛摩尔河（Squarecowmovers.com）
pos_context_src: 捷克考古学家在埃及的阿布西尔发现的数十种文物已根据严格的安全措施运送到布拉格国家博物馆。
与纳斯特（NASM）批准的所有运输（承运人，海关经纪人，货运转发，额外的安全性，储备，在场地之间的旅行等）必须得到NASM的批准，并由借款人批准。需要使用批准的海关经纪公司来协调所有国际贷款的运输，并且可能需要某些国内贷款。

如果需要快递员，借款人将负责所有快递成本以及确保安全运输和安装借出工件以及快递员运输所需的所有不可预见的支出。 NASM保留要求贷款由NASM员工快递（或外部合同的个人）伴随的权利，并且要以借款人的费用来监督，拆卸，安装，安装，安装，安装和重新包装。通常需要辅助快递员的借出工件类型包括但不限于具有独特的保护问题的人（例如太空服），高度脆弱的人工制品，需要专业知识进行安装或处理的文物，以及具有高货币或学术价值的文物。除了快递外，某些高价值的工件可能需要在运输过程中使用专门的安全护送。
标题中问题的简短答案是 - 非常非常谨慎。由于展览经常发生变化，因此博物馆必须运送许多珍贵的，文化上重要的物品。除了无价的文物外，许多博物馆的作品非常精致，不适合标准包装盒。移动任何类型的人工制品都是一项巨大的工作，需要多个移动专家。

水分是天气损害工件的最大原因。一点点的湿度会损害动植物材料制成的物品。如果相对湿度脱离，它也会增加霉菌和微生物生长的机会。


温度也是一个问题。极端寒冷和炎热的温度可能会损害某些物品。在某些地区，在春季或秋季移动是首选时间，因为天气通常更温和。许多伪影的理想温度为65度华氏度。


气候必须在每个阶段受到控制，包括短期存储。如果在运输过程中没有隔热的卡车，请考虑如何包装以提供额外的绝缘材料。移动毯子是提供额外填充和绝缘材料的绝佳方法。


###给物品足够的空间


无论您搬家时，战略性地包装都是重要的，但是对于博物馆的质量物品来说，通常需要足够的空间。传家宝，文物和艺术品实际上可能会从额外的空间中受益，而不是像沙丁鱼那样将所有东西塞在一起以节省空间。


如果有摩擦或接触的机会，可能会损坏放置在板条箱或特殊包装中的博物馆作品。博物馆甚至不得不建造坐骑，托盘和支撑物，以便在搬迁之前稳定文物。如果不可能，则该物品已足够固定在适当的位置，并在移动的卡车中给出了足够的空间。


###文档的特殊包装


即使是对历史文物或艺术作品进行身份验证的文档也是必须谨慎处理和包装的重要项目。当您将文件移动时，水分再次成为最大的问题，但是如果文档未适当打包，也很容易造成物理损害。


文件框旨在安全保存数千个字母或合法规模的文件。文件文件夹也可以在框中使用，以使文档保持秩序，而不会造成任何损坏。


###限制光线和紫外线曝光
report_src: 运输稀有、珍贵且不可替代的文物须先制定详尽的安全与保护方案，博物馆通常动用多名搬运专家并“非常非常谨慎”地操作[4]。对国际（及部分国内）运输，所有承运人、货运、海关经纪人等必须经馆方批准，并使用指定经纪公司办理通关手续[2]。高价值或极易损文物往往需由馆员或外部快递员全程陪同，监督拆装、重新包装，并在途中配备专门安全护送，费用由借方承担[3]。此外，捷克学者将埃及发现的文物运至布拉格时即实行“严格的安全措施”，凸显高安全级别的重要性[1]。环境控制同样关键：运输温度宜维持约65 °F（约18 °C），并严格控湿以抑制霉菌与微生物生长[5]。若车辆无法恒温，应以隔热材料、移动毯增加保温，并为每件文物预留空间、定制坐架或托盘，避免摩擦与震动[5]。随行的鉴定文件亦需防潮并置于文件盒、文件夹中妥善固定[5]。

question_en: How UPS drivers save gas by avioding left turns.
pos_context_title_en: ORION: The algorithm proving that left isn't right | UPS (www.ups.com)
Why UPS trucks (almost) never turn left (www.cnn.com)
The Science Behind Why UPS Trucks Avoid Making Left Turns (bigthink.com)
pos_context_en: Left turns mean idling, which increases the time a route takes. Left turns mean going against traffic, which increases exposure to oncoming cars. Right turns are faster. Right turns save fuel.
Left turns are also three times more likely to kill pedestrians than right ones, according to data collected by New York City’s transportation planners.

By keeping left-hand turns to a minimum, UPS says it's saved 10 million gallons of fuel, avoided the emission of 20,000 tons of CO2, and delivered 350,000 more packages a year. UPS senior vice president Bob Stoffel told Fortune, “We'll never have a person turn left to deliver on that side. We'll have someone go down the right-hand side and someone coming back down the right-hand side to avoid those left-hand turns. And that's where you get stuck in traffic trying to come back across."

为什么UPS卡车（几乎）永远不会向左转（www.cnn.com）

pos_context_src: 左转意味着空转，这增加了路线所需的时间。左回合意味着要违背交通，这增加了对迎面驶来的汽车的影响。右转弯更快。右转节省燃料。
根据纽约市运输计划者收集的数据，左转弯的杀死行人的可能性也比右手的可能性高三倍。
UPS表示，通过将左手转弯至少，它节省了1000万加仑的燃料，避免了20,000吨二氧化碳的排放，并且每年提供350,000辆二氧化碳。 UPS高级副总统鲍勃·斯托弗尔（Bob Stoffel）告诉《财富》（Fortune）：“我们永远不会有一个人转身送货。我们会让某人沿着右侧走，有人回到右侧，以避免那些左手转弯。这就是您在交通中遇到的地方，试图返回。”
report_src: UPS 的路线规划系统会尽量减少驾驶员的左转弯，因为左转常需在路口等待对向车流而长时间怠速，既拖延行程也白白耗油；相反，连续右转通常能顺着交通流快速通过，从而减少怠速时间并缩短总里程[1]。UPS 透露，这种“少左多右”的策略每年可节省约 1000 万加仑燃料，并避免排放约 2 万吨二氧化碳[3]。换言之，UPS 并非通过左转本身省油，而是通过尽量避免左转、优先安排右转来降低怠速与行驶距离，从而达到显著的节油与减排效果。

question_en: How would a bank make money if I deposited 1 billion dollars into my savings, considering the interest would be millions?
pos_context_title_en: Finance 101: How Do Banks Make Money? - Money Under 30 (www.moneyunder30.com)
Finance 101: How Do Banks Make Money? - Money Under 30 (www.moneyunder30.com)
Finance 101: How Do Banks Make Money? - Money Under 30 (www.moneyunder30.com)
pos_context_en:
It all ties back to the fundamental way banks make money: Banks use depositors’ money to make loans. The amount of interest the banks collect on the loans is greater than the amount of interest they pay to customers with savings accounts—and the difference is the banks’ profit.


For example: You currently have an emergency fund of $10,000 in a high yield savings account that may pay 1.50% APY. The bank uses that money to fund someone’s:


* Mortgage at 5.50% APR
* Student loan at 6.65% APR
* Credit card at 16.99% APR


Your bank may have paid you $150 in a year’s time but they earned hundreds or thousands more from the interest on loans (made possible with your money). Now, think about this process repeated with millions of banking customers and billions of dollars.

Yes, banks make a lot of money banks from charging borrowers interest, but the fees banks change are just as lucrative.


* Account fees. Some typical financial products that charge fees are checking accounts, investment accounts, and credit cards. These fees are said to be for “maintenances purposes” even though maintaining these accounts costs banks relatively little.
* ATM fees. There will be times when you can’t find your bank’s ATM and you must settle for another ATM just to get some cash. Well, that’s probably going to cost you $3. Such situations happen all the time and just mean more money for banks.

* Penalty charges. Banks love to slap on a penalty fee for something a customer’s mishaps. It could a credit card payment that you sent in at 5:05PM. It could be a check written for an amount that was one penny over what you had in your checking account. Whatever it may be, expect to pay a late fee or a notorious overdraft fee or between $25 and $40. It sucks for customers, but the banks are having a blast.
* Commissions. Most banks will have investment divisions that often function as full-service brokerages. Of course, their commission fees for making trades are higher than most discount brokers.
* Application fees. Whenever a prospective borrower applies for a loan (especially a home loan) many banks charge a loan origination or application fee. And, they can take the liberty of including this fee amount into the principal of your loan—which means you’ll pay interest on it too! (So if your loan application fee is $100 and your bank rolls it into a 30-year mortgage at 5% APR, you’ll pay $94.40 in interest just on the $100 fee).
question_src: 如果我将10亿美元存入我的储蓄，银行将如何赚钱，考虑到数百万的利息？
pos_context_title_src: 金融101：银行如何赚钱？ -  30岁以下的钱（www.moneyunder30.com）
金融101：银行如何赚钱？ -  30岁以下的钱（www.moneyunder30.com）
金融101：银行如何赚钱？ -  30岁以下的钱（www.moneyunder30.com）
pos_context_src:
这一切都与银行赚钱的基本方式联系在一起：银行使用储户的资金进行贷款。银行在贷款上收取的利息金额大于他们通过储蓄帐户向客户支付的利息金额，而差额是银行的利润。


例如：您目前有一个高收益储蓄帐户的10,000美元的紧急基金，该帐户可能会支付1.50％的APY。该银行用这笔钱为某人的资金提供资金：


*抵押贷款为5.50％APR
*学生贷款为6.65％
*信用卡位于16.99％的APR


您的银行一年内可能已经付了150美元，但他们从贷款的利息中赚了数百或数千美元（用您的钱使您的贷款成为可能）。现在，考虑一下数百万银行客户和数十亿美元的重复，请考虑一下这一过程。

是的，银行从向借款人的利息收取利息的费用中赚了很多钱，但是银行的变化同样有利可图。


*帐户费。一些收取费用的典型金融产品正在检查帐户，投资帐户和信用卡。据说这些费用是出于“维护目的”，即使维护这些帐户的费用相对较小。
* ATM费用。有时候，您找不到银行的自动柜员机，您必须为了获得一些现金而安顿下来。好吧，这可能会花费3美元。这种情况一直在发生，只是为银行带来更多的钱。

*罚款。银行喜欢为客户的不幸事件打罚款。您可以在下午5:05发送的信用卡付款。这可能是一张支票，比您的支票帐户中的一分钱写了一分钱。无论是什么，都希望支付滞纳金或臭名昭著的透支费，或者在25至40美元之间。这让客户很糟糕，但是银行正在爆炸。
*佣金。大多数银行将拥有经常充当全方位服务经纪人的投资部门。当然，他们进行交易的佣金高于大多数折扣经纪人。
*申请费。每当准借款人申请贷款（尤其是房屋贷款）时，许多银行收取贷款发起或申请费。而且，他们可以自由将这笔费用纳入您的贷款本金中，这意味着您也会为此支付利息！ （因此，如果您的贷款申请费为100美元，而您的银行将其额定为30年的抵押贷款，那么您将以$ 100的费用支付94.40美元的利息）。

question_en: If I were to create a company, have $1M debt, go bankrupt, how would the company that I owe get its money ? do I have to pay ?
pos_context_title_en: If A Company Goes Out of Business Do I Owe Debt to Collection Agency? (www.debtcollectionanswers.com)
When You Might Be Personally Liable for LLC or Corporate Debt (www.nolo.com)
When You Might Be Personally Liable for LLC or Corporate Debt (www.nolo.com)
pos_context_en:
The debt you owe as a debtor to a company that goes into bankruptcy administration will become part of the assets of the company in bankruptcy.


However, exactly what happens if you owe money to a company that goes out of business, and how that debt will be collected, depends in part on the status of the debt.



"The fact that a company files for bankruptcy does not automatically erase any


debt you owe."


If a lender is collecting the debt but goes out of business, you will need to continue to make payments on the loan or you risk damage to your credit reports and credit scores. If the company files for bankruptcy, the court will instruct you where to make your monthly payments if that changes. If you have any dispute over whether the debt is valid, raise that dispute as soon as you are notified of the bankruptcy. If you don’t, the debt may be considered valid.

If you cosign on a business loan, you are as equally responsible as the corporation or LLC to pay it back. This is usually the simplest way to voluntarily make yourself liable for your company's debts. Similarly, if you personally guarantee an obligation of the corporation or LLC then the creditor can come after your personal assets if the business defaults on the loan.


## Pledging Your Property as Collateral


If you have a new company or your company does not have many assets, a creditor may require you to provide some sort of collateral before approving the loan. If you agree to pledge your house or other personal assets as collateral for the business loan, the creditor may be able to take your property and sell it to satisfy the obligations of the company.


## Piercing the Corporate Veil


Above we discussed the ways you can voluntarily make yourself personally liable for a corporate or LLC debt. However, a creditor can also try to go after your personal assets by eliminating the limited liability protection provided by the corporation or LLC. This is commonly referred to as piercing the corporate veil.

more likely to pierce the corporate veil if:


* Corporate formalities, such as holding annual meetings and keeping minutes, were not followed.
* Certain owners exerted too much control over the corporation or LLC.
* Owners commingled personal funds with company funds or used personal funds to satisfy company obligations.
* The company was not sufficiently capitalized when it was formed.


(To learn more, see Piercing the Corporate Veil: When LLCs and Corporations May Be at Risk.)


## Fraud


A corporation or LLC's owners may also be held personally liable if they are found to have committed fraud

如果贷方正在收取债务但倒闭，您将需要继续向贷款付款，否则您可能会损害信用报告和信用评分。如果公司申请破产，则法院将指示您在哪里进行每月付款的地方。如果您对债务是否有效有任何争议，请在通知破产后立即提出争议。如果您不这样做，则债务可能被认为有效。

如果您签订商业贷款，那么您与公司或有限责任公司同样负责，以偿还它。通常，这是自愿对公司债务负责的最简单方法。同样，如果您个人保证公司或有限责任公司的义务，则如果企业违约贷款违约，则债权人可以追随您的个人资产。


##将您的财产保证为抵押品


如果您有一家新公司或您的公司没有很多资产，则债权人可能要求您在批准贷款之前提供某种抵押品。如果您同意保证您的房屋或其他个人资产作为企业贷款的抵押品，则债权人可能可以将您的财产带出您的财产并出售以满足公司的义务。


##刺穿公司面纱


在上面，我们讨论了您可以自愿承担公司或有限责任公司债务的方式的方式。但是，债权人还可以通过消除公司或有限责任公司提供的有限责任保护来追求您的个人资产。这通常被称为刺穿公司面纱。

如果：


*没有遵循企业手续，例如举行年度会议和保留会议记录。
*某些所有者对公司或有限责任公司施加了过多的控制权。
*业主将个人资金与公司资金或使用个人资金符合公司义务。
*公司成立时没有足够的资本化。


（要了解更多信息，请参阅刺穿公司面纱：LLC和公司可能处于危险之中时。）


＃＃ 欺诈罪


如果发现有欺诈行为，公司或有限责任公司的所有者也可能会承担个人责任
report_src: 公司进入破产程序时，100万美元债务会被列入破产财产，由破产管理人根据法定顺序用公司剩余资产（包括清算所得）向债权人分配[1]。破产本身并不会自动抹掉债务，只是由法院决定如何清偿并告知债权人付款去向[1]。在有限责任公司的正常架构下，若您既未为贷款签署个人担保，也未用个人房产作抵押，债权人通常只能从公司的资产中获得偿付，您个人无需另行付款[2]。但如果您提供了个人担保或抵押物，一旦企业违约，债权人即可追索您的个人资产来补足欠款[2]。此外，若公司资本不足、未遵守公司治理程序、混用公司与个人资金或存在欺诈，法院可能“刺穿公司面纱”，判定您对公司债务承担个人责任[3]。因此，除非存在个人担保、抵押或不当经营行为，否则公司破产后债务主要由公司资产承担，您个人通常不必掏腰包。

question_en: How can water boil below 100°C?
pos_context_title_en: What Is the Boiling Point of Water at Various Altitudes? (www.thespruceeats.com)

pos_context_en:
One of the most significant changes that occur in high altitude areas concerning cooking is the boiling point of water. As the altitude increases, the atmospheric pressure pushing down on water decreases, which allows the water to boil at lower temperatures.


A lower boiling point means that food cooks at a lower temperature, despite the fact that the water is boiling. It is important to recognize just how much the temperature of boiling water is reduced as the altitude increases.

Water molecules have an easy time escaping off the surface when the air pressure above them is less. Since this is a naturally-occurring condition in high altitude regions, the boiling point of water is reduced and thus it attains the boiling

It also impacts the boiling point of water: the temperature at which liquid water begins turning to vapor, which occurs when its vapor pressure equals the atmospheric pressure. At a higher elevation, the lower atmospheric pressure means heated water reaches its boiling point more quickly—i.e., at a lower temperature. Water at sea level boils at 212 degrees Fahrenheit; at 5,000 feet above sea level, the boiling point is 203 degrees F. Up at 10,000 feet, water boils at 194 degrees F.
question_src: 水如何煮沸100°C以下？
pos_context_title_src: 各种高度的水的沸点是什么？ （www.thespruceeats.com）
为什么水在高海拔地区迅速沸腾？ »科学ABC（www.scienceabc.com）
海拔对水沸腾时间的影响（Mountainhouse.com）
pos_context_src:
关于烹饪的高海拔地区，发生的最重要的变化之一是水的沸点。随着海拔高度的增加，大气压力下降的水减少，这使水在较低的温度下沸腾。


较低的沸点意味着食物在较低的温度下煮熟，尽管水正在沸腾。重要的是要认识到随着海拔高度的增加，沸水温度降低了多少。
当它们上方的气压较小时，水分子很容易逃脱地面。由于这是高海拔地区的天然状态，因此水的沸点减少了，因此可以达到沸腾
它还影响水的沸点：液态水开始转向蒸气的温度，当蒸气压等于大气压力时，这会发生。在较高的海拔下，较低的大气压意味着加热水更快地到达其沸点，即在较低的温度下。海平面的水在华氏212度沸腾；在海平面5,000英尺处的沸点为203摄氏度。向上10,000英尺，水在194摄氏度时沸腾。
report_src: 要让水在低于100 ℃时沸腾，关键是降低其上方的气压：当外界气压下降到与水在某一温度下的饱和蒸汽压相等时，水分子无需再克服海平面常压即可逸出液面，于是就在这一更低温度开始剧烈汽化[2]。在自然环境中，海拔越高，大气压越小，因此同样加热条件下的水会在更低温度就达到沸点；例如在高山地区，人们常发现水已经“滚腾”而实测温度却明显低于100 ℃[1]。实验室或工业上也可用真空泵抽走空气，制造低压容器，使水在室温甚至更低的温度下就能沸腾，这一原理同样源于压强降低导致沸点下降[3]。总之，无论通过上山还是抽真空，只要把环境压力降到水在目标温度时的蒸汽压，即可让水在100 ℃以下沸腾。

question_en: Why were native American populations decimated by exposure to European diseases, but European explorers didn't catch major diseases from the natives?

Why did Native Americans die from European diseases while Europeans didn't catch serious diseases from the New World? (history.stackexchange.com)
pos_context_en: Native Americans (and indigenous islanders) did not have many diseases on their side to use against the Europeans. Plagues spread quickly between people. Secondly, if you get a plague, either you die or you become immune. If you survive, you will never get it again, because now your body knows how to kill it. However, you can still carry the plague, and you can spread it to other people, but it can't hurt you.

Plagues prosper when you have a civilization/city which does a bad job of separating sewage from drinking water. This can help spread the plague, which helps evolve it fast. This makes deadly plagues. One such city which had bad water management was London.
So, since the New World had less cities (and less population), it had less plagues.

This means that to have a plague, you must have as much contact with animals as possible. In the Old World, where farmers tended for cows and pigs, while warriors rode horses and elephants, there was a much higher chance of accidentally getting a disease from the animal that in the New World, where there was not as much contact between animals and humans.

pos_context_src: 美洲原住民（和土著岛民）对欧洲人没有很多疾病。瘟疫在人之间迅速传播。其次，如果您遭受瘟疫，则要么死亡或变得免疫。如果您生存，您将永远不会再得到它，因为现在您的身体知道如何杀死它。但是，您仍然可以携带瘟疫，并且可以将其传播给其他人，但不会伤害您。
当您有一个文明/城市，瘟疫繁荣起来，该文明/城市在将污水与饮用水中分离出来时做得不好。这可以帮助传播瘟疫，这有助于快速发展。这会导致致命的瘟疫。伦敦的一个这样的城市是水管理不良的城市。
因此，由于新世界的城市（人口较少），因此瘟疫较少。
这意味着要有瘟疫，您必须与动物尽可能多地接触。在旧世界中，农民倾向于牛和猪，而勇士骑马和大象则是在新世界中意外地从动物那里感染疾病的机会，在新世界中，动物与人之间没有太多接触。
report_src: 欧洲人在中世纪以来的高密度城市中长期与污水混杂的饮用水相处，使致命传染病不断出现并快速进化，幸存者逐步积累了免疫力[2]；这些幸存者虽然自身无恙，仍可携带病原体远行传播[1]。相反，美洲原住民聚居规模较小，城市稀少，缺乏能让病原体持续循环并变异的大人口池，因此历史上几乎没有类似的大流行病，也就没有相应的免疫屏障[3]。此外，旧世界农民与牛、猪等多种家畜长期密切接触，而骑士亦与马、大象相伴，动物到人的跨种传播机会极多；新世界的可驯化大型哺乳动物极少，人畜接触有限，难以孕育对人类高度致命的新病原[4]。于是，当携带天花、麻疹等病毒的欧洲探险者抵达，美洲人群毫无免疫力，死亡率极高；而欧洲人面对新大陆稀有且毒性低弱的本土病原，则几乎不受严重威胁。

question_en: how is a heavy duty clog cleaner able to work on a significant amount of standing water?
pos_context_title_en: Buyer’s Guide: The Best Drain Cleaners (www.bobvila.com)
How Drain Cleaners Work (home.howstuffworks.com)
How Drain Cleaners Work (home.howstuffworks.com)
pos_context_en: Sulfuric acid is the key ingredient of this ultra-strength acidic drain cleaner. It’s potent enough to clear sink and toilet clogs that other cleaners leave behind. Use by pouring one-and-a-half to two cups of cleaner into a drain, waiting for 15 minutes, then flushing for five minutes with cold water.

* Oxidizing drain cleaners contain substances such as household bleach, peroxides and nitrates. These chemicals cause the organic material of the clog to lose electrons and become oxidized. The product is heavier than water, so it can move through standing water, and it releases heat and gas to help clear the blockage. * Acid drain cleaners aren't commonly found in stores, and some are sold only to plumbers. These typically contain high concentrations of sulfuric acid or hydrochloric acid, substances that increase hydronium ions in a solution and attract electrons from the clog. The hydronium ions react chemically with the material in the clog, and the reaction releases heat, which is necessary to melt congealed grease [source: Sheridan].

Be they liquid, gel or powder form, most of the drain cleaners you'll find on store shelves use strong chemicals, and they come in liquid, gel and powder forms. All chemical reactions involve moving electrons, and drain cleaners work by either taking or giving electrons to the clogging substance, generating heat in the process. There are three main types of drain cleaners:

 * Caustic drain cleaners contain substances such as lye and caustic potash. They're bases, so they give electrons to the clogging substance, and their hydroxide ions create the reaction that clears the clog. Their alkaline, or basic, chemicals release heat and turn grease into a soap-like substance that's more easily dissolved. These drain cleaners are typically heavier than water, which enables them to reach the clog through standing water.

*氧化排水清洁剂含有诸如家用漂白剂，过氧化物和硝酸盐等物质。这些化学物质会导致堵塞的有机物质失去电子并被氧化。该产品比水重，因此它可以在积水中移动，并释放热量和气体以帮助清除阻塞。 *酸排水清洁剂在商店中没有发现，而有些则仅出售给水管工。这些通常含有高浓度的硫酸或盐酸，这些物质会增加溶液中的氢离子并吸引堵塞的电子。氢离子与堵塞中的材料化学反应，反应释放热，这是融化凝结油脂所必需的[来源：Sheridan]。

pos_context_en:
Living off the land means you survive only by the resources that can be harvested from the land you own.


So, think food, water, and power.

The following values reflect the cost of land, housing, off grid solar system, heating systems, well, septic, transportation, gardens, livestock, and misc expenses. Moving off the grid can cost about $12,000 to $450,000 for common off grid living situations. Average monthly expenses run from $35 to $2,200. This accounts for housing, heating, water, and gardening expenses, that are unique to off grid living,

### Home Insurance


Be aware that off grid homes tend to be farther from fire rescue and other emergency services and tend to have wood heat. This makes home insurance much more expensive than you might be used to. We have seen cases of people paying more than double what the usual rates are.

### Fire Wood


Many people going off grid anticipate cutting their own firewood, but underestimate the effort and cost of buying firewood. Depending on how cold your winters are, the quality of your stove, the type of wood you have access to, and the insulation of your house, you could end up using anywhere from about 3 to 10 cords of wood per season.

A typical garden fence at homestead scale costs around $5,000. Most homesteaders go for a tall wire fence of this kind. Good quality fruit trees run about $60-$80/each. Berries – $15-$20/each. If you are buying seeds each year, then a large family garden would usually cost $100 – $200 per year.

report_src: 人类确实属于杂食动物：首先，“杂食是一种行为分类，所有人类社会都会食用肉类”[1]；其次，我们拥有能储存胆汁、一次性分解大量脂肪食物的胆囊，这种器官特征常见于食肉或杂食动物[2]；再次，人类牙列既有切削门齿也有磨碎臼齿，显示对动植物双重食源的适应[3]；此外，我们比从植物来源更能有效吸收动物性铁，这也是对动物食物的生理适应[4]。然而，一些素食主义者认为人类是草食动物，主要基于两点：其一，现代社会无需依赖肉类即可维持健康，他们认为“在2011年，我们不需要吃肉、乳制品或鸡蛋即可生存或蓬勃发展”[5]；其二，他们指出人类缺乏捕猎爪、尖锐犬齿及高度酸性的胃液，认为这些特征不符典型食肉者[6]。因此，科学证据支持“杂食”定位，而草食观点多出于伦理、生态及现代营养可替代性的考量。

question_en: Anabolism vs. Catabolism, what is each, how does each affect the human body, what the positives/negatives are of each.
pos_context_title_en: Anabolism vs. Catabolism: The Role They Play in Your Metabolism (health.clevelandclinic.org)
Anabolism vs. Catabolism: The Role They Play in Your Metabolism (health.clevelandclinic.org)
Anabolism vs. Catabolism: The Role They Play in Your Metabolism (health.clevelandclinic.org)
Difference Between Anabolism and Catabolism - An Overview (byjus.com)
pos_context_en:
When you think catabolism, think digestion, says DiMarino. This process takes larger structures like proteins, fats or tissues and breaks them down into smaller units such as cells or fatty acids. 


Catabolism occurs when you’re digesting food. For example, it’s the process that dissolves a piece of bread into simple nutrients your body can use, like glucose (blood sugar). And if your body isn’t getting the food and nutrients it needs to fuel daily living, catabolism is the mechanism that breaks down muscle and fat for energy.

### What is anabolism? 


Anabolism is the opposite of catabolism: It’s the mechanism that takes smaller units like nutrients, cells, or amino acids and bonds them together to create bigger structures. 


“One example of anabolism in action is when your body is trying to heal a cut. It adds tissue and structures around that wound,” DiMarino explains. “It’s also the process involved in a child’s growth and in building stronger muscles.”

Catabolism functions no matter what you give your body, states DiMarino. It breaks down food, whether it’s junky or nutritious. Whatever it doesn’t use for energy now, it stores for later (hello, extra pounds). 


But anabolism is entirely different. It only functions properly when you’re getting enough nutrients through foods like vegetables, fruits and lean meats. Your body needs high-quality building blocks to heal, repair and grow.

The major differences between Catabolism and Anabolism are the way the molecules are utilized in the body. Anabolism creates molecules the body needs for functionality and it uses energy in the process. Catabolism, on the other hand, breaks down complex molecules and releases energy which is available for the body to use.

pos_context_src:
Dimarino说，当您认为分解代谢时，请思考消化。该过程采用较大的结构，例如蛋白质，脂肪或组织，并将其分解成细胞或脂肪酸等较小单位。 


当您消化食物时，会发生分解代谢。例如，这是将一块面包溶解成人体可以使用的简单营养的过程，例如葡萄糖（血糖）。而且，如果您的身体没有获得日常生活所需的食物和营养，那么分解代谢就是破坏肌肉和脂肪的能量的机制。

###什么是代谢性？ 


代谢是分解代谢的相反：这种机制采用较小的单位，例如营养素，细胞或氨基酸，并将它们结合在一起以创建较大的结构。 


Dimarino解释说：“动作中代谢性的一个例子是，当您的身体试图治愈切割时。它在伤口周围增加了组织和结构。” “这也是孩子成长和建立更强壮的肌肉的过程。”

Dimarino指出，分解代谢的功能无论您给身体什么。无论是垃圾还是营养，它都会分解食物。无论现在不用于能源，它都可以存储以后（您好，额外的磅）。 


但是合成代谢完全不同。仅当您通过蔬菜，水果和瘦肉等食物获得足够的营养时，它才能正常起作用。您的身体需要高质量的构件来治愈，修复和生长。
分解代谢和合成代谢之间的主要差异是分子在体内使用的方式。代谢产生了人体对功能性的需求，并在此过程中使用能量。另一方面，分解代谢会分解复杂的分子并释放能够使用的能量。
report_src: 分解代谢是把蛋白质、脂肪等较大结构拆解成细胞、脂肪酸或葡萄糖等小单位，过程伴随能量释放，用于即时活动或转存为脂肪，因此是人体“供能端”[1]；当摄食不足时，它还会分解肌肉和脂肪以维持生命，虽能救急却可能导致肌肉流失、体重反弹等负面结果[1]。代谢性（即合成代谢）则相反，把营养素、氨基酸等小分子重新组合成新的组织，如伤口愈合时增生组织、儿童长高及增肌，属于“建造端”且需消耗能量[2]；只有当饮食提供充足且高质量的蔬果与瘦肉等原料时，它才能顺利进行，否则修复、生长效率下降，肌肉难以增强[3]。总体而言，分解代谢的优势在于快速提供能量，但过度或长期缺乏食物会带来组织损耗；合成代谢的优势在于修复和生长，但若营养不足或能量供应不平衡，其功能受阻并消耗大量能量[4]。

question_en: Why does my pee smell like asparagus when I eat asparagus but it never smells like anything cool, like lobster tail or ice cream sundae, when I eat something cool?
pos_context_title_en: Why Does Asparagus Make Your Pee Smell? (health.clevelandclinic.org)
Why Does Asparagus Make Your Pee Smell? (health.clevelandclinic.org)
Why Does Asparagus Make Your Pee Smell? (www.healthline.com)
Why Does Asparagus Make Your Pee Smell? (www.healthline.com)
Why Your Pee Smells Funny After Eating Asparagus (www.webmd.com)
pos_context_en:
1. Everyone digests food differently and some people can break down the sulfur byproducts more efficiently.
2. Some people lack the ability to detect the odor simply because of genetic variations.

The main culprit is aspargusic acid, which is found exclusively in asparagus. When asparagus is digested, asparagusic acid gets broken down into sulfur containing byproducts. Sulfur, in general, is not very pleasant to smell, notes Dr. Bobart. When you pee, the sulfur byproducts evaporate almost immediately, causing you to smell that unpleasant scent.

The asparagusic acid in asparagus produces many sulfurous byproducts that give your pee a rotten-like smell.


The smell can be detected as early as 15 minutes after eating asparagus and may last up to 14 hours.
One study in 6,909 adults noted that 58% of men and 62% of women had asparagus anosmia, suggesting that this specific genetic modification is quite common

Researchers believe that, during digestion, the vegetable's sulfurous amino acids break down into smelly chemical components in all people. And because those components are "volatile," meaning airborne, the odor wafts upward as the urine leaves the body and can be detected as soon as 15 minutes after you eat this spring delicacy.

pos_context_src:
1。每个人都对食物的消化不同，有些人可以更有效地分解硫副产品。
2。有些人仅仅因为遗传变异而缺乏检测气味的能力。
罪魁祸首是芦笋，仅在芦笋中发现。当消化芦笋时，天峰酸被分解成含有副产品的硫。 Bobart博士指出，总的来说，硫磺的气味不是很愉快。当您撒尿时，硫副产品几乎立即蒸发，使您闻到令人不愉快的气味。

芦笋中的山地天酸会产生许多硫化副产品，使您的小便像腐烂的气味。


食用芦笋后15分钟可以发现气味，可能持续长达14小时。
一项在6,909名成年人中的研究指出，有58％的男性和62％的女性患有芦笋厌食症，这表明这种特定的遗传修饰很普遍
研究人员认为，在消化过程中，蔬菜的硫酸氨基酸分解成所有人中臭的化学成分。而且由于这些成分是“挥发性的”，意思是空降，因此气味会在尿液离开身体时向上飘动，并且在您吃今年春季美味佳肴后的15分钟后可以检测到。
report_src: 吃芦笋后尿液散发出特殊气味，是因为芦笋独有的山峰酸（asparagusic acid）在消化过程中被分解成多种含硫挥发物，这些硫化物气味刺鼻并在尿液排出时几乎立即蒸发[2]。研究表明，气味可在进食后约15分钟出现，并可能持续长达14小时[3]。相反，龙虾尾或冰淇淋等食物不含这种能迅速产生高挥发性硫化物的底物，因此它们的代谢产物不会显著改变尿味。感知差异也起作用：有些人能更有效地分解硫副产物，使气味更浓[1]；另一些人因遗传变异缺乏检测这种气味的能力，一项针对6,909名成人的研究发现约58%男性与62%女性存在“芦笋尿失嗅症”[4]。因此，芦笋特殊的化学成分及个体代谢与嗅觉差异，共同解释了只有它让你的尿闻起来“像芦笋”。

pos_context_en: some people get "conditioned" to worry, ruminate, plan, think and engage their brains during the night. This association is not intentionally formed. It's the result of accidental learning. This is amplified if you try to avoid worries during the day by keeping yourself busy and distracted. After a while, lying in bed at night becomes the only time for major concerns to rise to the surface of awareness.

“You can’t stop your brain from thinking, but you can distract it by focusing on something neutral,” says Findley. Since digital screens can further disrupt sleep, he recommends analog distractions whenever possible—like reading a physical book

report_src: 我们临睡前容易思绪万千，主要是因为我们在夜间无意中把“躺在床上”和“担忧、反省、计划”建立了条件反射：白天用忙碌把杂念压下，真正安静下来只剩上床这一刻，大脑便把被按下的念头一股脑地推到意识表面[1]。这种偶发学习使大脑错误地将“该想事”标记为睡前任务，越想越清醒[1]。同时夜间外部刺激骤减，无法再用工作或手机等强烈信息源继续“分心”，内部思维自然成为注意力唯一焦点，感觉停不下来[2]。打破这一循环可通过给注意力一个中性目标（如阅读纸质书）来重塑关联，让大脑重新学习“上床＝放松”[2]。

question_en: How do people get away with squatting in a house without getting arrested?
pos_context_title_en: Squatters’ Rights: Guide to State Law & How-To Evict - AAOA (www.american-apartment-owners-association.org)
Squatters’ Rights: Guide to State Law & How-To Evict - AAOA (www.american-apartment-owners-association.org)
Squatters: What's Legal, What's Not, & How to Get Rid of Them (www.biggerpockets.com)
pos_context_en:
Squatters rights refers to laws which allow a squatter to use or inhabit another person’s property in the event that the lawful owner does not evict or take action against the squatter.


Typically, squatters rights laws only apply if an individual has been illegitimately occupying a space for a specific period of time. In New York, for example, a squatter can be awarded “adverse possession” under state law if they have been living in a property for 10 years or more.’

Some of the states listed above require the squatter to possess a deed, or to have paid taxes during their occupancy, while others do not. In some states, if the squatter can produce the required documentation, the number of years may be reduced.

On top of that, they also need to use the land as a real owner would. Each jurisdiction and judge will have different criteria for evidence of this, but it could include anything from the tenant maintaining the property to paying utilities or even property taxes.

pos_context_src:
擅自占地的权利是指允许擅自占地者使用或居住在合法所有者不驱逐或采取行动对棚户区采取行动的法律。


通常，仅当个人在特定时间段内非法占用空间时，棚户权利法律才适用。例如，在纽约，如果他们在财产中居住了10年或更长时间，则可以根据州法律授予擅自占地者。”
上面列出的一些州要求擅自占地者拥有契据，或者在其占用期间缴纳税款，而另一些则不缴纳税款。在某些州，如果擅自占地者可以产生所需的文件，则可以减少年数。
最重要的是，他们还需要像真正的所有者一样使用土地。每个司法管辖区和法官都将有不同的标准来证明这一点，但其中可能包括从维护财产到付费甚至财产税的租户的任何内容。
report_src: 想在房屋内“蹲住”而不被捕，通常必须满足所在州“擅自占地权”（adverse possession）的要件：第一，持续且公开占用物业达到法定年限，例如纽约须居住满10 年[1]；第二，根据部分州规定，期间需持有契据或按时缴纳房产税，以显示对物业拥有“主人般”的控制[2]；第三，要像真正业主那样使用和维护房屋，包括修缮、缴费甚至支付税款，以说服法官自己履行了所有者职责[3]。在法定年限内若合法所有者未提出驱逐，警方往往把纠纷视作民事问题而非刑事入侵，因而擅自占地者可避免被逮捕[1]；但各州标准不同，若未完全符合当地法律，仍可能随时被驱逐或面临刑事责任。

question_en: Why is it such a faux-pa to ask someone how much money they make? Is it like that in other cultures?

pos_context_en: Parfait Eloundou-Enyegue, a development-sociology professor at Cornell University, told me that when income or wealth is invoked as a status symbol, it can spark a competition with others that will be unpleasant for all involved. “For that reason,” he said, “people will refrain from the most blatant forms of self-puffery unless they are absolutely necessary or effective.”

"People feel sensitive about how much money they are making, they feel there is an overwhelming concern that they're going to be judged by it," explained Dr. Ryan T. Howell, an Associate Professor of Psychology at San Francisco State University, and co-founder of Beyond the Purchase, which allows individuals to discover how their spending choices affect their happiness.

These primal definitions we attach to money (from power and control, to freedom, peace of mind, and security, to love—giving money without strings attached or giving money with strings attached) indicate that we, as a society, too often conflate earning power with success and personal value, and regard a low income as a result of poor choices or even moral failings. "I think people are generally afraid that if they reveal they make less than one of their friends they'll be regarded with pity, while if they reveal they make more they'll be treated with resentment," said Jennifer Wright

“It goes against social conventions to talk about how much money you have or how much money you make,” she told me. “I think there’s also reluctance, among the people I interviewed for my book, to recognize how much money they have, partly because they’re worried they have more.”


Some of that reluctance comes from having a lot of money in a society that is known to be unequal. “It’s convenient, right? That we have this taboo,” Sherman said, in the sense that not talking about money might allow people who have the most of it in a given society to ignore that fact.

Similar forms of this “constant chatter” are found elsewhere as well. In a 2018 article for Vice, the writer Paulette Perhach noted that in Paraguay, “people openly ask how much you make, how much your phone costs, and even, one time when I handed someone a present, how much I paid for it. When I told the birthday girl how much her gift was, she chided me that I’d overpaid, and told me I should have gone to another store for a better price.”

pos_context_src: 康奈尔大学（Cornell University）的发展 - 社会学教授Parfait Eloundou-Enyegue告诉我，当收入或财富作为地位象征时，它可能会引发与其他人的竞争，这对所有参与者而言都是不愉快的。他说：“因此，除非他们绝对必要或有效，否则人们将避免最公然的自我形式。”
旧金山州立大学心理学副教授瑞安·霍维尔（Ryan T. Howell）博士解释说：“人们对自己的赚钱量感到敏感，他们认为他们将被它判断。”
这些原始的定义我们附加在金钱上（从权力和控制，到自由，安心和安全到爱，再到爱 - 没有条件的金钱或与绳子相关的金钱）表明，作为一个社会，我们经常将收入的能力与成功和个人价值混为一谈，并将低收入视为不良选择甚至是道德失败的结果。詹妮弗·赖特（Jennifer Wright）说：“我认为人们通常会担心，如果他们透露自己的结识少于他们的朋友中的一个，而如果他们透露更多的话，他们会受到怨恨的对待。”

她告诉我：“谈论您有多少钱或赚多少钱是违背社会惯例的。” “我认为，在我为书中采访的人中，人们也不愿意认识他们有多少钱，部分原因是他们担心自己还有更多的钱。”


其中一些不情愿来自在一个众所周知的不平等社会中拥有很多钱。谢尔曼说：“这很方便，对吗？我们有这个禁忌。”从某种意义上说，不谈论金钱的人可能会允许在给定社会中拥有最多的人忽略这一事实。
这种“恒定聊天”的类似形式也可以在其他地方找到。在2018年的《 VICE》的一篇文章中，作家Paulette Perhach在巴拉圭指出：“人们公开问您赚了多少钱，您的电话费用，甚至有一次，当我递给某人礼物时，我为此付出了多少。
report_src: 在美国等英语文化中，询问别人收入被视为“人造pa”（社交禁忌），主要因为金钱被当作地位象征，公开比较会引发不愉快的竞争感[1]；人们担心收入曝光后会被他人评价高低[2]，收入高者怕遭嫉妒，低者怕被视为能力或道德失败[3]；因此“谈论你有多少钱”被认为违背社会惯例[4]。然而这种禁忌并非普世；例如在巴拉圭，人们会自然地问你赚多少、电话费多少，甚至礼物花了多少钱，都被视为普通聊天[5]。可见收入话题敏感度取决于文化对金钱与个人价值的关联强弱及社会不平等程度，美式避谈是一种特定社会结构和价值观塑造的“人造”禁忌，而非人类普遍本能。

question_en: What causes us to tear up when we cut onions? Is there a way to prevent this?
pos_context_title_en: Why Do Onions Make You Cry? Enzymes, Treatments & More (www.healthline.com)
Why Do Onions Make You Cry? Enzymes, Treatments & More (www.healthline.com)
Why Chopping Onions Makes You Cry (www.webmd.com)
pos_context_en:
Onions spew enzymes and sulfenic acid when their skin is broken. These compounds combine to produce propanethial S-oxide, an irritating gas.


Propanethial S-oxide is a lachrymatory agent, meaning that it generates tears when it touches the eye. Propanethial S-oxide turns into sulfuric acid when it touches the water layer that covers and protects your eyeballs.


But just like onions, your eyes are also equipped with a defense mechanism meant to protect them from harm. When the nerves in each eye detect a lachrymatory agent, they generate tears to flush it out.
The tears you shed while chopping onions are not caused by any type of emotion. They’re reflex tears stimulated by exposure to irritants.

"Your eyes have a set of nerves that detect anything that's potentially harmful to your eyes. Your eyes react to the gas that is formed, and your eyes try to flush it out with tears," Rosa explained in a school news release.


However, onions pose no serious threat to your visual health.


"Chopping onions can cause some burning and irritation and tears. Other than that, it's pretty safe on your eyes. It's a temporary sensation with no known long-term effects, nor will it worsen any other conditions, like pink eye," Rosa said.


Goggles can prevent the gas from reaching your eyes while cutting onions, but they aren't really necessary, he added.


"Some people may cut the onions in a bowl of water," Rosa said. "I'd personally recommend using eye drops, like comfort drops, to help lubricate or rinse the eyes and dilute the gas exposure to the eyes."

当洋葱破碎时，洋葱会喷出酶和硫酸。这些化合物结合起来产生抗硫化S-氧化物，一种刺激性的气体。


抗硫化S-氧化物是一种液化剂，这意味着当它接触眼睛时会产生眼泪。当抗硫化氧化物接触覆盖和保护眼球的水层时，它会变成硫酸。


但是就像洋葱一样，您的眼睛还配备了一种防御机制，旨在保护它们免受伤害。当每只眼睛的神经都检测到液化剂时，它们会产生眼泪以冲洗掉。
您在切碎洋葱时流下的眼泪不是由任何类型的情感引起的。它们是通过暴露于刺激物的反射眼泪。

罗莎在学校新闻稿中解释说：“您的眼睛有一组神经，可检测到任何可能有害的眼睛。您的眼睛对形成的气体反应，而您的眼睛试图用泪水冲洗掉。”


但是，洋葱不会对您的视觉健康构成严重威胁。


罗莎说：“切碎洋葱会引起一些燃烧，刺激和眼泪。除此之外，它在眼中还很安全。这是一种暂时的感觉，没有已知的长期影响，也不会恶化其他任何条件，例如粉红色的眼睛。”


他补充说，护目镜可以防止割洋葱时气体到达您的眼睛，但并不是真正必要的。


罗莎说：“有些人可能会在一碗水中切下洋葱。” “我个人建议使用眼滴（例如舒适滴）来帮助润滑或冲洗眼睛，并将气体暴露于眼睛。”
report_src: 切洋葱时，细胞被破坏后会释放酶和含硫化物，它们结合生成刺激性气体丙烯基硫氧化物（抗硫化 S-氧化物）；该气体接触眼睛泪膜后转化为微量硫酸，刺激角膜神经，使眼睛反射性大量分泌泪水以冲洗刺激物[1]。因此产生的是“反射泪”，并非情绪所致[2]。想减少流泪，可通过阻断或稀释气体：佩戴贴合的护目镜以阻止气体接触眼睛[3]；在一碗水中或自来水下切洋葱，让气体先溶于水[3]；切完后使用人工泪液滴眼，帮助润滑并冲洗残留刺激物[3]。气体刺激只是短暂不适，对视力无长期危害，是否采取防护视个人需求而定[3]。

question_en: How long would it take to see the stars when you take light pollution away?
pos_context_title_en: EarthSky | How many stars can you see? (earthsky.org)
EarthSky | How many stars can you see? (earthsky.org)
EarthSky | How many stars can you see? (earthsky.org)
Globe at Night - What is Light Pollution? (www.globeatnight.org)
light pollution | Definition, Causes, & Facts | Britannica (www.britannica.com)
pos_context_en:
What if you were far away from city lights, on a night with no moon and no clouds or haze. How many stars could you see with your unaided eye?


There’s really no definitive answer to this question. No one has counted all the stars in the night sky, and astronomers use different numbers as theoretical estimates.

Considering all the stars visible in all directions around Earth, the upper end on the estimates seems to be about 10,000 visible stars. Other estimates place the number of stars visible to the eye alone – surrounding the entire Earth – at more like 5,000. At any given time, half of Earth is in daylight. So only half the estimated number – say, between 5,000 and 2,500 stars – would be visible from Earth’s night side.


Plus, another fraction of those visible stars would be lost in the haze all around your horizon. That could bring you down to around 2,000, the number commonly used for these estimates. Just know that it varies depending on a number of factors.

You also have to take into account the brightness of your night sky. Even on a moonless night, the glow of lights from Earth’s surface brightens the sky.


Still, far from city lights – under absolutely perfect conditions of darkness and sky clarity – a young to middle-aged person with normal vision should be able to see thousands of stars.

Light pollution is excessive, misdirected, or obtrusive artificial (usually outdoor) light. Too much light pollution has consequences: it washes out starlight in the night sky, interferes with astronomical research, disrupts ecosystems, has adverse health effects and wastes energy.

Light pollution adversely affects professional and amateur astronomers, as well as casual observers of the night sky, because it severely reduces the visibility of stars and other celestial objects. The reduction in night sky visibility is a result of “skyglow,” upward-directed light emanating from poorly designed or directed lamps and security floodlights. This wasted light is scattered and reflected by solid or liquid particles in the atmosphere and then returned to the eyes of people on the ground, obliterating their view of the night sky.

pos_context_src:
如果您远离城市灯光，在没有月亮，没有云或阴霾的夜晚，该怎么办。您可以用独立的眼睛看到几颗星星？


这个问题确实没有明确的答案。没有人算出夜空中的所有恒星，天文学家使用不同的数字作为理论估计。

考虑到所有恒星在地球周围的所有方向上都可见，估计值的上端似乎是10,000个可见恒星。其他估计，仅在整个地球周围可见的恒星数量更大，更像是5,000。在任何给定时间，地球的一半是在日光下。因此，从地球的夜面可以看到估计数字的一半 - 例如，在5,000至2500颗恒星之间。


另外，这些可见的恒星中的另一部分将在整个地平线周围的雾霾中丢失。这可能会使您达到约2,000个，这些数字通常用于这些估计。只是知道它因许多因素而异。

您还必须考虑到夜空的亮度。即使在一个无月的夜晚，地球表面的灯光也使天空亮起。


尽管如此，远离城市灯光 - 在绝对完美的黑暗和天空清晰的条件下 - 一个有正常视力的年轻人与中年人应该能够看到成千上万的恒星。
光污染过多，误导或令人震惊的人造（通常是户外）光。过多的光污染具有后果：它在夜空中冲出星光，干扰天文学研究，破坏生态系统，具有不良的健康影响和浪费能量。
光污染对专业和业余天文学家以及夜空的休闲观察者产生不利影响，因为它严重降低了恒星和其他天体的可见性。夜空可见性的降低是“ Skyglow”的结果，这是从设计不良或有向灯和安全泛光灯的向上指导的光。这种浪费的光被大气中的固体或液体颗粒散射和反射，然后回到地面上的人们的眼睛，抹去了他们对夜空的视野。
report_src: 光污染通过向上泄漏的灯光产生“skyglow”，大气把这些光散射回地面，抹去人们对夜空的视野[5]；当这些光源被关闭或遮蔽后，此类散射光立即消失，天空随即变暗，星星开始重新显现。对人眼而言，最亮的星体在几秒内即可被察觉，而完全暗适应（即视网膜对弱光敏感度达到极限）大约需要 20 分钟；一旦达到这一状态，在无月、无云并远离城市灯光的夜晚，视力正常的年轻人可以用裸眼看到成千上万颗恒星[3]。因此，从消除光污染到“看见星星”几乎是瞬间的过程，而要恢复到能看到最大数量星星的最佳视力，大约需等待 20 分钟左右。

question_en: Is there a biological reason that human beings are attracted to certain facial characteristics (such as a defined jawline) or is it just cultural preferences?

pos_context_en: Attractiveness ratings of the images made by male participants relate positively to parameters of skin homogeneity. The authors propose that skin texture is a cue to fertility and health. In contrast to some previous studies, the authors found that dark skin, not light skin, was rated as most attractive.

The Evolutionary Advantage theory proposed that symmetrical faces are perceived as more attractive because the symmetry indicates good health in an individual. Everyone’s genes are designed to develop a face perfectly symmetrical, but as we grow, develop, and then age, disease, infections, and parasites cause imperfection in our appearance (asymmetry). Thus, those that have less asymmetry and imperfections, are perceived as having better and stronger immune systems to withstand the infections and parasites that occur naturally. So, symmetry is a good indicator of a person having good genes to pass on their offspring.

A strong Jawline is attractive to the opposite sex


This is a well documented fact, right from an evolutionary perspective. A strong jawline in men is considered to be a sign of high testosterone levels which translates into greater virility. High testosterone levels are a sign of a strong immune system which means greater strength and stamina; therefore a strong jawline in men is considered a trait that is attractive to women.


Women with sharp jawlines are equally attractive to men and a well defined jawline in women is considered a sign of strength, grace and responsibility; traits that are extremely attractive to men. Some of the most beautiful actresses and models are observed to have an extremely chiseled jawline.

pos_context_src: 男性参与者对图像的吸引力等级与皮肤同质性的参数呈正相关。作者建议皮肤质地是生育和健康的提示。与以前的一些研究相反，作者发现，深色皮肤而非皮肤，被评为最具吸引力。
进化优势理论提出，对称面孔被认为更具吸引力，因为对称性表明个人的健康状况良好。每个人的基因旨在发展出完全对称的脸，但是随着我们的成长，发展，年龄，疾病，感染和寄生虫的外观不完美（不对称）。因此，那些不对称和瑕疵较少的人被认为具有更好，更强的免疫系统来承受自然发生的感染和寄生虫。因此，对称是一个很好的指标，表明一个人具有良好基因可以传递其后代。

强壮的下巴对异性有吸引力


从进化的角度来看，这是一个有据可查的事实。男性的强壮下巴被认为是高睾丸激素水平的迹象，它转化为更大的活力。高睾丸激素水平是强大的免疫系统的标志，这意味着强度和耐力。因此，男性的强壮下巴被认为是对女性有吸引力的特征。


尖锐的Jawlines的妇女对男性同样有吸引力，而女性的下巴却被认为是力量，优雅和责任的标志。对男人极具吸引力的特征。观察到一些最美丽的女演员和模特具有极其凿的下巴。
report_src: 人类对面部特征的偏好兼具生物学基础与文化塑形：在进化心理学框架下，实验发现男性脸部皮肤越光滑均匀且色调较深时，受试者给出的吸引力评分越高，研究者解释为肌肤同质性和色泽可作为健康与生殖能力的信号[1]；面部左右对称度越高，也被观察者普遍视为更迷人，因为对称提示发育过程中较少疾病或寄生虫干扰，意味着“好基因”可遗传后代[2]；而清晰有力的下颌缘被认为反映较高睾酮水平与更强免疫系统，因此被异性视为活力与力量的标志[3]。这些跨文化重复出现的生物指标说明吸引力评判并非纯粹社会建构；不过不同社会的美学标准（如对肤色深浅、面部线条柔和度的偏好）仍会随历史与媒体而变动，显示文化可在生物框架内微调人们的具体审美。

question_en: Why do we prefer cold pillows to warm pillows?
pos_context_title_en: While You Are Sleeping (www.webmd.com)
Learn How to Sleep All Night Naturally and Not Wake Up (amerisleep.com)
Too Hot to Sleep? Lots of Cooling Tips Here (bebrainfit.com)
Here Are The Effects Of Sleeping In A Cold Room | Sleep Advisor (www.sleepadvisor.org)
Here Are The Effects Of Sleeping In A Cold Room | Sleep Advisor (www.sleepadvisor.org)
pos_context_en: It tends to go up and down a little during the day, and the same is true at night, although while you’re sleeping it can be 1 to 2 degrees lower than in the daytime. Body temperature starts to fall as bedtime approaches, paving the way for a good night’s sleep. Your body also tends to lose heat, which helps you fall and stay asleep. That’s one of the reasons experts say you shouldn’t exercise close to bedtime: Exercise heats you up. We sleep better when we’re cooler. Your temperature starts to rise toward morning, preparing your body for wakefulness.
Keep it cool. The ideal temperature for sleep is around 65°, so set your thermostat accordingly. If that seems too chilly for comfort, experiment to find the temperature that’s right for you.

During this part of the sleep cycle, you lose some of your ability to thermoregulate, i.e., adjust your inner temperature to the surrounding air temperature.


So when the room temperature is too warm, your body starts to heat up which can wake you and make it hard to get back to sleep.

A stressful day and an overactive brain aren’t the only things keeping you awake at night. Studies show that people who suffer from insomnia tend to have a warmer core body temperature before falling asleep than so-called normal people.


Remember that our bodies cool off at night in anticipation of sleep. But if your body automatically runs hot, you’ll have to alter your environment to cool your temperature down enough to signal that it’s time for bed.

Sleeping barefoot and sticking one or both feet out from under the covers will help keep you cooler. We lose a lot of body heat through our head, hands, and feet, so allowing your feet to breathe has a cooling effect.
question_src: 为什么我们更喜欢冷枕头而不是温暖的枕头？
pos_context_title_src: 当您睡觉时（www.webmd.com）
了解如何整夜睡觉而不是醒来（amerisleep.com）
太热了无法入睡吗？这里有很多冷却技巧（bebrainfit.com）
这是在寒冷的房间里睡觉的影响|睡眠顾问（www.sleepadvisor.org）
这是在寒冷的房间里睡觉的影响|睡眠顾问（www.sleepadvisor.org）
pos_context_src: 白天它往往会上下上下，而晚上也是如此，尽管当您睡觉时，它可能比白天低1到2度。就寝时间即将来临，体温开始下降，为睡个好觉铺平了道路。您的身体也倾向于失去热量，这可以帮助您跌倒并入睡。这就是专家说您不应该在就寝时间锻炼的原因之一：运动加热您。凉爽时我们睡得更好。您的温度开始在早晨升高，为您的身体醒来做准备。
保持冷静。理想的睡眠温度约为65°，因此请相应地设置恒温器。如果这似乎太冷了，无法进行舒适，可以找到适合您的温度。

在睡眠周期的这一部分中，您将失去一些热量调节的能力，即将内部温度调节到周围的空气温度。


因此，当室温太热时，您的身体开始加热，这会唤醒您并难以入睡。

压力很大的一天和过度活动的大脑并不是让您晚上清醒的唯一事情。研究表明，患有失眠症的人在入睡前往往比所谓的正常人患有较高的核心体温。


请记住，我们的身体在晚上预计睡眠时会冷静下来。但是，如果您的身体自动炎热，则必须改变环境以冷却温度，以表明该是时候了。
赤脚睡觉，将一只或两只脚从盖子下方伸出，这将有助于使您保持凉爽。我们的头部，手和脚失去了大量的身体热量，因此让您的脚呼吸具有冷却效果。
report_src: 入睡前大脑会指挥核心体温下降约1-2 ℃，散热越顺畅，入睡越容易[1]；因此睡眠时身体“喜欢”凉爽，当环境或卧具过热时，体温无法下降，反而会被过度加热而惊醒或难以再次入睡[3]。失眠者常表现为入睡前核心体温偏高，必须通过外部降温给身体“提示”现在该睡觉了[4]。头部与手脚一样是主要散热部位，暴露或接触凉爽介质能快速带走热量，从而帮助体温达到入睡所需的低点[5]。冷枕头正好提供了一个持续散热的接触面，让头部血管将热量转移到枕头中，既符合夜间降温的生理节律，又避免因过热出汗带来的醒觉不适；相比之下，温暖的枕头阻碍散热，使核心体温难以下降，降低入睡速度和睡眠深度[1]。

question_en: Shutter Speed and Aperture.
pos_context_title_en: Understanding ISO, Shutter Speed and Aperture - A Beginner's Guide (photographylife.com)
Understanding ISO, Shutter Speed and Aperture - A Beginner's Guide (photographylife.com)
Nikon | Imaging Products | DSLR Camera Basics (imaging.nikon.com)
pos_context_en: Shutter Speed – the length of time a camera shutter is open to expose light into the camera sensor. Shutter speeds are typically measured in fractions of a second, when they are under a second. Slow shutter speeds allow more light into the camera sensor and are used for low-light and night photography, while fast shutter speeds help to freeze motion.

Aperture – a hole within a lens, through which light travels into the camera body. The larger the hole, the more light passes to the camera sensor. Aperture also controls the depth of field, which is the portion of a scene that appears to be sharp. If the aperture is very small, the depth of field is large

changing aperture also changes depth of field, while changing shutter speed alters the appearance of moving objects. In other words, you can also adjust aperture for depth of field or shutter speed to produce the effect of motion.
question_src: 快门速度和光圈。
pos_context_title_src: 了解ISO，快门速度和光圈 - 初学者指南（Photophotyylife.com）
了解ISO，快门速度和光圈 - 初学者指南（Photophotyylife.com）
尼康|成像产品|数码单反相机基础知识（imaging.nikon.com）
pos_context_src: 快门速度 - 摄像机百叶窗打开的时间长度将照明暴露于相机传感器中。快门速度通常以一秒钟的分数测量，当它们不到一秒钟时。慢快门速度可为摄像机传感器带入更多的光线，并用于低光和夜间摄影，而快门速度有助于冻结运动。
光圈 - 镜头内的一个孔，光线通过该孔进入相机体。孔越大，光线就会传递到相机传感器。孔径还控制着景深，这是一个看似清晰的场景的部分。如果光圈很小，则景深很大
更改孔径还会改变景深，而更改快门速度会改变移动对象的外观。换句话说，您还可以调整孔径的景深或快门速度以产生运动的效果。
report_src: 快门速度指相机快门开启的时长，通常以1秒的分数表示；速度慢（如1/4 s）时传感器获得更多光线，适合夜景或营造动态拖影，速度快（如1/1000 s）可冻结运动[1]。光圈是镜头内让光线进入机身的孔径，孔越大（如f/2.8）进光越多且景深变浅，孔越小（如f/16）进光减少但景深扩大[2]。创作时可借改变光圈控制景深，或调节快门速度表现运动效果，两者需配合以获得正确曝光与预期视觉效果[3]。

The 6 Most Common Subject Line Mistakes to Avoid (blog.aweber.com)

Overview of the Junk Email Filter (support.microsoft.com)
pos_context_en:
Sometimes the words you choose are what’s keeping you from reaching your prospect.


This applies most to your email subject line. Words like “free,” “money,” “help” and “reminder” all trigger content-based email spam filters. Especially if you’re not added as a contact in your recipient’s email database.
Special characters such as * % & # and ^, have been known to trigger spam filters, so be sure to use them sparingly as well.

The Junk Email Filter evaluates each incoming message to assess whether it might be spam, based on several factors. These can include the time when the message was sent and the content of the message.
Any message that is suspected to be junk is moved to the Junk E-mail folder.

question_en: Seismologists: How do you determine whether an earthquake was naturally occurring or if it was human induced?
pos_context_title_en: Human-Induced and Natural Earthquakes are 'Inherently Similar,' According to LSA Researcher | U-M LSA U-M College of LSA (lsa.umich.edu)
Natural or manmade quakes? New Stanford technique can tell the difference (news.stanford.edu)
Manmade and natural earthquakes not so different after all (earth.stanford.edu)
pos_context_en:
Huang's work discovered that stresses released by natural and human-caused earthquakes are similar, which means that the same tools might be used to predict both.


"Our study shows that induced earthquakes and natural earthquakes in the central U.S. are inherently similar, and we can predict the damaging effects of induced earthquakes using the same framework as natural earthquakes," said Huang.

A new study by Stanford researchers suggests that earthquakes triggered by human activity follow several indicative patterns that could help scientists distinguish them from naturally occurring temblors.

The research concludes that human-induced and naturally occurring earthquakes in the central U.S. share the same shaking potential and can thus cause similar damage.


The finding contradicts previous observations suggesting that induced earthquakes exhibit weaker shaking than natural ones. The work could help scientists make predictions about future earthquakes and mitigate their potential damage.
question_src: 地震学家：您如何确定地震是自然发生的还是是人类引起的？
pos_context_title_src: LSA研究人员称，人类引起的自然地震是“天生相似的” | U-M LSA U-M LSA学院（lsa.umich.edu）
天然还是人造地震？新的斯坦福大学可以说出差异（news.stanford.edu）
毕竟人造和自然地震并没有那么不同（Earth.stanford.edu）
pos_context_src:
黄的工作发现，自然和人为引起的地震释放的压力相似，这意味着可以使用相同的工具来预测两者。


Huang说：“我们的研究表明，美国中部引起的地震和自然地震本质上相似，我们可以预测使用与自然地震相同的框架的诱发地震的破坏性影响。”
斯坦福大学研究人员的一项新研究表明，人类活动触发的地震遵循了几种指示性模式，可以帮助科学家将其与自然发生的狂热区分开。

研究得出的结论是，美国中部的人类引起的和自然发生的地震具有相同的震动潜力，因此可能造成相似的损害。


这一发现与以前的观察结果相矛盾，表明诱发的地震比自然的地震较弱。这项工作可以帮助科学家对未来地震做出预测，并减轻其潜在损害。
report_src: 要判断一次地震是自然还是人类诱发，地震学家首先比较其时空分布与工业活动的关系：若震源集中在废水注入、采矿或水库区，并在作业启动或注液量变化后短期内出现，说明人为触发的可能性大[2]；其次查看震源深度与聚簇特征，诱发地震通常较浅且在数月内成簇出现，而自然地震多沿深部断层长期活动[2]；还会统计震级—频次关系并与历史背景比对，若某区原本地震稀少却在人类作业后迅速增加，同样指向人为因素[2]。然而，美国中部的最新观测表明，两类地震在应力释放和破坏潜力上几乎无差异，所以即便确认成因，仍应按自然地震的最严标准评估风险[1]。

question_en: How do we synchronize our pace when walking next to someone?
pos_context_title_en: Walking Together May Resolve Conflicts During the Pandemic (www.psychologytoday.com)
Mirror neuron system (www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov)
In sync and in control? (newsroom.ucla.edu)
In sync and in control? (newsroom.ucla.edu)
pos_context_en:
Social walking is one way to activate "mirror-neuron networks."


We mimic each other’s pace and gait, swinging our arms and legs in unison. This entrains other physical processes: Our breathing becomes more synchronized and our heart rates increase and decrease (as we walk faster or slower, up-hill or down) at similar times. Walking together also elicits social-cognitive processing to help us understand the other person’s intentions and plans and process their social cues (speech, expression, gesture) in order to anticipate their movements and predict their trajectory.

Mirror neuron system is a group of specialized neurons that “mirrors” the actions and behaviour of others. The involvement of mirror neuron system (MNS) is implicated in neurocognitive functions (social cognition, language, empathy, theory of mind) and neuropsychiatric disorders.

We have found that when men are walking in step with other men, they think that a potential foe is smaller and less physically formidable and less intimidating than when they’re just walking in no particularly coordinated manner with other men

Even though each participant was accompanied only by a single companion, those who walked in unison with their partners judged the angry man as significantly less physically imposing than did the study subjects who had not walked in unison with their confederate: On average, they estimated that the man in the photo was about an inch shorter than the other participants did.
question_src: 在与某人旁边行走时，我们如何同步我们的步伐？
